Regardless, it's a fun, abstract game to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
345
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[COLOR=#FFFFFF][BGCOLOR=#FF9933][b]aaj's FAVORITE STOCK TRADER[/b][/BGCOLOR][/COLOR]
Acquire is a classic game that unlike many has stood the test of time effectively. There's no theme to speak of (unless buying and merging hotel chains is your jam), the component quality is shoddy, and the core mechanic of the game (drawing new tiles) is entirely based on luck. So why is it so highly regarded?

For one thing, it's so much better than its competition. Other games from the 1960s were even worse, so Acquire stands out even today simply because of its company. If this game were launched amidst the Terra Mysticas, Puerto Ricos, and Pandemics of today it might not be noticed. But as it is, it stands out. 

Secondly, Acquire presents you with meaningful decisions. The hidden money and stocks mean that you have to keep track of other players' positions as you play, and expand and merge the hotel chains accordingly. Though there is luck in drawing each tile, the fact that you have six of them at a time means that you very rarely have nothing useful to play. 

The genius of Acquire rests in its bonus system. When a hotel chain is subsumed into another chain, a bonus is awarded for the player who has the most stock in that company. Additionally, bonuses are recorded at the end of the game as well. This makes merging chains a strategic decision that carries a lot of weight for you and every other player. Often, a skilled player can ride a wave of mergers to a dominant position in the largest remaining hotel chain at the end of the game, and cruise to victory on his bonuses. 

This is why Acquire is so great: there's a great deal of tense thought that goes into every tile placed. It's a harsh and unforgiving game that rewards players with a good memory, and penalizes those who play carelessly. This type of game isn't for everyone (it definitely isn't for my wife) but it will always have a place in my collection because there's not really anything out there that has replaced it yet.

You can fuggedaboutit when it comes to theme, but Acquire still represents one of the best of 3M's bookshelf series, and it's rightly considered a classic. This mind game will have you blocking and maneuvering other players to come out the richest.

RATING: 8
I really like Acquire. I used to play a 4-players version on my Palm Pilot. The rules are easy to learn and despite the tile drawing aspect, there is really a skill to gain on that game: which tiles to play or to retain? Where to play on the board? What to buy? When? Sure, you're getting a huge advantage in being able to gain money early in the game and that first move is giving you a strong momentum that opponents may have difficulties to recover. Still, I find the game very nice: I like the tile-laying aspect as well as the majority aspect of it. I wish it was as renowned as Monopoly is today.

RATING: 6
2010-04-12
The 1966 edition of the game I owned, smelled good. However, I sold this because it got very few plays.

2016-04-12
Acquire is themed as an economy/market speculation game. However, this description does not fit. It is a tile placement game and you speculate which entities stay on the board the longest and grow the most. 

You could kind of expect that a game from 60's would not provide any real decision but this is not the case here. Players are given a number of tiles to form a personal stack and the contents is for their private information only. Thus you can make some educated guesses which "companies" will grow, and critical tiles give you even some control over the game.

This speculation is really the meat of the game. Tactical decisions and correctly timed moves serve as garnish. You cannot really follow any great strategies since the tiles you draw dictate the possibilities you have. So the game falls at the tactical end of the spectrum and as such it is a notable one.

RATING: 9
My wife loves to hate this game, but it's always a hit with visitors. The strategy is somewhat counter-intuitive, so people almost always want to play it again after their first time. It might initially seem like there is a lot of luck involved, but the strategy required to play well makes it challenging. That is probably one of the main reasons this game has been around for so long! If you can remember who has what (and how many) cards and accurately foresee how mergers might happen, you might not find yourself penniless for too long.

RATING: 6
A classic stock game. You are building hotel chains, merging with other companies, and buying and selling stock in an attempt to make the most money. This is the game monopoly should have been. It's influence on my appreciation of stock games is significant as one of my earliest exposures to the mechanic in games and can be seen in other great games I own like airlines Europe and imperial. This game rarely gets to the table with my gaming friends now as more sophisticated games have displaced it but I am always happy to get it out for the casual crowd as it is still a solid "gateway" game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favorite game.  Not really a finance game either - deals with stocks/majorities/mergers, but that's just the theme.  Might turn some people off, but if you can get around that, it's a really intense game of short-term gain vs. long term gains.  In 4-6 player games 1-2 people will get shafted and the first merger is very important.  Works best with 3 players, maybe 4 at most.  But if you run out of money it's usually your fault as there are layers of tiles you shouldn't play.  And most games you won't have a merger before you place a new company.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great game with simple rules that works with even newer gamers and also works if people do not wish to negotiate in the game or do, although I feel the game is much more fun doing so. The rules are simple yet very satisfying in terms of strategy and logic to when to hedge into many hotel's shares or horde one hotel's shares, given the imperfect information presented to one. The Game is also short and sweet at about a hour plus.
Downside is thematically there is some things that don't work like the real market but overall the theme still comes through and the older edition's 3D plastic pieces seem much more sought after than the current cardboard version out there. 
Overall, I do enjoy the game and can say it will work in more than just one particular type of group.

RATING: 8
1st play: I absolutely underestimated this game. The pacing is excellent, tense decisions abound and this may be Sackson's best game. I can understand why it's been around so long and reprinted so many times. Can't wait to play again.

2nd play: A solid game the second time around. I debated whether it was worth a 7 or an 8, but then I realized the game played in 70 minutes, start to finish. If it were a 90-120 minute game, I think it would be a 7, but packing so much game into such a short time period pushes it just slightly up to the low 8 range.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This game is really nothing to look at. In fact, and some people are likely to become a little defensive about this, it has dated badly. Of course the layout makes sense, but it isn't attractive, and paper money is a problem nearly every time. 

Mechanically, this is one of those games that does one thing really well. Unfortunately it only does one thing. 
The approach it has to 'investment' is undeniably clever, and offers some real-world connection. 

Dynamically, shifting values and notions of how to ride someone else's preferences to profit are fun. However, in this game, it's all so bare that the ugliness of the variance feels unsatisfying, rather than tense. 

Overall, I think a lot of games present the investment dynamic in a more palatable way. I don't pretend to enjoy this foundation in many games - I realised quickly I didn't like stock games - but I need at least some skin over the skeleton. 

I'D RATHER PLAY: [thing=822][/thing] at 2-3, [thing=54138][/thing] at 4-5. Carcassonne is subtly a game of investment, as long as you're playing with the Big Meeple, and Imperial 2030 is free and beyond-math enough to assimilate any player order errors at the heavier scale. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A game that's still worth playing after 20 years!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
STRATEGY

Build hotels and buy equity in existing ones. Fight for the majority stake in takeovers and mergers, hostile or otherwise. A good game!

There can be some amount of downtime between turns. The negative effect of this (possibly disengagement from the game) can be minimized by reducing distractions, like resisting one's cellphone and not talking to someone who isn't playing the game.

Recommended with 3-6 players (best 4). 90 mins.

RATING: 7
I think this game is about as mechanically sound as you can get hence the high rating. But, while I enjoy it, I never really go out of my way to suggest it. I bring it to game nights because it's simple, supports many players, and nobody dislikes it. I do enjoy playing against AI from time to time on GTO (for free).

Playing with any assets hidden is pointless since you can track them. The random tile draw and hand management is enough hidden information for this game. I guess if you like making uninformed decisions in a game that already has a significant random element knock yourself out with "hidden" info.

update: I recently played in what may have been the best game of Acquire I've personally witnessed. First through fourth were separated by a mere $4K and I only won by $300. I did this by making sure I retained some cash on hand even when my majorities were being threatened. This game really solidified my opinion that Acquire is a very demanding game in regards to management of cash. Don't spend all your money until you have an absolute sure thing. 

Yes, there's a luck element and no, you can't negate it. But you can really help yourself by following one simple rule:

DON'T SPEND ALL YOUR MONEY

update: lowered to 7 due to becoming more interested in no-luck economic games of higher complexity like Chicago Express, Imperial, and 18xx. I still think it's a great game and very newbie friendly but I'd almost always rather play a heavier game in the right company. This is excellent lighter fare, however.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Classic but a little dry for the mainstream. None of the post-Bookcase Edition versions have been improvements although naming a chain after Sackson is a touch of class..

Regarding Hasbro's 2016 version: The smaller game board means a few more mergers and the new payoff schedule means more money will be in play for the participants. The production, however, leaves something to be desired. The spaces should have their names painted as with other editions. There is not enough play money for the final payoffs. There is no excuse for that.

I rate it this low only because I'm so terrible, thereby lowering my willingness to play!  One of my better $2 thrift store acquisitions...

RATING: N/A
[i]Location: Basement (FR)[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Well, Monopoly and Scrabble had a one night stand and gave us Acquire!

No, well actually it's a totally different beast, but it IS a business game that uses tiles on a grid as some form of abstractified business positioning and growth indicator - odd thematically but in practice it is perfectly easy to follow through.

When two companies meet, the one that get swallowed up is the smaller of the two - and the owners of shares in that company are the people who make money.

An excellent change from the norm, and decades ahead of the curve.

RATING: 7
I've been playing this for years. It used to be an innovative game but lately has become a bit dated. The income distribution early on can be brutal. A player or two can be essentially out of the game through no fault of their own. But it is a good solid economic game. I think there are variants out there that will help with the early game income problems that occasionally crop up. Overall though this is one of those game that everyone should play. In terms of just number of versions and the history of the game in publication this one rivals any game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Acquire is a game of fun and fortune for 2 to 6 players. High adventure in the world of finance.
All it takes is a little luck - and a lot of strategy. Each player builds and strategically manipulates vast, profitable hotel chains.  Grow your hotel chains, invest in them, then merge them in order to collect the stock bonuses. Shrewdly buying the right stock at the right time. Decide when is the best time to merge your chain of hotels. Control the stocks of your hotel chains and ensure you're the major stock holder. Invest in your opponent hotel chains in hopes to gain a majority bonus payout. Buy, Grow and Sell in a calculated race to acquire the greatest wealth.

Expected playing time is about 1.5 - 2 hours

RATING: 7.5
2011-02-15
Very interesting tile laying stock game.  You have to be careful in this one to actually not buy stock in the company that will eventually be the strongest, because you need to invest in smaller companies that will pay off when they get acquired so that you have enough money to keep up the continual investments.  Pretty neat game, and although the tile drawing is "luck", this game is not luck driven at all.

RATING: 8
3-6(4)

I can see why it's a classic. It looks drab, perhaps, but it does exactly what it needs to do very elegantly, while also adding plenty of tension.

The auctions and everything from that are great and I do like how the only real way to get money in-game is selling, not converting, your shares during a merger. However, this does sort of possibly lead to scenarios in which players are sort of completely hamstrung (or rather, I suppose, just wait out a merger that they can participate in).

Still, as far as games within the relatively heavy share ownership auction game mechanisms go, this is a beauty in how quickly and easily it plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I hunted around and paid a little over the top for the 1999 - Avalon Hill large box version. The one with the large plastic board and pieces

When I first bought this game I thought it was ok but nothing special. After repeated playing though it has grown on me. It isn't a game that will overwhelm you with different routes to victory and variety of game play. It has very subtle strategies that you'll refine over repeated plays. 

It's pretty easy to teach, apart from one or two rules about payouts that won't click with beginners until a merger or two has taken place. On their second playing they'll have it down no trouble at all. 

I must say even though I haven't played any other version of this game so I could be wrong, I have a feeling that the set I bought (through its aesthetics) contributes to the gaming experience more than it should for me. I'm not sure I'd have the same feelings for this game if I were playing on a cardboard set with cardboard companies, as seen in the recent edition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The king of all financial management games Acquire is deceptive in its play. Strategy is truly wedded to the market, NOT in the firm way people can read a wargamers mapboard, but in the player&#039;s perception of that market.
It&#039;s all about anticipation based on imcomplete information, like the &quot;real world&quot;. From there the game allows for a variety of strategic approaches akin to investing strategies: you can be a risk-taker or risk-averse. You can play the market or hold pat.
The only con to the game is players, especially late in the game, can bog down trying to get optimal placement and results.
So what? it&#039;s called &quot;maximizing your return on investment&quot;!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
PROS:
*) Simple and clever idea
*) Rules are straightforward
*) Careful planning required (especially so that you don't run out of money at a critical time)

CONS:
*) Still a significant luck factor (if you get the necessary bits to create a company, or merge two)
*) Often loses tension in the end, when it's clear which corporations will survive, and which will be swallowed up.

RATING: 7
Some heavy luck elements with the tile drawing, but that doesn't stop me from really liking this game.  My paper money game of choice.  I don't see many good comebacks though.  Most of the time you will know who is still in the race for first by mid game once a major chain takes off.  After that, it sometimes has a habit of playing itself.  Still, there is lots of room for bold moves and wild stock speculation, which keeps it tense if you can stay among the contenders.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
9/4/17: No catch-up mechanism, and it is possible to be in a situation where you don't get to participate in mergers and you get left in the dust.  Fortunately it's a short enough game that this doesn't last long.

6/11/16: A little chaotic with 5.  I would think that with 6 you would have little to no control.


A fun lighter game that has been around a long time.  The last Avalon Hill/Hasbro version has some great eye candy appeal.  You need to manage your money well and being stuck on the sidelines with stock and no cash while mergers happen around you can seriously suck the fun out of the game.  A little light on theme.  I enjoy playing this, but it is not as rewarding to me as other games.  

Growing up we played a variant known as the "John Smith" variant.  The name has been changed to protect those who were found guilty in a court of law.  This variant was based on the life and times of my mother's stockbroker.  In this variant you place one blank spare chit in the draw pile. (My edition came with spares.)  When drawn, you can use this chit at any time by placing it on a competitors chain.  With the chit placed, players have one round to add to that chain of hotels.  If the chain is not expanded during the round it burns down on the placing players next turn and is removed from the board.  This can lead to an anxious round if no chits have been kept in reserve and other players don't have enough stock in a chain to want to save it.  In real life the chain in question was a Bobby McGee's restaurant, and yes, my mom did switch stockbrokers after this.  The "John Smith" arson variant rule did much to add to the enjoyment of our games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
8/16/2014: Can play with 7.

11/29/2009:A fun lighter game that has been around a long time.  The last Avalon Hill/Hasbro version has some great eye candy appeal.  You need to manage your money well and being stuck on the sidelines with stock and no cash while mergers happen around you can seriously suck the fun out of the game.  A little light on theme.  I enjoy playing this, but it is not as rewarding to me as other games.  

Growing up we played a variant known as the "John Smith" variant.  The name has been changed to protect those who were found guilty in a court of law. Recommended with 7 but you start getting a little downtime.

RATING: 6
The rule tweaks between this and the 2008 edition are not trivial. For example, shrinking the safe corporation size and adding a tertiary shareholder bonus. It will take more plays to evaluate these changes.

I was quite disappointed with the component quality. The tile bag isn't big enough. The board coordinates are impossible to read. The tile and board coordinates use a stylized font that isn't very clear. There are 2 corporations with very similar colors. The player aids are a bit worse, missing a couple reminders (e.g. safe corporation size).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
套利是個適合 5 人左右(遊玩人數為 3 ~ 6 人) 的遊戲，遊戲時間大約是 80 分鐘。

玩家藉由放下手上有編號的板塊，進行下列動作：
1. 成立新的企業 (連續兩個以上相連的板塊，且不屬於任一企業)、
2. 合併企業 (當兩個企業的板塊相接起來時，板塊少的被板塊大的併購)、
3. 擴大企業

遊戲的訣竅在於如何變現你手上的股票。因為玩家的現金有限，且購買的股票是不能賣出的。玩家必須想辦法讓某家企業被併購，然後把手上該家企業的股票換成現金。由於持股最多的玩家們可以獲得而外的獎金，所以要設計好如何讓自己成為併購案中獲利最多的人。

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I finally got to try this classic, and although the rules made it sound tremendously fun, the actual game isn't.  The tile placement restrictions leave a lot of your success up to chance.  Sure, there are some moves you can plan for, but after players place their "useful" tiles they are at the mercy of whatever they randomly draw.  Furthermore, players can be hurt very early in the game by not being part of the first few successful mergers.

Additionally, there are times during the endgame when your only legal move will be to play a tile that helps a company you have very few shares in, thus pushing your opponents even closer to victory.  The math-heavy "collect a ton of money at the end of the game" portion felt very anticlimactic as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

All time classic.  Easy to learn, no dice.  Devious strategy game.

RATING: 7
Initial play: 6-02-07
Played with 5 people and it was fun.  Yeah, there is quite a bit of luck in this game but it is still enjoyable.  Will scour BGG for rules to see if the rules from wikipedia that was in the box accurate.  Will play more to get a better feel of the game to rate.  For now it certainly is enjoyable and will play again.

Update: 6-23-07
I have been enjoying my games so far.  I have been playing with standard rules so far and it has been fine.  However, I think the game might be a bit flawed that there is a run away leader.  If you are the few people to have the first mergers payout, you have a very big head start investing in other companies to further increase your wealth.  Being stuck without money early on is very rough.  I am still unsure about this game.  It is a solid game but we'll see how it goes with more plays.

RATING: 7.5
Wow, this game is 50 years old! Sid Sackson was obviously a time traveler!

This is truly a modern and ingenious design, and after having played this classic I finally begin to understand why Sackson is considered the father of the euro games genre...

The rules are so elegantly simple, but the gameplay so rich and engaging... Sometimes luck can decide the outcome of a game, but usually skillful play is the main factor that leads to victory.
A true classic, that can be played with the family or among gamers, and that I absolutely need to play more!

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Next time I'll write down all the stock purchases (or just play with the stocks face up).  Otherwise good play relies too much on memory for my tastes.  The game relies upon the limit of three stocks that may be purchased on a given turn, and the way players can run out of money waiting for a merger.  Tile play seems obvious and is highly constrained by random chance, of course.  Therefore, the heart of the game is which three stocks to buy each turn...not quite enough choice for me in a game lasting 30-60 min.

RATING: 7.5
12/31/06

This game is so simple and yet very engaging.  There can be tough decisions to make, especially concerning where to build, whether or not to merge and what stocks to buy. 

Players who don't have their companies merged early in the game can have some trouble catching up as the game progresses so always aim to get some small payouts early to assist in moving forward.

RATING: 10
I bought this version with hopes that it would be more visually appealing to my family and friends who don't want to play my 1968 version. Although I'm very disappointed in the production of this reprint, it may just do the trick. The game is the same, the major difference is the components. 

The stocks are now on durable cards instead of thin cardstock. The hotel chains are nicely done in color. The tiles are just large grey cardboard chits to cover the black board - very unexciting. My main complaint is the tile (chit) holders. The tiles can't stand up on their own like the old tiles, so they created a stand out of cardboard that is ugly and flimsy. 

I finally "acquired" the Hasbro version with the plastic hotel pieces. No point in holding onto this lesser version. TRADED.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
StockMarket, MultiOnly

You can see the roots for similar tile-laying games like T&E or Reef Encounter in play here; people complain about not being able to place a tile wherever they want to, but that's the nature of the stock market---which Acquire captures very well.  
  
The Hasbro version is stunning and a great tribute to Sackson, and even though the Sackson company is a small red one, I seem to end up using it quite a lot... 
  
I keep this game around for several reasons: I love tile-laying games of this nature, and this was one of the first; it's a Sackson classic and one of his best games; and the Hasbro production is astonshingly good.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I can definitely see why this game is a classic.  It is loaded with interesting decisions.  I like how they've linked the theme with the mechanisms so well.  Watching small corporations get swallowed up by bigger companies, trying to buy stock in companies that you think will be successful, and working to be a majority stockholder are all very interesting mechanisms that work well together.  It's also intriguing how players will just spend every dollar they have in hopes that they will recoup more at a later time.

Probably my favorite part of the game is simply the short play time.  It feels like this epic economic game where you're really struggling to build these huge companies, and yet it can end sort of abruptly without warning.  I think the downside to the game is the amount of counting that can go on.  If players are trying to track how much others own of a particular stock they can freeze up in analysis-paralysis as they try to figure things out before playing.  But it's still a very intriguing game that I'm glad I own and will look forward to playing again soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Finally managed to track down a copy of the 1999 edition. Love this game even more

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For the age of this game the concept is beautiful. However, the random factor in tile selection (and the fact that a player could spend the entire game locked only into those stocks that they bought in the beginning) can be frustrating and evokes a feeling of helplessness. I've read about a "wildcard" tile option in a few places and I'd like to get the family to give that a try. The original yellow board with locking tiles was great! However, all of the new version are poorly produced in one fashion or another. Avoid the cardboard tile version completely. If you buy the raised/locking plastic tile version, then great for you. However, you may notice that you need to take a sharpie to the back of half or more of the tiles to avoid being able to see the letters through the backs of the tiles as you're selecting them. A great game, great concept, and good for learning how to think critically about managing your in-game stocks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A genuine classic, one of my fav. money/investing games of all time

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A favorite since childhood.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
1.	Intro: This is my favorite auction game.
2.	Weight: Medium
3.	Audience: I think that this game appeals to gamers as well as beginners.
4.	Players: 6 player is the sweet spot for me
5.	Solitaire:
6.	Bits: The newest version has cheap components but it has all you need to give you a great gaming experience.  I like this game so much I found a 3M version of the game.
7.	Rules:  The rules are concise, clear and short.  If you are a moderator for the game its easy to explain in about 15 minutes.
8.	Setup:  10 minutes
10.	Game-flow: The game flow is smooth.
11.     Randomness: The only randomness in the game is tile choice.  It adds the right balance of excitement and constantly forces you to re-evaluate your strategy.  It also makes each game you play different and unscripted.
12.     Interaction:  There is good player interaction throughout the game
13.	Downtime: There is hardly any downtime and whatever downtime there is you have to use to re-evaluate your strategy because the board is constantly changing.
14.	Fun:  This game is very engaging and fun.  It requires concentration and its hard to determine who is winning until the very end.
15.	Theme:  I find that the theme is well integrated in this game.  I feel like an investor and like handling the money and the stocks.
16.	Recommendation:  This game is a solid performer in any collection.  I recommend that you try the game a few times with your gaming group and if you like it I suggest that you try and get the 3m version or if you have a tight budget then get the latest one that was produced.  This game is probably going to be liked more by men than women as the theme is very much buisness.

Versions owned:
1962-1976 Acquire by 3M
1999 - Avalon Hill large box version
2008 - Avalon Hill square box version

Player Aid: http://files.boardgamegeek.com/geekfile_view.php?fileid=34469
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
3 Tiles are missing (8C, 7A, 11F) & rules are missing
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The classic hotel chain stocks and shares game. The tile draw does leave you with some element of luck involved, but if you can't make a play with a tile, you can still dabble in the stock market and invest your cash in ways that can benefit you more than just laying down a random tile.

The winner of the game I played was the person who benefitted most from the first merger, there's ways to deal with that, but not that you'd get from a bunch of guys playing it for the first time! I played this a second time with most of the same players and almost the same thing happened. The person profiting most from the first merger finished second this time, countered only by a player who benefitted from the next two mergers.

Of course, the tile draws mean that the person(s) benefitting most from the early mergers are those who are lucky, or who guessed right.

This game is built to last and is evidently really well thought of here, it's just not really for me. I think there are better economic type games, so this is just an abstract really.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Old game, but still a lot of fun. This is an example of an older game that is not outdated by new mechanics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Acquire is a classic game of stock management in which players strive to invest their starting wealth in a way that maintains their liquidity.  The "trick" to the game that is not always immediately apparent is that pretty much all investments will result in more money for the player, but certain investments will turn over faster - and it is these that are worth the most, rather than those that give the best ROI.  

Acquire is a game that must be played by anyone who calls themselves a gamer, and I recommend playing twice with the same group to really experience the game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I've played this one for years and it never loses my interest.

Easy rules to learn, but so hard to master. Becomes a real cutthroat with only 3 players.
Want to play again
--- Update ---
Played with 4 players, and its such a tight game. A real nailbiter. Specially in the end when you have a hard time placing pieces without doing mergers before you actually wants to.
We play with hidden share-cards. Make it a real pain a couple of rounds into the game trying to remember who has what.
Such nice and simple mechanics.

RATING: 9
I would actually consider this my gateway game. A friend and his wife introduced it to my wife and I during college, and I thought it was brilliant. It is a great game for teaching the concept of owning stock in something without actually owning or controlling the entity itself. There is good depth of strategy although seating position takes a fairly large role in the game, especially when competing for majority with one of the players to your left or right.

Just finished trading for the 1999 AH large box version and I couldn't be happier!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
3-6 | (4) | 90 min | 12+ | Sid Sackson
I was looking forward to trying this classic investing game and must admit I really enjoyed the experience (despite it being a six-player game, a number which supposedly makes the game very chaotic). It should not have come as a surprise given that the game has been in print for over half a century. The rules are so simple that it can possibly work as a gateway game, but at the same time, there is room for clever plays and some strategy. I would definitely love to get more plays to determine how decisive tile distribution really is, but I feel that that very randomness adds much of the underlying tension of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My 3m version of this game may be bland, but because of that I'm always impressed at the way that the theme pours out of the gameplay. I find it very slick that you are always asked to focus on your next turn, de-emphasizing the current turn, reducing any possibility of AP. Its pace is excellent but its still not exactly a rip-roaring time. Still, I love the moment of being acquired and selling off at just the right time. An example of a classic that is still great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A very good game that was ahead of its time 45 years ago! Shades of area control (through holding stocks) and hints of Tigris & Euphrates (bigger companies/kingdoms wiping out smaller ones). A real 'modern' classic.

Avalon Hill's latest edition is quite nice with the 7 different coloured buildings to represent the corporations. Very nice. Reprint it already!

Update May 2013 from Feb 2009: this was just okay after revisiting it. Downgraded from 7.5 to 6.5. Seems a bit luck dependent. If you draw tiles that can start companies and/or merge companies then you are going to do well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
6/29/10 - Bumping the rating from 7 to 8. After several plays, I've really come to appreciate the subtleties of this game. While there is luck involved with drawing tiles, there is surprisingly little luck involved with the game overall. It's all a matter of carefully managing your purchases. A word of warning to new players: This is definitely a game where you can take yourself out of the runnign VERY quickly. If you mis-manage your purchases (for example, by heavily investing in a remote hotel chain early in the game), you will become a spectator for the second half of the game without any chance of winning -- so be careful.

RATING: 9
Great game, although you have to get past the counter-intuitive nature of the economics (thematically, the tech-stock fantasy-world 90's version may get more traction than the hotel version). Understand that the game is bascially abstract, and it's a great game.
---
EDITION NOTES, for what it's worth: generally, I think the three most common versions of Acquire are actually the nicest: the classic 3M/Avalon Hill version, with the plastic grid and tiles and iconic stocks; the overproduced 1999 "new" Avalon Hill version; and the 2008 Wizards of the Coast/AH version. These three versions are all usable, clean, graphically effective, and pleasant to play with. The old AH edition has a classic feel, while the 1999 version is overproduced but does not sacrifice function to form, and is still a playable and pleasing set. The new 2008 WotC/AH version is a good, compact, cheaper set which has usable and attractive components.

Many other sets have issues of various kinds: the Schmidt Spiele is garish and has low-quality cards instead of tiles; and the 1995 AH version comes in a freaking immense box without a commensurate increase in quality of components; 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
1995 version for trade. AH.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The two interlocking levels of strategy (moves on the board, and purchases of stock) make this game a fantastic challenge.  The random tile draw, meanwhile, adds just enough luck to a) make the game different every time and b) give you that "c'mon, c'mon!" feeling, hoping to get a tile that will let you close that merger you so desperately need.

RATING: 8
Lots of fun.  Lots of tension. Can you hold out just one more turn before merging those corporations?  Or will someone beat you to it?  Oh, those darn decisions!  Add just enough randomness to not overwhelm the game with chaos and you've got yourself a game that appeals to the non-gamers and gamers alike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Despite the game's very simple mechanics and good dose of luck, I really enjoy this one.  Really, all you do is place a tile and buy some stock on your turn, but the development of the game board and the hope that mergers will go your way really has some sort of fun quality to it for me.

I personally enjoy playing with hidden stock, which adds to the suspense when a merger happens.  I generally have a decent idea of where I stand when stock is revealed, but my memory isn't the best so it's always fun to see whether things pan out the way I thought they would.

Overall, just a fun, light stock/economic game that's surely a classic in the gaming world.

RATING: 8
People who like thematically rich games will find this game a bit dry. I spent my childhood playing Monopoly (because nothing else was available), which was ridden with crazy dice rolls and no real strategy, and as another "money game" Acquire definitely comes in as fine replacement. Tile luck does play initial role, but its up to you to decide when to buy and when/how much to sell. Bluffing and negotiation goes a long way. Overall its a simple game that I enjoy ocasinaly.

RATING: 6
Well, this game seems to be pretty popular in the States. Here in Germany I don't think it became anywhere that popular. Anyway, I only played it for the first time a couple of months ago and I have to say I was slightly disappointed. I had expected more. Among today's games it does not stand out. Just one of the many solid ones.

 Pity it's so abstract and with a theme pasted on. Such games rarely do much for me. And componentwise I must prefer wooden bits than plastic. Not a biggie of course. I just prefer wood to plastic and fortunately most German games have gone that way, while American games tend to be either with lots of plastic or cardboard (there I much prefer the cardboard stuff - that's where the good American stuff is to be found). Okay, enogh rambling about components...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great economic game. I know some people find this dull and antiquated, but I think this is a tight, smooth system. 

The rules are simple enough to be a good step up from Monopoly for non-gamers, but there's enough meat here to keep hardcore gamers coming back. It manages to move at a good pace and let you make meaningful (and sometimes tense) decisions every turn.

There's a good amount of luck here, but with proper risk management and playing the odds a skilled player will mitigate much of it - the end result is a game with just enough luck to keep things fresh without being the deciding factor.

Small side note: I definitely prefer playing with closed stocks!

RATING: 7
The perceived 1st merger advantage is really minor with experienced players. There just has to be a lot of implicit collusion with the tile play against early majority holders. Also, reflexively buying 3 shares every turn no matter what, especially in the beginning, is just poor play. 

Best with 4 IMO, as often players need to pair up on opposite sides of the board to balance the early mergers. It does take 4 or 5 plays for the game to really shine.

RATING: 5.5
Meh. While I can see that it was a great game a few decades ago, I think the age really starts to show, and I personally don’t understand why it’s rated just outside the top 100. There is a lot of speculation about what the other players are going to do, which companies they will buy stocks in, when and which company will overtake another company, especially at the beginning of the game where it’s crucial to get a payout from your company – it seemed as if a big money boost at the start of the game really helps a lot going forward, so while it’s not impossible to catch up, it’s much easier to do well if you get a good start.

It’s pretty important to get good tiles. In my second game I won, but I did draw some awesome tiles which could connect some companies and I had control over what happened as well as financial control as I had the most money and shares in good companies. It’s very important to buy shares in the right companies! The final round can have a big impact on the winner as the bonus for most shares in the most expensive company is very high, at least if the game ends in the way with a company being 41+ tiles big, which is the most common (oh, and speaking of this, it’s pretty cool that you have to state that the company is 41+ tiles big or the game won’t end). Of course everybody knows this, but it still felt like a lot.

I think Acquire plays best with 4 as the stocks are in the companies are divided among those, and 5 takes too long plus you don’t have enough control about what is happening. I think 3 would definitely be too few, but I cannot say until I try it. Despite the player counts, I don’t think I have too much control over what’s happening if I don’t get great tiles and because I don’t know the tiles of the other players. Maybe I don’t know the shares either, as that depends on which rules you play by, but I think both open and hidden stocks have their pros and cons. The game has also ended in both ways, and it was interesting to see how differently the two games played out. However, I doubt I’m going to play it a lot in the future.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2 or 3 tiles missing
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A classic but rather dry. I like the idea but I'm not sure how to do well at this game. I felt I had next to no control from the point at which the first two companies merged and very little  money to buy shares in order to reverse my fortunes whilst the rich got steadily richer.

After 3 plays: Forget trying to make money by manipulating share prices. This game is about rapid turnover of shares from mergers NOT long term investment. Money comes from owning the majority of shares in the smaller companies being merged. Still dry and luck dependent.

RATING: 8
I have been looking for this game for about a year.  I remember it being in my house when I was a young kid, but it belonged to my older brother (8 years older).  Turns out he took his copy with him when he moved to Detroit, then sold it in a garage sale for cheap.  A friend knew that I wanted it desperately, and after about 2 months of constantly looking for it in various thrift stores and garage sales, found a 1968 3M Bookshelf version for me on 10/04/07.  Needless to say, I am very elated.

Haven't played it yet, but from what everyone says, this is a great game.

Edit on 11/19/07:  Finally got to play this game - twice - yesterday, and I would like to report that everything good that you may have heard about this game is very true.  There can be some tension as you wait and see if someone else will merge with the hotel chain of which you own the most shares of stock, and there is a deep level of strategy in determining when to play each of your tiles.  Overall, an excellent game.

I recommend getting this game in any manner possible.

RATING: 7.5
Acquire may be a few decades old, but there's a reason it is still in print.  It is easy to learn, fun to play, and it has elements of tension that will keep it popular for years to come.  It is a bit dry for my taste, but others around me seem to really enjoy it.

There is an element of card counting that is necessary for good gameplay: one must know how many of each stock each of their opponents has.  But it isn't overly burdensome, and most players seem to enjoy doing it.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you play according to the official rules, a player that wins the first two mergers will run away with the game.  However, the rules can be fixed making the game "perfect".  First, change the rules to never allow anyone to keep stock in a company that does not exist.  This prevents someone from leveraging their advantage to keep his/her opponents down.  Second, begin the game with approximately 12 tiles on the board, not one per player, as stated in the rules.  This greatly increases the speed at which mergers occur which also prevents someone from leveraging their early advantage to suspress his/her opponents. Third, give each player 5 tiles instead of 7.  This greatly reduces a players ability to "sit" on tiles that help their opponents - which is another way that a leader can leverage his/her advantage.  The overall result of these 3 rule changes is that the game's action is quicker and less predictable, the game will change leaders more frequently, the influence of luck is greatly reduced, and the game is much more fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Before playing the abstract look of the board was a little off-putting to me, so I was really surprised at how much I like this economic classic.

Even though there is a lot of luck to this game (and in general, I do not like luck so much in games), I still find this mentally challenging enough to keep me interested.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
We have one of the plastic 3M versions.  It isn't much to look at, but is interesting to play.  On the tiles in our version, the letter I looks an awful lot like the number 1.  We play with 2, which uses a dummy player whose influence can be pretty frustrating.  Money is paid out for 1st and 2nd place, based on shares of stock.  The amount held by the dummy is drawn randomly, generally preventing one player from getting any money, and often reducing the leading player's bonus to 2nd place.  You have to balance your investments in small hotel chains, which give you short-term money during the game, and big powerful chains which really pay off at the end.

RATING: 6
This game is fun if your into a stock purchasing game. It's hard to long term plan as two factors work against you. The other players is the first. Naturally that is what happens in games. Other players foul up your plays. However here, especially in larger games as with 4 players, the other players actions seem to impact yours. Secondly, the tiles have a huge impact on your actions. In some cases several turns can go by with little happening due to a bad hand of tiles.

Overall, this can be a fun game, and fairly easy to learn.

RATING: 7
It seems like once you know how to play Acquire, you pretty much use the same strategy every game and hope you get good tiles.  It's an interesting mix of a "playing the odds" mechanic and an area majority mechanic, but a huge part of the game still rests on luck.  Just like the stock market, I guess.  Although this game is less about playing the stock market and more about investing in companies that are going to be acquired.  Thus the name...  Seems very thematic and very abstract at the same time.
Having said all that, the game is always tense and a lot of fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(Own hand-made Acquire 97 using Big Boss components, stored in the Terra Turrium box with Big Boss. Note rating comments below, the 8 reflects this version of the game. Standard Acquire rates a 6.)

The age of this game astounds me; for a game originally published in the 60s it has some remarkable nuances and plenty of room for skillful play. The idea behind the game is very mathy, and a little dry like most of Sackson's games, but it also is exceptional given its era. Players try to make money by placing tiles onto the board, forming corporations, causing mergers, and flipping stocks. The art of this game is timing when to invest heavily in a company, preferably before it's consumed by another (that has a few stocks left) so you can get both the majority/minority bonus, as well as a prime opportunity to cash in your stocks for even more valuable ones.

The game varies a lot based on the rules being used (open vs. closed stocks and money (I prefer open stocks and closed money. Open money is OK, closed stocks are not)) and whether you're playing the standard editions vs. the 1997 edition. The 97 edition is extremely rare (it was basically a finished game that was axed. Pre-production copies were made by Schmidt Spiele that look like professional releases for all intents and purposes, but the actual release was killed. There are only a handful of these and they sell for a mint), and fundamentally altered the board play by making 4 copies of each space, thereby giving the players more choices and control. I rate the standard Acquire at a rough 6, and find the amount of randomness that the tiles inject into the game irksome. The 97 system creates a lot of decision space that is in control of the players, which means that group think can easily lead to clusters in given areas of the board and crazy build-ups, but I like that dynamic significantly more than the "pray my tiles can be used for [i]something[/i] one from the original system.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Acquire is a classic economic game that is simple to learn and yet has plenty of strategy. Basically, you build hotels by laying square tiles next to each other, you buy stock, and then you try to collapse the hotels into bigger ones and make money. It's a good game that never gets played the same way twice. The problem is that there's too much luck involved with the tile draw and placement. And if you're broke, you twiddle your thumbs playing tiles and waiting for everyone else to control the game. Some might consider boredom to be a good punishment for players who are broke. Others do not. I fall in the latter category, which is why I only like, but do not love, Acquire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This was one of the first games I was introduced to outside of the Monopoly and Candyland world of games. I guess it was kind of love at first sight. In most games (especially the very competitive ones) I really don't know who will end up with the most money at the end of the game. Also all of the wild money counting at the end is so stinking satisfying!!

I find the game mechanics to be unique enough that no other game quite quenches the Acquire Urge whenever it comes up for me.  The one major downside is the potential for a player to get shut out of the action mid-game if they are not aligned in any mergers and/or they too quickly spend their money. For the most part, this can be corrected with more game experience and possibly some guidance for newer players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Acquire turned out to be better than I expected given the game's age: more often than not oldies are pretty crappy. I liked the mechanics of increasing the value of your hotels by adding to their 'footprint', and then getting a truckload of money (or new shares) when the thing merges with a bigger hotel. Clean and simple. However, it does have some problems: the hotels are grown by what is essentially luck of the draw, and therefore mergers need not always occur when and where you want them to happen. People lucky enough to get an early lead will have more cash to spend and are thus somewhat more likely to get hold of the stock they need. While this is a rich-get-richer problem, its effect is not very pronounced: at some point it is not feasible anymore to buy stock to play catchup, so your buying power is reduced. (Of course this assumes that no interesting stock remains.) Inexperienced players will be blown away by the more experienced ones: those know that you need to create lots of small hotels to feed them to the God Hotel. And of course have plenty of stock in all of them, which is not an easy task if everyone is playing with their eyes open! 

With 6 players the luck of the draw is significantly increased but with too few players stock contention can cause significant turn angst, so I expect that there is a sweet spot in the middle at 4, perhaps 5 players. Nevertheless, Acquire was a pleasant surprise, and served as a major eye-opener as far as its heritage is concerned. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.25

Suggestion:  I've played a couple games with the normal scoring cards and can highly recommend that people download and use the modified 100-75-50-25 payout sheets available on the Geek.  The two games I played without them suffered from a run-away leader issue after the first merger.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Actually I am referencing the 1976 Avalon Hill version which I own - which is very similar to the 3M 1962 version. Acquire is a really good strategy game best played with 4 or 5 players.  This is mostly a game of skill while managing the "chance" factor of tile draws.  Acquire has simple rules, is a clean game, and plays fast with little downtime.  This is also a game where the most "skilled" players tend to almost always end up in 1st, 2nd or 3rd place most every game.  My analogy is likened to Texas Hold'em poker play - sure there is randomness in each players hand draws each turn (like tile draws in Acquire), but the best players manage the "odds" for tiles, stock share acquisition, hotel mergers and most often come out on top or near the top in most games.  Where this game lacks is evident in the replayability department.  After 20 or so plays, the game tends to get shelved and only played once every year or two.  Also, players who have great memories for tracking who picked up what stocks and are good at number crunching seem to excel at Acquire, which can alienate some potential players.  Lastly, once in a while some players feel that they simply can not pull a tile chit to save their life and they then associate this to simply bad luck. With no dice, this is the only real downside to Acquire in my opinion.  All in all, I think Acquire is a superb, fun game and worthy being in any serious gamer's collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Utilizes hand management of tiles that you place strategically on the board on matching coordinates in order to grow hotel chains and merge with other chains.  You buy stock in hotel chains in the hopes that they will grow, get bought out so that they give you fat bonuses in the mid-game, and ultimately your goal is to position yourself at the end with the most stock in the biggest companies at the end game.  I am relatively new to the game, but it is amazingly good. 

Your choices are: when to form a chain(and then whether it is a cheap, mid-price, or expensive chain), hand management (which tiles to place and when), what shares to buy and when, and what to do with shares of companies that are bought out in a merger (trade shares 2:1 to new owner company shares, sell for value at time of merger, or hold on in hopes of starting chain again later).

Play time: 1-2 hours.  

Would love to find the version with the plastic buildings without paying an arm and a leg. Or maybe they will finally print a modern version with decent components??? MAKE ACQUIRE GREAT AGAIN
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Components: The Avalon Hill version is well-made, with sturdy, snappy stocks cards, and plastic pieces that perfectly serve their function, yet are attractive as well. I dock the game a production point because of the Monopoly-grade money and because of the poor storage inside the box (no tile racks, no draw bag, and a plastic insert that is only useful when the game is set up). I've seen some comments that disparage this version of the game; I just can't agree; I love the chunky tiles and the brightly colored buildings.

Experience: This game is a real thrill, with a healthy amount of tension coming from the conflicting desire both to increase the size of a corporation, but also buy more stock in it while it is small; also from the desire to invest in the big, safe corporation, planning for the big payoff in the end, but also needing to buy stock in short-term, merge-ready sources of income.

First Played: 2001-01-01
Last Played: 2012-11-10
Eagerness to Play Again: Within a year

Plays (10):
? players: 5
4 players: 2
5 players: 2
6 players: 1

RATING: 6
Acquire can be very good fun, the trouble is that it can also be terribly boring.  About one in 4 games is really good fun.  The problem arises from the fact that your hand of tiles is so crucial, yet so random.  One can easily be left in the situation of controlling no decent tiles and so having to make guesses about which hotels are going to merge.  This is fine is one has sufficient cash to invest widely, but can make for a dull experience as you wait for someone else to do something to help you out.

RATING: 10
It amazes me how such a simple, elegant, almost self-explanatory game can be so deep and engrossing.  Compare this to, say, Rheinlander (to which it is almost identical):  I can teach Acquire in five minutes, whereas Rheinlander can take fifteen minutes or more.  And Acquire just feels more satisfying.  This game ranks third overall in my book after Diplomacy and Scrabble.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Asymmetric incentive structures

Hopefully these are starting to seem intertwined by now. This obviously relates to many things I've already discussed. 

In particular, when a game randomizes opportunities / incentives, I would like it to do so differently for different players.

A game with a random setup at the game-level [Settlers] is less interesting than a game with a random setup at the player-level [Race for the Galaxy]. 

A game that presents all players with the same opportunities [Dominion] is less interesting than one that presents them with different ones [Acquire].

I want to feel I am doing something different not just because a winning strategy is "do what no one else is doing".

I want to do something different because I have different sub-goals within the overall goal of winning the game.

http://boardgamegeek.com/blogpost/219/nates-top-10-games-things

RATING: 4
Too much luck factor by cap drawing.
Economic facts misrepresented in the mechanics: Stock value goes up when copanies grow instead of stock price raise when stocks run short.
Exchange factor of stocks for bigger company should not be fixed to 2:1 but depending on relative size of respective companies.
For sure, will not play this again.
Acquire is prommising a economic tough game but is in fact only lightwight game where your fate is driven by tiledrawing.

RATING: 8
One of my favorite stock/financial games, this has a little bit of a luck factor, but it takes enough planning and cunning to get ahead.  I had played a previous version with cardboard tiles and hotel corporations, but the copy I just bought is the new AH version with plastic tiles and plastic 3D skyscraper pieces for the different corporations.  Also, I don't think the previous version I played had rules for a 2 player game, and this one does.  It actually worked pretty well, so I was pleasantly surprised.  I really enjoy that change and the plastic pieces, so I am glad they released it again.  Good game, highly recommend this one.

RATING: 8
A brutal Euro (but not from Europe--yay, buy American!) that will do nothing to prevent you from absolutely losing this game.  There is no friendly "reward people who aren't doing as well" catch up mechanic.  

Nope, just like in real business, if someone is beating you, they're going to keep beating you into the ground until you figure out how to catch up.

Which will usually not be until the next game--it's nasty.

I love it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
3-6

Voorbereiding :

1/ Plaats de tegels gedekt naast het spelbord.
2/ De bank geeft iedere speler 6000$ (4x1000$, 3x500$ en 5x100$), een samenvattingskaart en iedere speler neemt 6 tegels. 
3/ Bepaal de startspeler: iedere speler trekt 1 tegel en legt deze op de desbetreffende plaats op het speelbord. De speler met de tegel dichtst bij 1A (kolom per kolom) mag beginnen.

Zie overzichtskaart in spelregels:

Eerste 3 kolommen: bedrijven + aantal tegels (gebruiken om aandelen te kopen en te verkopen)

Vierde kolom: prijs per aandeel volgens het aantal tegels van het bedrijf (gebruiken om aandelen te kopen en te verkopen)

Vijfde en zesde kolom: bonussen (meerderheids- en minderheidsaandeelbonussen worden uitbetaald bij een fusie)

Speelverloop:
 
De spelers spelen volgens beurtvolgorde, beginnend bij de startspeler. In iedere beurt moet de speler volgende 3 acties in volgorde uitvoeren: 

1/ Speel een tegel (Verplicht) 

Neem één van jouw tegels en leg deze op de desbetreffende plaats op het speelbord. Er kunnen zich 3 situaties voordoen: 

1a/ De speler legt de tegel als een ongebonden tegel.

Als een speler een tegel naast een ongebonden tegel op het speelbord plaatst, dan wordt er een bedrijf gesticht. De speler kiest een bedrijf, plaatst het op één van de tegels en krijgt één bedrijfsaandeel. Een tegel die een achtste bedrijf zou stichten, mag niet gespeeld worden!

1b/ Als een speler een tegel zo plaatst, dat hij twee of meer bedrijven verbindt, dan vindt een fusie plaats. Het grootste bedrijf (met de meeste tegels) neemt het kleinste bedrijf over. Bij gelijkstand bepaalt de fusieleider welk bedrijf overleeft. Het gebouw van het overgenomen bedrijf komt terug in de voorraad en de aandelen worden bekend gemaakt. 

Zodra een fusie plaats vindt, moeten alle spelers het aantal aandelen van het overgenomen bedrijf, bekend maken. 

De speler met de meeste aandelen = meerderheidsaandeelhouder, 
De speler met de op-één-na meeste aandelen = minderheidsaandeelhouder. 

De bonussen voor deze aandeelhouders worden uitgedeeld.

+ Als slechts één speler aandelen bezit, dan krijgt hij beide bonussen. 
+ Als er een gelijke stand is voor de meerderheidsaandeelhouder, tel dan de meerderheids- en minderheids bonussen bij elkaar op en verdeel ze gelijk, eventueel naar boven afgerond naar het dichtstbijzijnde betaalbare bedrag. (De minderheids aandeelhouder krijgt geen bonus.) 
+ Als er een gelijke stand is voor de minderheids aandeelhouder, verdeel dan de minderheids bonus onder deze spelers. Rond indien nodig de resulterende bonussen naar boven af naar het dichtstbijzijnde honderdtal. Zie informatiekaart voor de bonussen. 

Nadat de bonussen zijn uitbetaald, moet elke aandeelhouder beslissen wat hij/zij zal doen met zijn/haar aandelen: 

a) Houden: De speler mag zijn aandelen houden (later kan hetzelfde bedrijf nog eens worden gesticht) 
b) Verkopen: Aandelen worden verkocht tegen een prijs die bepaald wordt door het aantal tegels van het overgenomen bedrijf (Zie informatiekaart) 
c) Inruilen: De speler kan voor elke 2 aandelen van het overgenomen bedrijf, één aandeel in het overlevende bedrijf aanschaffen.

De speler mag bovengenoemde mogelijkheden door elkaar gebruiken.
 
2/ Koop aandelen (Optioneel) 

Een speler mag maximaal 3 aandelen per beurt kopen. Dit kunnen aandelen van één bedrijf of van verschillende bedrijven zijn. De prijs per aandeel vindt je terug op je informatiekaart. 

3/ Trek een nieuwe tegel (Verplicht) 

De speler trekt een tegel uit de voorraad. Tijdens deze actie mag hij ook onspeelbare tegels wegleggen en deze vervangen door nieuwe tegels. Dit kan maar eenmaal per beurt gedaan worden.

Einde van het spel :

Het spel eindigt wanneer een speler tijdens zijn beurt aangeeft dat alle bedrijven veilig zijn of date en bedrijf 41 of meer tegels op het bord heeft. De speler die aan het einde van het spel het meeste geld bezit, wint.

Belangrijke regels:

+ Als bij de bepaling van de startspeler 2 tegels aangrenzend zijn, dan worden ze beschouwd als ongebonden tegels. Als er later een tegel wordt toegevoegd worden ze een bedrijf. 
+ Een speler zonder geld, kan geen aandelen meer verkopen. Hij moet wachten tot er een fusie gebeurt met een bedrijf waarin hij aandelen heeft. 
+ Bedrijf = Twee of meer verbonden tegels met daarop een bedrijfsgebouw. 
+ Onverbonden tegel = één of meer tegels die nog niet verbonden zijn.
+ Veilig bedrijf = een bedrijf dat 11 of meer tegels op het speelbord heeft liggen.
+ Een veilig bedrijf kan nooit met een ander bedrijf fusioneren.
+ Op het einde van het spel worden alle actieve bedrijven van groot naar klein afgehandeld. Meerderheidsaandeelbonussen en minderheidsaandeelbonussen worden uitbetaald en alle aandelen worden verkocht tegen de huidige prijs (Zie informatiekaart). Aandelen in een bedrijf dat niet op het speelbord staat, zijn waardeloos. 

Aanpassingen voor 2 spelers: zie spelregels

RATING: 3
Nearly broken.  A longish game that is decided early.  Either by luck or by skill, the recipient of primary payout from first merger will likely win.  If you don't make money on that first merger, or VERY soon afterwards, you are doomed.  The person who owns the most stock early in the largest chain, cannot sell and is essentially out of the game.  I'm good at this game, played many times, and I always pity the damned.

RATING: 8.5
This is a great game if people keep their stocks hidden and play pretty fast.  I usually do not like abstract games but this one just gets by.  Very solid game.

Pros:  Tons of difficult decisions in regards to keeping stock or trading 2:1 and especially in trying to determine if someone else might trade all of their stock 2:1 in something in which you are the leader.

Cons:  It is possible for new players to get into a cash crunch (even when you tell them that the first half of the game is all about getting cash for being a majority holder in the smaller hotel chain) which makes the game frustrating for them.

RATING: 3
A game that didn't have much of a chance with me, simply because it's a bit too dry and abstract.  Some of the ideas were intriguing, but I am not engaged by this spatial money puzzle.

I particularly disliked one random element of the game. On any given player's turn, their best option will probably hurt another player.  But there is no connection between who is being hurt and their position.  If the player in last place is standing on the path that best suits me, then I'll crush that player.  This means that getting hit by another player doesn't feel as if they're playing against you specifically.  This creates a feeling of being hosed at random, which I did not care for.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simple rules, plenty of depth, and appropriate theme.  Random tile draw makes it infinitely replayable.  Unlike other tile drawers that I don't care for (Carcasonne), in Acquire you always have 6 tiles to choose from to play.  This increases your options and adds depth/skill.

If Parker Brothers or Milton Bradley had bought the rights to this game in the 60s, every family would own a copy.  I brought it out yesterday, and one of the other players (who doesn't buy games that often) already has his copy on order.  It's that addictive. Update: Had to drop it down to an 8 (from a 9) because every game I play involves at least one player running out of money and getting shut out of the mergers.  It's never happened to me, but this is a definite flaw that occurs regularly.

Have to drop this a point.  There's just too many games where somone gets locked out of mergers or there aren't but a couple of mergers before the game ends.

RATING: 8
Everyone seems to like this game, so it gets to the table frequently (or at least it used to, before I got sucked into the cult of the new). It's a relatively simple but elegant game. Having to place a tile before buying stock creates a fun tension when deciding whether or not to expand a hotel. It's definitely a cash flow game (which I like), but the game is unforgiving if you run out of money to buy stocks. The game can definitely leave players out in the cold, but when it's working right, it's a tense and highly entertaining experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow... I can't believe what I have been missing all these years! Don't make the mistake of passing this game by in favor of a newer title. It outshines the current crop of popular euro games by a longshot! It seems like a granddaddy to both "tile placement" and to "score majority" games. Sometimes seminal games can be less fun than their kin, but not in this case! It plays in about 45 minutes and is lean and elegant.

RATING: 9
I initially found this game through [gameid=483] (Avalon Hill (Hasbro) ad with game).  I realized my dad had had an old 3M version that I had never played.

I bought it, and I was very pleastantly surprised.  I think this game has a "Euro" feel to it, and as such it might even predate [gameid=13] as a "Eurogame."  It probably had influences on "Eurogame" deigners, so you will probably find elements in this game from others you have played.

This is a great game.  I will play this game pretty much anytime.

RATING: 6
Far, far ahead of its time.   I liked the stock aspect of it, and the uncertainty which companies would disappear and reappear.   However, the gameplay is a bit more dry than I expected, and a bit more repetative also.   There's some *pizzazz* missing here.   It's also a math-heavy game with a lot of chart look-up involved.   If I'm going to do that much chart look-up, I think I'd rather play BattleTech and blow something up.   I appreciate it for what it is, and I like how it shows its influence in other similar games like Union Pacific or even Uptown.

RATING: 8
Very good game, especially for a game that came out in 1962. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A relatively quick stock holding game with a scrabble-ish board where empires grow on the board and eventually get taken over or take over smaller companies.

I like having to balance buying stocks with your cash reserves and trying to manipulate the board to get pay outs in your benefit. 

However, the random tile draw bothers me. I've had too many instances where i want to merge a company, or grow a company...but all i can do is add to a company where i dont own any stocks and it only benefits my opponents...but thats the only move i have. I also don't like that once you fall behind in stocks, its almost pointless to try and keep up. 

Because the more experienced players have won each game, I'm sure my complaints are more of a me problem than a game problem, but i still find the luck of the draw frustrating.

I don't mind playing the game. But as far as stock games or light economic games go, I'd rather play Chicago Express, Tulip Bubble, or Modern Art.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Even though Acquire seems dated now, when I was a kid, this game was the most cut throat, devious, backstabbing, kill-your-neighbor game in our closet.  This game made RISK look darn right civil.  Basically, Acquire is like Monopoly, but with a bit more gusto.  You build hotel chains and invest in stocks, hoping that you can keep your chain bigger than your competitors, AND, keep yourself filled up with a diverse stock portfolio just in case they take you over in a merger.  This game has a prefect mix of strategy and randomness to make each game unique and challenging for all players.  I recently got my hands on the 1999 big box edition, which is definitely the coolest edition to have.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I freaking love this game! We've played this twice now in my game group and I find myself thinking about it all the time.  Things that stand out:

The merger mechanic is incredible.  Both games I made myself 'queen of the budget chains' and hoped by positioning that I would be bought out by a larger, more expensive hotel.  There's nothing like having a handful of super cheap stocks and upgrading them into a pile of stocks that no one can afford to buy.  Also, I enjoy that a stock is never wasted.  Even if the chain is gone, you can hold onto it and refound it at a later date.  THAT'S BRILLIANT!!

To me, it's difficult to figure out who is 'winning' at any given point.  My husband has played the game once and spent the first two thirds thinking he was hopelessly out of it, and the game ended with him being in last, less than 3k behind the winner.  The game can swing so quickly.

Acquire is competitive and yet not vicious.  I think what makes it work so well for me is there is no player trading.  I can sometimes feel pressured into making a trade that does me no good in a game just because I want to be 'nice'.

To end, this is a fairly easily taught great game that should be part of every gamers' collection.  As many a person has pointed out, there's a reason this game is 50+ years old and in the BGG top 100.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This has remained a classic - compared to some newer games this might now seem a little basic and dated, but strangely it's simplicity is part of it's appeal. There have been many discussions about the luck factor of the draw, but in my opinion this element creates good tension that gives the game a quasi relaxed character that makes it more of a family game than let's say "1830" (which has some similarities with "Acquire"). As this is one of the most influential games of all times it should be an essential part of any collection.

I gush.......rightfully so!!!

Only played twice.  Downgraded rating to a 9.

RATING: 5
Easy to learn; difficult to master; mathematically interesting; high production quality and graphical design. You'd think it would be a big hit, but something about it just isn't super fun.  Maybe it's the somewhat indirect player interaction, or the fact that you don't really have a position on the board or a character you can identify with (just a pile of stock and money).  I appreciate this one and will often share it with guests because of the easy learning curve, but I'm never eager to play it.  No one ever laughs and has a great time, nor do they have their thinking caps on.

RATING: 6.5

It was easy to learn, and I think we played it 3 times. This is a fun game, the only negative for me was that at some point in the middle of the game the outcome seemed to be very predictable and nearly impossible to change. However I will admit that it's very possible that I made a mistake with the rules somehow. I would try this again, it's a good game and would be even better with a few adjustments to the rules.

RATING: 7
The hand management, timing, and balancing of short and long-term goals seems great. It's a lot of fun to grab on to another player's strategy and let them do the work for you. But it is possible to get a terrible hand of tiles and have few options to get cash from mergers. In that case it is important to conserve your money to buy just a few shares of each company so you can get 2nd majority bonuses and trade up for more valuable shares.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the original 1964 version of the game. In Acquire, each player strategically invests in businesses, trying to retain a majority of stock. As the businesses grow with tile placements, they also start merging, giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizable bonuses, which can then be used to reinvest into other chains. All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks for current value or trade them 2-for-1 for shares of the newer, larger business. The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This was the first real "board game" that I bought.  I have the 1999 edition whith 3D buildings and plastic board. It’s stategic, elegant and really enjoyable.  Definitly one of my favorites.

RATING: 9.25
I first played this as a kid and loved it ever since.  One of the first games I played where a lot of pure strategy won the day. I like the whole businessman theme of mergers and stocks. Also love the 3d look to the board...I'm glad I have the 99 version with the hotel pieces...was disapointed they did away with them. Would play this anytime though it does require players who know what they are doing/take it seriously.  A bad player can really mess up the game. Fortunately its an easy game to teach and pick up. Top 3 game for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I was really looking forward to playing this, and so I was surprised that I found it to be a mediocre experience in my one six-player game.  It was fun, and I'd be happy to play again, but I felt that the progression of the game was largely out of my control, and that determining which companies to invest in was, to some degree, luck.

In the game, I never had a tile that allowed me to start a company or merge two companies - until I made the final merger of the game.  I was able to finish third, because I was the minority share holder in an early merged company and I resunk all that money into the biggest company.  Clearly, its necessary to be involved in an early merger so you have money to re-invest.  But my fortune seemed somewhat arbitrary.  Perhaps more plays will reveal more control.

I think other games have taken Acquire's mechanics and improved them, but I'll need to play with fewer players before I'm sure.

UPDATE - Now played with five and I did like it better, so I upped the rating a tad.  It's a fun game but not all that satisfying.  I felt a bit more in control with fewer players, but the game was still largely decided on seating order.
