=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic Sackson economics/finance game, ahead of its time!  Outstanding.

Much debate about open/closed stocks/money (see [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/320905/open-or-closed-money-and-stocks]here[/url], [thread=320905]here[/thread], [thread=493567]here[/thread], [thread=636775]here[/thread]). The 1999 rules left it to the players: "[i]Show or hide assets: Players must now decide as a group whether the money and stocks they acquire will be openly displayed. An open display is strongly recommended for new or inexperienced players. If money and stock are not displayed, the game is even more challenging because players must try to remember how much stock each player has purchased.
Note: At any time during the game, a player may ask how many stocks of a company are still unpurchased.[/i]"

The preference of a slim majority of people is to play with open stocks and closed money (see this [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/340460/official-open-or-closed-stocks-poll]poll[/url]).

Hidden stocks: 
+ done in tournaments
+ quicker
- less strategic, go by instinct instead of numbers

Open stocks:
+ is trackable anyway
+ prevents it becoming a memory game
+ is like real world, where stocks are public but money isn't
- slows game down with AP, can run twice as long!

Gift from friends family

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My arc of experience with this classic game was like this: I played it extensively when I was young (I had the 1976 version that I still prefer) and really enjoyed it, then I reacquired it when I got back into the hobby a few years ago and tried to recapture its excitement. I enjoyed it from a nostalgic POV, but alas, it didn't hold up for me in light of modern games due to the randomness. The tile pulls swing things in or out of players' fortunes, and I've seen some players get shut out of the game early on. 

Sure, there can be epically tense plays that come down to the bitter end, but there are more likely going to be sessions with a runaway leader/loser such that it's just too fragile a game considering the other options we now have available to us. 

If you're interested in this game, I would recommend against the newer version with the "all crappy cardboard components" and pick up one of the older ones.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic and very good game. You have a rack of pieces in front of you and try and play them next to it to form hotel chains. Once a chain is formed you (and the other players) can by shares in it - with the bigger the chain the more expensive the shares. If you join two chains, the smaller one gets bought out and the shareholders get paid. 

A recent five-player game (13/09/2012) had one player frozen out for most of the game, yet came second so downgraded rating from 8.5 to 8. Still a very good game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The classic Sid Sackson game of stock acquisitions and mergers.

[u]Overview[/u]
The board is a rectangular grid where coordinates represent hotels. The players are investors who buy stock in seven hotel chains in order to gain the most money by the end of the game. Each player holds a hand of six tiles with coordinates on the grid, one of which they have to play each turn, opening a new hotel there. If the location is adjacent to an existing chain, the hotel becomes part of it; if instead it's adjacent to other open hotels not part of a chain, a new chain is formed. A merger happens when playing a tile causes two chains to connect, with the larger company buying the smaller one; the two players with most stocks in the bought chain get an acquisition bonus and everyone has to choose whether to sell, convert 2 for 1 or keep their stock in the bought chain. Companies with at least 11 hotels are safe from mergers and cannot be taken over.

[u]Strategy and comments[/u]
At the beginning money dries up faster than stock, so players try to arrange the acquisition of the companies where they are majority stockholders to receive extra cash (mostly from bonuses) and to move their stock into a better chain (as long as there is some available). An early merger is very profitable because it allows players to reinvest their liquidity into new or better companies, reaping massive profits while drying up the stock; who buys after them will usually do so at a higher price and, due to the limited nature of the stock, might be unable to buy (or convert) into the best companies. Investing in a company that isn't likely to merge can be a huge mistake, as it ties up money without giving a satisfying return. The random draw of the tiles can have a significant effect, as players holding a tile that causes a merger can take better decisions about which stocks to buy. Looking carefully at what everyone is doing may give you a few hints on what to expect, but it will hardly be better than playing the right tile at the right time. A full six-players game will probably last around two hours.

It's a pretty decent game, but nothing to set the table on fire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This game has the best chance of becoming my second "10".  Granted, it has only been four plays, but I just found it thoroughly enjoyable. It has a lot of strategic depth, yet is not too confrontational.  Not that I mind confrontation, but it doesn't suit everyone in the family. The game is also pretty easy to teach, and covers a good spread of players.
---------------------
Update:
I still don't win often, but I love this game!  You will hear people lament the poor components of the 2008 version.  I don't agree.  The stock cards are far superior, even as the board components are not.  I have played on the 2008 board and a 1968 board, and they bother have their strengths and weaknesses.  If you are fretting over it, don't.  You are losing time when you could be playing this great game!

See my full review at:
http://sofrankly.com/2011/05/more-economic-game-for-your-money.html

RATING: N/A
S11A
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In Acquire hotels are formed, expanded and eventually merged. These hotels have shares that can be bought by any of the players, so in effect most of them will be owned by 2, 3 or more players. 
The hotel's expansions are done by a mechanism of tile placement where players try to control the hotel's growth at their best possible interest (not always possible...).
Might seem strange but with more players the game turns globally less chaotic as it approaches the rules of normal markets. With fewer players, each player has more control over the tile placement process and can turn apparently bad investments into good ones.
There is a luck factor involved (especially if you pick a tile that allows a perfect hotel merge), but a good reading of the market evolution is normally the key for victory.
The few money you start with, is perfect to create the right amount of tension during the investment stages. 
The game offers different ways to victory, either by making sucessive small wins (producing small hotel merges) or by being able to do a few big wins (holding a good number of shares from the biggest hotels).
The rules can be explained in 5 minutes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 8
Surprisingly good. Although having limited ability to place tokens on the board (only five random pieces) seems like it would seriously impair the player interaction (there are occasional opportunites for great moves when the board starts to fill out), the ability to buy whatever stocks you want (between 0 and 3) is primarily where the conflict in this game presents itself. There is a reason that this game has lasting appeal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Considering its age, Acquire is a very good game. Still, when comparing it to current titles, the paint is starting to come off.

You buy shares in hotel chains, then try to make bucketloads of money when merging your chain with another. Which chains can be established and merged is decided by pulling chits which essentially means that which mergers happen when is largely decided by the luck of the draw.

It's also a very dry affair overall and, depending on which edition you get to play, its presentation can be rather drab.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Best with 4, Recommended with 3-6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the greatest games you can play. What a great concept Sid Sackson came up with. The game mechanics are simple and elegant. This is almost (if not in fact) the grandaddy of all "Euro-style" strategy board games. Do yourself a favor and pick this up if you haven't already, and be sure to get a copy with tiles that remain in place on the board, and not the versions that have cheap cardboard ones.

What other game can you form a hotel chain and proclaim: "Who can... AmeriCAN."?

RATING: 5.7
[2014.06.01] - 8.5

A wonderfully tense game of abstract economics by the master Sid Sackson.  I took a >20 year hiatus from this gem and regret it dearly.  The theme is fairly thin, but that doesn't matter at all.

[2015.07.20]

The luck factors too much into this game.  While I still enjoy the occasional play, my tastes have changed such that I'm less enamored by wild swings of luck in a game that purports to be about skill.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Acquire is an early and uber-smart entry from Sid Sackson.  Even with the luck of tile draws, you are managing your tiles in a way that benefits you and not your opponents.  The purchasing, selling, and trading of stocks is a very clean and realistic system.  Acquire (like Bazaar) is a great, heady workout with math.  It shows Sackson's ability to make games that involve money and random tile pulls very interesting and competitive.  Plus, the 1999 AH version is a sight to behold in terms of its design!  Sometimes it runs too long for a game that is essentially a three-step pattern of turns, but overall this is one of the top stock holding games I've ever played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great step above Monopoly when getting into finacial/property games. My family enjoyed playing this game a little too much.

RATING: 5
Acquire is a game with two faces for me.  Either I enjoy my experience and feel I have control over my game, or I just can't wait for the madness to end.  I realise and can see the clever play in this one, but for some reason my sessions with acquire have left me with the aforementioned spectrum splitting feelings.  It is this inconsistency in my experiences that leaves me giving this classic a slighty better than mediocre score.

UPDATE:  Stephenson's Rocket makes this Sid Sackson classic obsolete.  With a similar core, Stephenson's is able to strip away the luck that plagues Acquire, as well as make it a more simple and elegant design.  

I just believe the tile draws to be too powerful in this game.  If you don't get the right draws, the game is tedium as you watch your opponents pull away, and the rich get richer.

RATING: 2
The issue I have with this game is that if no one takes over the companies in which you hold stock, and you don't draw those merger tiles yourself, you're stuck sitting there only playing tiles.  It's still a fun game though, and something a family would like to play.

Variant: After each round (once around the table), randomly draw a tile and place it on the board.  This will both speed the game up and mean that new hotels may have a higher stock price right off the bat.

LOCATION: B3

7-27-14 Game this evening one of the best we have had. 3 player Barb(RIP) , Mike and me (Ron) won by Mike with 57,300 to my 55,800 and Barb's 54,000 won on last play by Mike when he merged a corner tile with Continental 3 squares big into American to get paid for first in Continental and also end the game. I was second in Continental but the difference between Mike' first and my second gave him just enough $ to at the end after all the final payoffs give  him a 1500 dollar win. If I could have reached 41 tiles and ended the game I would have won and if Barb could have done a small Festival merger before Mike she would have merged into American creating 41 and she would  have won and she had the tile to do so.

RATING: 8
Unique game concept in which the board is not a geographical map, but more of an abstract description of the relative sizes of companies and their probabilities of taking part in a merger.

I have the Hasbro 2008 edition, which is distinguished by its truly deplorable component quality.  (I think this is the first time that a game publisher has expected me to construct a Scrabble-style tile rack from a thin cardboard punch-out.)  I will be keeping an eye out for opportunities to pick up a different release.

Plays pretty well all the way up to 6 players, but there is lots of downtime with that many at the table.

RATING: 6
Okay, this game is a sacred cow in the game world, but I haven't enjoy it most of the times I have played it. There is always some sad player who is out of phase with the game. They're out of money and their turns are all but meaningless. It's tough to watch this player going through the motions being dragged by the game. It's even tougher BEING that player. A player can make all the right choices and still be completely snake bit. There are so many better game available now, why bother with this tired old dog. If you're looking for a game that can scratch your Acquire itch, try  [GAMEID=433], the Ravensburger 2001 Edition, instead.

RATING: 2
#Family

90% luck. If you have bad luck you can never build a hotel chain and get one extra card. If you have bad luck you can never do a fusion. If you are at the wrong place on the table, all players before you buy all the interesting stuff. Totally random and waste of time.

Even my 2nd play couldn't improve my opinion about this game. I prefer watching paint drying.

It's horrible with 6 players, you wait about 15min for your turn because some people are thinking about 2-3min. And this is a totally waste of time, you also can complete your turn within 20s and you can win.

[c]
Theme:          :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [size=7]I don't feel like a hotel manager[/size]
Gameplay:       :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [size=7]Very repetitive[/size]
Interaction:    :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [size=7]Look where your opponents placing their tiles, that's all[/size]
Luck:           :star::star::star::star::nostar: [size=7]Heavily depends on what tiles you draw[/size]
Strategy:       :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [size=7]Try, but it won't help[/size]
Components:     :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [size=7]Ugly plastic shit[/size]
Play duration:  :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [size=7]Way too long[/size]
Easy to teach:  :star::star::star::star::nostar: [size=7]The only advantage[/size]
Setup time:     :star::star::star::star::nostar: [size=7]At least you don't waste to much time here...[/size]
No downtime:    :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [size=7]Depends on players, can be really huge[/size]
[/c]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For an oldie very good and even when measured with today's standards it holds its ground. Simple rules and yet a challenging gameplay. There is randomness but in the end your score depends on your skill and outsmarting abilities.

There are many games published 10 or 20 years later that don't reach the level of Acquire in any way, shape or form - it's classics and still fresh. Although some of its elements are not as good as they should be, it's still hell of a game.

Recommend.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An old classic, and a favourite of mine. Simple, elegant and one game I happen to feel I am pretty good at! Definitely a lot more to it than might appear at first glance; while the luck of the tile draw is significant, you can influence this element a lot more than many realise.
I definitely prefer those editions with proper physical tiles rather than a flat board and cards or chits.
IMHO, this is not a memory game and shares should be played open, though I don't mind playing semi-open or closed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Sid Sackson's masterpiece is considered a landmark in game design for good reason. It has one big problem, however: it just looks and sounds like it would be incredibly boring (especially the drab 3M edition, which looks like something that only an accountant could enjoy).  With three or four players, Acquire is a delicately-textured counterpoint of many levels of strategy and tactics.  Outrageous luck will occasionally rear its head, but most games will be won through skillful play. And despite the rather somber appearance, it's not an intimidating or brain-burning type of game.  And *definitely* not boring! (unless you play with hidden shares a.k.a. "Acquire the Headache")

RATING: 8
Fantastic game with minimal luck and quick pace that escalates the tension right until the very end. The game is deservedly acknowledged as a classic: it's easy to learn, is competely unique, and will appeal to a wide audience while still being a "gamers" game at its core. My only complaint is the amount of multiplication, addition, and referencing that's necessary every turn of the game. You'll need one person who's good at basic accounting (or with a spreadsheet!) to keep track of the costs of things. Great game, however, and highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After many plays, I can say that Acquire is probably a good game, but it's not one I really ever want to play.  It seems less like a game and more of an abstract mathematical simulation, except with a small element of bluffing and quite a lot of luck.  In fact, it seems that if the players are all sufficiently familiar with the game, a lot of it just comes down to luck.  I just don't like it at all.

RATING: 8
Acquire is dry as a bone, but it stands the test of time. I like that the complexity of the game arises from the many strategies one can employ rather than the rules (which are pretty simple and straightforward).

A strong argument can be made that Acquire is the father of modern "eurogames" but it remains an eminently playable one.

RATING: 6.5

I'd rate it more highly but 1) the components are all plastic, and 2) the theme isn't a big draw for me. Winning based on having more money than everyone else seems a hollow victory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
After just one game I give this a solid 8.5. It is a fun game, but takes quite a while to fully grasp what is needed to succeed. My next game will be much clearer, and I can't wait to give it another whirl. It has a nice balance between trying to out think your opponent and guess at what stocks they will purchase, and worrying about what tiles your opponents have that could possibly merge your companies when you don't want them to merge. The 3 tiers of companies adds another bit of strategy, in whether you want to invest in the heavy hitters, or get quick money with the low cost start-ups.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Original (2003): Avoided playing this for years. The tile mechanic just seemed too random to me. After playing the game a few times, I feel the need to repent. An amazing game that requires an flexible approach against an ever changing board. Update: Here at the University of Illinois College of Law this game has, at least temporarily, replaced Poker. A dozen or so people have learned to play, and the game is hitting the table two or three times a week for a pre-bar play. 

Update (2010): I don't know how many games have been played at this point, but it seems increasingly obvious that the game becomes increasingly strategic as the players become more experienced. 

Update (2014): Still playing. I wish I'd kept track of how many games, but if you count online play, it's in the hundreds.

Update (2016): And I just keep on playing. I have seven active games on gamesbyemail.com, with friends, at all times.

Note: when it comes to table play it's worth tracking down an early edition with the plastic board and tiles. All of the subsequent versions feel junky, fiddly, or cheap.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With a theme of corporate America and a bland-looking board covered in nothing but letters and numbers, it might seem odd that I find this game as enjoyable as I do. And indeed, there is a strong feeling of abstraction. But stronger still is the feeling of tension that exists here. Acquire is chock-full of moments that literally get your heart racing, not in excitement, but in suspense.

The turn structure (and the game itself) are quite simple. You place a tile, buy up to three stocks, and draw a new tile. Two adjacent tiles starts a corporation, which will grow in stock price with the addition of further tiles. When two corporations are joined, the bigger one takes over the smaller one. Those with stock in the smaller one get a payout, either in cash or stock of the larger company. This continues until the board is full, and everyone gets a final payout for the stocks they hold. 

The strategy here is about getting majority ownership in as many companies as possible. This requires getting others to help you merge companies (by having SOME stock in them) but with you holding the most. It also requires careful managing of your cash flow so you can always spend your money on new stocks, predicting the right moment of the merger. Your stocks never really LOSE value, which I like, but it can definitely be bad to invest heavily in a company that only sees minor growth.

It's a shame that the current printing of this venerable classic is so shoddy. The 1999 edition is the kind of treatment it really deserves. This one is a very fun game, not just for when it came out, but even today.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I don't really like this game, but there's no denying that it's a classic.  I recently came in 2nd in a game (as opposed to my regular last place) because I held shares in almost every company.  Well, it was also because I actually got some merge tiles, and thus had control over who got money and who didn't.

I must remember never to play a 3-player game.  Usually, one person gets screwed (getting no cash until the end of the game) while the other two get multiple payouts which allows them to re-invest and grow.  The only way out of this is to find some incentive for another player to make a merger that pays something to you.  Perhaps you have to play for second place in other people's big companies... but that gets competitive too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This looks and feels old, but also all too fresh at the same time. Playing this for the first time in 2014 makes me wonder, if Sid Sackson were alive today, would he be partaking producing worker-placement resource conversion games? I say this because this game was created before there seemed to be *an8 archetype for what a boardgame should be, or at the least the archetype that would have been available for boardgames at the time (as I understand it) wasn't all that hot (and invited different takes). 

Social commentary aside, this economic tile laying game holds up incredibly well today for a game from the 1960s. It has the spatial competition, interaction, and vague ownership of Tigris & Euphrates with a speculative market (rather than a more granular victory point system). When to buy shares and how many becomes a financial game of chicken as you want to maximize your shareholding (and not get locked out of growing businesses) but at the same time, you don't want to be unable to participate in buying shares because you blew your load too early. Great economic and spatial interaction and competition. The fluid financial values make it difficult to keep track of who's where, which I appreciate (so long as everyone at the table is down for a gut feeling type game - which I usually am).

-------------------------------------------------------
Update September 2015
I've dropped the rating from an 8 to a 7 as I'm not sure how deep the game is -- while I still very much enjoy the game (it's tense, fun, and iconic), I'm not sure how many more strategic surprises the game has in store in terms of creative, clever, and dickish plays.

I recognize the importance of Acquire (as well as how easy it is to teach), but given the choice, would rather play Tigris and Euphrates, Reef Encounter, or Khronos.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Classic game, with a good portion of luck in the drawing of tiles. You have to be in some of the early mergers to prevent you from falling behind. The key is to predict (unless you can control) which chains will be taken over and merged in to a larger chain. 

The game is very easy to learn, and is suitable for the casual gamers as well as experienced gamers who can tolerate some luck. I am a happy owner of the 1999 Hasbro Edition which has been made with quality components. The latest version (2008) with thin cardboard bits looks cheap and does not do this fine game justice. Such a classic game should be produced with better components.

RATING: 6.5

RATING: 9
2-18-10
Now that I've played it a few more times, this game has held strong ground.  Trying to piece together tiles for your own benefit while investing in the right companies at the right time is a lot of fun.  A bonus is that my parents both like this game so it's pretty easy to get on the table.

However, the luck can be a bit much.  If you establish a company early and are able to pick up a bunch of stock in it, then sell it, and continue to build it once or twice more, there's just not much to be done about it.  If the tiles are on your side, you can get a lot of extra bonuses.  If they're not on your side though, it can feel fruitless.  I also don't particularly like how people can be ousted for many turns until someone finally merges the right companies.  It's their own fault, sure, but it brings down the fun if you sit there just playing a tile while others continue to buy up stocks and dominate you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A classic game that continues to be heralded as one of the greatest games ever published, and deservedly so. Simple rules, simple play, but sophisticated strategy and some luck. The theme is abstract, but the feel is undeniably "corporate" / "big business". The best incarnations are the 3M/AH bookcase version with hotels (if you can find it) or the 1999 AH/Hasbro big box version with corporations (again, if you can find it). Avoid the cardboard versions if you can. What AH has done, reprinting this game on TWO different occasions with lousy cardboard is not only criminal... it's an outrage. Shame on you corporate bean counters!

Update (08/22/09) 6 plays - Seems to drag out unnecessarily with 6 players, and there seems to be too much chaos. It is relatively unpredictable what will happen in-between turns, and waiting for five players to react is too long. Sometimes, it is just luck that one picks the right corporation(s) to invest in. Feels like 4 players would be the sweet spot, but will have to play some more.

Update (08/14/10) 17 plays: Played with 6P and won, but barely. Another player and I were conceivably not doing so well throughout the game, but were only $200 off! The 2nd place player had majority one of the three final corporations (39 tiles, upper-tier), while I had 1st place the last of the three (16 tiles, middle-tier), and 2nd place in the second largest (25 tiles, lower-tier). It seemed that one player who merged within the first turn, would have the advantage in gaining a huge influx of cash early, but he didn't win, since he allocated his capital poorly in some corporations that did not grow. With 6P, I believe one must be extremely selective in what corporations they invest in, and not just any one because they're cheap (if it doesn't grow, it's dead money). At least I knew that I had the expansion (and merger) tiles for the corporations I was investing in. There is some uncertainty, as players ahead of you will merge unexpectedly, or start a corporation somewhere where you didn't want it, but one must adapt; sometimes, they give you the game unexpectedly. For this game, I went in with the intention of being extremely selective, so is that the winning strategy for 6 players?

Update (08/18/2014) 36 plays: Still a solid "10" after all these years. Played the two-player variant rules, but aborted halfway through game. The game is extremely fragile and easy to break. The game is very slow to develop initially, since there are only two tiles to start out. If one player is lucky enough to get a merger, they will most likely get the minority bonus (as the tile draw determines how many shares the bank has, and that can range up to "12"), and the other player will get nothing. From there, it is an economic snowball with very little chance of clawing back in. That minority bonus can be used to buy all the vulnerable corporations, essentially locking out the other player from getting any bonus (the bank getting the majority, most of the time). Possible fixes (that have been play tested by others) are to start with $10,000 instead of $6,000, and to halve the number on the tile draw to determine the number of shares from the bank. Rules as written, two-player is broken and not recommended. It is a "2". With fixes, it may be higher, but I think I'll never play this again with two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6


fun but big boss is better

thifted traded reprinted

RATING: 9
This game is a swastika tattoo tramped-stamped on a sweet baby Jesus tattoo tramp-stamped on a tycoon-quality, bipolar call girl.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's kind of a travesty that Monopoly is making millions every year and has a complete hold on the popular view of what a board game is when a genuinely good game like this has been around for 50 years and is virtually unknown outside the board game niche.

This is very thematic, the way you need to maintain liquidity and you can completely screw someone out of the assets they have spent the game building up just because they have no money left and you do really makes a player feel like a business mogul

It plays quite quickly and takes up to six, both of which are good traits.  You do need to play the odds, you can't go in with a predetermined strategy because what tiles you get has a huge impact on what you can do.  If you do not like games that require you to manage chaos you may not like this.  This is not to say that it is a random game, the decisions you make are what creates the opportunities for you to do well.

My only complaint, and unfortunately it is a significant one, is that if you bet wrong you may end up crippled with all your assets invested in hotel chains that aren't being developed and no ability to do anything to affect your position. When I started playing this sort of thing happened a lot because people put all their eggs in one basket and when that basket was left on the shelf they got in trouble.  Now people almost never do that and ensure they have a diversified portfolio so that hopefully most things that might happen can profit them somewhat.  Even though that makes it less likely it is still possible that your investments end up not paying off and once you have no money you are powerless for the rest of the game.  This is no fun and makes you glad this is a relatively short game.

Still, on the whole this is a great game which I recommend.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of only three games I own which I recommend to both family and gamers, the others being Modern Art and Scotland Yard.  Acquire has two parts: (1) a distinctly abstract method of visualising the growth of corporations over which the players have direct (but not complete) influence, and (2) an element whereby players have to manage the risk of their investment based on the size of the corporations.  These two elements combined offer a unique gaming experience which is both deep yet accessible!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Stock manipulating games tend to be fairly dry, which is why this has never sold as well as rivals like Monopoly. Were this to be published as a German game today it would be derided for its luck of the draw mechanism, so I suspect there's some sentiment in the high ratings here. You need to ensure that you're a beneficiary of the first merger or two, that's the only way that you can gain liquidity. If you don't and run out of money you'll rapidly fall behind and the extent to which you do that is largely governed by the random tile draw. In spite of all the above, this is one of the few Sid Sackson games I'm happy to play. A well above average game for the date of its invention.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
First played March 4th, 2009. Taught in 10 minutes, played in about and hour and 15 minutes with 3 players. It seems with more players it would take a little longer. There is good luck/strategy balance in the game. You will need to decide when a good time to buy and sell to make the most money at the end of the game. Each player is given $3,000 to start and each player draws a tile to place on the board and 6 to fill their starting tiles. Then the start player places one of their 6 tiles. If that creates a space with two or more tiles together then they place a hotel of their choice (from 6 hotels out of the game) and get 1 stock of that hotel (for free) and can buy up to three of any hotels (can three different or 2 of one and one of another as well) that are in existance. The cost of the 3 stocks is dependant of how many squares make up the hotel and the type of hotel (see chart). Then you draw a tile to get back up to 6. Each following player can place a tile (creating a new hotel if possible, adding on to an existing, or a single tile) and has the option to buy up to three stock. A player may also merge ONLY if at least one hotel has less than 10 tiles, otherwise those tiles can be thrown out of the game. If the tile merges two or more hotels then there is a merger and the lesser hotels merge into unless it's a tie and the tile place decides. The majority and minoirty stock holders gets a certain bonus. If a tie, those tied split. Merging hotels' stock can either be traded in 2 for 1 of the new stock, sold a current value prior to the merger, or held (if held and the chain does not start back up again it would be worthless. Starting with the tile placer, each can trade in stocks or sell. The the current player gets their option to buy 3 stocks. The game is over when there are no more stocks to be sold. Once a hotel was merged it's avaliable to be re-placed on the board if the senerio presents itself. You can't place a tile to create a new hotel chain if none of the 6 hotels are availble to be placed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2/10/09
-------------------

[i]Acquire[/i] is a game where players take the role of investors buying shares in hotel companies, and capitalising on mergers, and growing their chains of hotels. This game can be played from 3 – 6 players, which is a big plus, in my opinion, as it seems to scale very well, but plays differently at each level. The complexity is fairly low, and younger gamers should have no trouble understanding how to play, though the nuances of strategy may be out of their grasp.

The basis of the game is, of course, a share market mechanism, and it the main decisions on the game are choosing the right moment to invest in a company, when to merge, and even when to end the game. The tiles and luck impact the amount of control you have over where the game goes, whether one hotel will grow bigger, or be merged and usually does not stop a player from making the right decisions, though it is still possible to be severely hampered by an unfortunate run of tiles, as has happened to me numerous times. However, a better player should be able to time their purchases correctly, and as buying usually is not affected by tile-laying, there is plenty of opportunity to maintain a lead.

In conclusion, this game is very good at doing what it does, and the difference in play for each number of players and variance in tile layout ensure that there will be much replay ability in this game. The thing that stops [i]Acquire[/i] from being rated a 10 is the lack of control. Though it should not prevent a good player from winning, it can detract from the experience, as you do not dictate the direction and have no chance to take the initiative. It is rare that this continues for the whole game, however, keeping this game’s rating at a very respectable 9.

[b]Pros[/b]
-	Fast paced
-	Interesting decisions for most of the game
-	Lots of player interaction
-	Scales very well
-	Luck is minimal

[b]Cons[/b]
-	Lack of control over game at some stages
-	May be at mercy of other players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The perfect mix of tile picking luck and strategic placement. Picture Monopoly meets Scrabble and had a child that was actually fun. I can play this with family and friends and it has yet to repeat itself or get dull.

RATING: 9
I like this game.  It is a fairly quick game to play compared to some of our others.  I would have liked to have gotten a Hasbro Avalon Hill edition (which is now out of print) but I have two 3M copies.  The game is simple to teach to new players.  The trick is to acquire stock in companies and become the majority holder in the ones that grow.  But you also want to have a majority of stock in companies that are going to be dissolved when they are acquired so you get more cash.

RATING: 6
I finally played this old classic of Sackson's and I felt lukewarm, at best, toward it.  Acquire is pretty dated by now.  There's a significant amount of luck in tile draws, deciding what to buy can feel arbitrary at first, and there isn't a whole lot really going on.  Basically, it's a guessing game on what shares to buy as little information comes up as to what will merge and payoff.  Miss the first few mergers and it can feel like a prolonged funeral.  I'd play it again, but probably wouldn't ever request it.

RATING: 8

RATING: 10
In all reality this is not a 10/10.  I however do rank it as a 10/10 because of its sentimental factor.  

Acquire is the game that got me into the hobby.  Its the game I have played with casual gamers that has gotten them into gaming.  Its easy to teach, fun to play, and has that climatic ending!

While there are games that are better now days for me this will always be one of my favorites.  Over 200 plays for me and I still love it.

RATING: 6
Ideal Players: 3-6

Description: Trade stock in hotel chains as they grow and merge. 

Pro: Interesting mechanic to take advantage of inside information. Deep strategy to take advantage of growth and merging. Subtle hints from watching other players' actions.

Con: Virtually no theme. Paper money is a little fiddly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic Avalon Hill game.  Though it has been recently reprinted, I think I want to wait and find the Hasbro edition with the plastic pieces.

There is a nice balance in the game between do I want my copy to get larger so I can win at the end of the game or to sell it off early to get more profit now.  The downside of the game is that there can be a lot of luck in tile draws.  In the early game, you want to be able to start a company and get the free stocks for opening a company.  If you don't get that, then you can be quickly out of the game.

RATING: 5
Good for its age, but see EDITs...
I'd say it's slightly better with higer number of players (5-6) than with lower (3).

AH 1999 edition rulez ;-)

[I had a chance to play AH 2008 version -> horrifying experience...;  and I see no appeal in 1995 Schmidt Spiele version -> AH 1999 edition is SO MUCH better...]

EDIT: I can see the problem - sometimes game puts you in 'no control, no win' situation and you cannot do anything about it.  Also, sometimes I feel there is too little room for manoeuvre and too few interesting decisions.

EDIT2: After 6 plays I can conclude with certainty - the game is very luck-dependent and huge snowball effect can occur too.  Of course, there are games when the luck is equally distributed and then satisfying, close, emotions-packed game shapes up, but this happens in the minority of cases...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So far 8 plays on computer version...

I can see why this game not only stands the test of time, but does it with style. It may be a dinosaur but it won't ever be extinct, looks to be the grand-daddy of tile layers. Very calculative and engrossing, great watching the hotel chains grow and then merge. Fast play, some strategy, quite tactical and fun getting rich.

[u]UPDATE:[/u] I was surprised how well this game handled 6 players, it was a little slow and long for what it is but it was smooth overall and didn't seem too chaotic like I thought it might be with 6. We played the Sid S variant of putting all the unclaimed tiles (after initial random distribution) back on the board upside down at the start of the game and picking from the board which gives you much more control than picking randomly from a blind pile, I don't think I can go back now...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Acquire has one of the best board development mechanics that I have seen. What happens in the play area directly affects the value of companies and stocks, and that makes it addictive. Random tile drawing can get frustrating though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I kind of dismissed this game for a long time because I felt like it was too random, but now I'm starting to change my mind a bit.

The thing that has made the difference is that I have started hanging on to pieces that are near or adjacent to chains rather than playing them.  The result - I now mysteriously have merger pieces all the time whereas I used to complain about how I never drew them.

I feel like I should have had this "aha" moment a long time ago.

RATING: 10
Takes second place to Union Pacific in my book, both having very similar mechanics. But Acquire is truly excellent. I initially put off playing this game for a very long time, mostly because of seemingly boring the theme of buying and selling stocks. Well, after playing it I finally realized what I'd been missing and that the theme is actually perfect and not dry at all! It's a great game, don't wait like I did to play it.

Update: I've played it about 150 times now in the past nine or ten years and I have to say that really wish I'd played twice as much.  I don't play nearly enough and I lament that fact very much. This game is definitely in my top 25, if not my top 10 favorites of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When one gets down to it, Acquire is sort of a tactical gambling game. There is quite a bit of luck here, but players must use the information they have to guess where the tiles will be placed.

The luck factor is a bit higher than I'd like and the amount of in-game accounting can be tedious, but I still enjoy it because it's easy to teach and almost always plays out very tensely.

There's a reason this game is still played 50 years after its release - now if Avalon Hill / Wizards / Hasbro would just release a new version with better components, it might get to the table even more often than it does.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This one doesn't hit the table often, which is a shame since we always say, "Hey, we should play that more often" when we're done.

RATING: 8.5

I ranked it higher because for a game of this solid of design and ability to be learned quick and enjoyed by more casual gamers. Still can take 1.5-2 hours to play.

Note: I will only play this game with open stocks (but closed money)... otherwise unless you have good memory as to who has majority/minority, it's like playing in the dark (does make game go much faster with closed stocks but for me just no fun and random)

RATING: 7
2011-07-22

Initial Rating: 5.0 (July 2010)

Acquire is an "Acquired" taste :P. I didn’t like it a bit the first few plays (the original rating was around 5.0) but I’m beginning to see why so much people like the game. It has luck but almost always the best player is the winning one. It is not an easy game, it has a steep learning curve but I totally recommend it. This is a classic and a true gamer’s game.

In general, new players don’t know what to do and this often leads to unintentional kingmaking.

I love to play with hidden information.

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2015-09-11

I like Acquire a lot. It is amazing to me that a game so old can be still so good. Sid Sackson was indeed a great designer. Acquire rules are mind-numbingly easy but the game has a huge depth, every move counts and I still learn new things every time I play it.

The game components of the Avallon Hill edition are great, the 3M edition are also very good. I still haven’t played with the new edition but I have heard the components are very regular. 

As I wrote before, I always like when a game has a memory component, so I love to play Acquire with hidden shares.

Current Rating: 7.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This comment is only for the 2016 Hasbro edition.

2017-06-18

Initial Rating: 7.0 (May 2017)

I really like Acquire, a game with a permanent spot among my game collection. I was happy to learn Hasbro was printing a new edition as the 2008 one wasn’t very good components’ wise.

The new edition of Acquire changes some rules of the game. First and most important now the third place on the mergers also wins some money. I’m not sure how I feel about this, but perhaps it makes the game more strategic and reduces a little bit the luck factor, overall I think I like this change, it also makes the game a lot easier and forgiving. Second, they made the board smaller, this impact when a corporation is safe and when the game´s end. I don’t like this change as much, but it is a minor issue. Third, there are less shares per corporation, this doesn’t bother me.

Acquire´s new components are great looking, but as is usual from Hasbro, they dropped the ball, this time with the board. They, obviously, didn´t test it. It is very hard to see the numbers on the board. In our game (and the games of many friends) players have made mistakes because they cannot see clearly the coordinates, they are too obscure. A friend solved this painting them white but I’m very disappointed by this. To add insult to injure, Hasbro also chose a font that is hard to read as well. Both of these deficiencies lead to players making mistakes when they play.

Bottom line, the new components are great, but the usability of the game decreased a lot due to the obscure board and the font they used. I´m very disappointed by this, I won’t replace my old copy of the game.  You can read my opinion of the game in the other entry. The current rating for my old copy of Acquire is 7.0.

Current Rating: 6.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've turned the corner on this game, I think.  After a long while where I refused to play because my group played with closed shares, I finally played, did reasonably well (3rd out of 6) and generally enjoyed myself.  I still prefer the game with open shares as I just don't care for burning my brain tracking information.

This is the stock game distilled to its very core.  Unlike in many other stock games, where valuation of the stock presents the primary challenge, Acquire has always seemed to me to play more like an area majority game, as the bonuses are very clear and open to everyone who wants to count the tiles on the board.  And yet I like it anyway, probably for the same reason I like El Grande despite my general distaste for the mechanic.  Implemented well, area control games can be packed with tension, and Acquire's uncertainty of payouts provides the tension that even cousins like El Grande lack with their fixed payout systems.

Rating is a composite of a 7 for closed shares, and a 9 for open shares.  The annoyance of having to track the shares is that pronounced for me, though I can see the case for viewing the closed-shares variant as a better game.  It might be, but I find it significantly less fun because my disinterest in tracking information puts me at a disadvantage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
one of the best money/stock game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I very much enjoy the strategy (which is deep and challenging) and the randomizing factor of the hidden tiles.

There is a thrill to backing one particular hotel chain and trying to get it to 11 before it can be acquired. This is a well-designed game.

I'd play it more often if it weren't for the tendency to run long and push away new players due to the learning curve on the strategic elements.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
God, could I suck more please?

A classic game, great strategy, can be brutal, you can be out of the game with no chance to catch up VERY early in the game, but you can still influence events and the shape of the game...believe me, I'm very experienced in this role! :)

There are 2 ways to play: open shares--you can see exactly how many each player owns; and hidden shares--you can't see how many each players owns. I strongly prefer the hidden shares. It introduces a bit of memory, a bit of gambling, and more risk yet it reduces none of the strategy.

Open holdings is the best way to start, but it leads to slow games and trite games as the counting becomes a crutch for folk every single round and every single action. Open shares does allow an almost perfect information game...but it sucks the fun out of the game for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Late to the party as usual, 49 years after this came out (it's the same age as me) I finally get to play it. At least I got to play the classic AH bookcase edition - always a pleasure to pull a bookcase game off the shelf.

Turns out it's a Euro-style stock market/financial game (i.e. a numbers optimiser, albeit just about the original) but it has a number of twists that still make it attractive. 

I like the spatial elements on the board (many number optimisers are nothing but just that), I also like the drive to build up majorities in minor companies with the intention of having other companies buy them out while you are the majority shareholder - easier said than done.

Like many modern optimisation games (hello Powergrid) the end game slows down frustratingly as players try to optimise their final score in the last few plays, otherwise sound.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Before there were "German" games there was Sid.  Excellent game that has stood the test of time.

***Update***
I think I'm the odd man out but I've always played this with hidden shares although the number left is public knowledge.  I've talked to some who hide money.  Still others play with completely open knowledge of shares and money.  I'm not sure I'd like that.  Think it would remove some of the tension from the game.  Overall, a classic and a title I don't imagine will get traded away.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]1979 Spiel des Jahres Selection[/url][/b]

[url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameversion/20508/avalon-hill-hasbro-english-large-box-edition-1999]Acquire: Avalon Hill 1999 Edition[/url]

Each player strategically invests in businesses, trying to retain a majority of stock. As the businesses grow with tile placements, they also start merging, giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizable bonuses, which can then be used to reinvest into other chains. All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks for current value or trade them 2-for-1 for shares of the newer, larger business. The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth.

Players:   3, 4, 5, 6
Time:      90 min
Mechanics:  [property=2040][/property], [property=2005][/property], [property=2002][/property]

RATING: 8.4

I definitely enjoy this game far more. This game flows really well. It never dragged and although in the game I played it took a while for the first takeover to happen I was told that was unusual.  The rules are simple enough once you have played a few rounds and the game is intuitive enough that I was able the plan strategys before we had it mid game in my first play. I would definitely play this again and wouldn't turn down a game. A solid game from a master game designer. I'm proud to have this one in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Thrifted a 1968 version!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Most turns in Acquire revolve around a key question - do I expand or merge a chain now, or wait while I quietly try to gain cheap shares or a majority in the chain? There is a significant bluffing element where you try to buy shares to set up future plays without signaling to the other players your intentions. I think what makes a tile-laying game great, is that the tiles played continue to have meaning through to completion. Since chain size determines value and payout, tile plays certainly hold their meaning to the end. Bad choices early can doom you to having little or no money for much of the game.

It's the luck factor that keeps this from being a 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not very good as a two-player or as a six-player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The more you play the faster it goes, but with 6 there can be some downtime. If you buy stock until you run out of money, you will either win the game when you are lucky with the first mergers or you will have to look at it without anything to do for the rest of the game when you are unlucky. It takes a while before you realise this. Over all I like it, though. (10 jan 09 after 9 plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A classic intro to commodity speculation for those who would otherwise be uninterested in the topic. Think of it as a natural transition from monopoly. However, if players specifically want a commodity speculation game, skip Acquire and go right to Chicago Express, Container, or Modern Art as better starters. 

As for Acquire proper, it is EXTREMELY dependent upon players of equal skill. With less skillful players all I have to do is count cards (i.e stocks) to stay in the money. Finding the optimal move each time is too easy, I find that I play this game on auto-pilot and still manage to win 95% of our plays. The random tile draws are swingy though not terribly annoying. I have little desire to play this unless it's as an introduction or with highly skilled players. I appreciate its history and contributions to gaming but it just isn't an evergreen for me. 

WIFE RATING - 7

RATING: 8
A classic.  This is where tile laying games all began.  For me, it is the simplist, yet most elegant of all the tile laying games.  The rules are easy to master.  Learning a winning strategy, that takes a while.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A classic investing game in which you place tiles on a board to "grow" companies you own stock in. If a tile touches two companies, they merge, and the owners of the smaller company are paid out dividends. The key choices to make are which companies to invest in, how heavily to invest, and which tiles to hold back for timely mergers. 

As a ~50 year old game, the established fan base divides into two camps: open shares or closed shares. With closed shares there is a heavy memory aspect, which the fans of that style of play are comfortable ignoring. With open shares the game becomes a little bit bland. Still good, but not remarkable. I prefer open but even then Acquire is a "once-in-a-while" game. It might be fun with the family but there are better choices for that scenario. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
It's a stock trading game.  Not my genre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great stock ownership game that remains relevant decades after it was produced. The game play is simple but the decisions are not. Most of your decisions revolve around when to cash out of companies and when to hold on to the stock for future gains.

I main criticism is that there is just a tad more luck than I like, however for a 6 player game that plays in 75 minutes it's not too much luck. Imperial is a better game with open info and much more to think about but plays in at least twice the time as Acquire. If you like Imperial but find it doesn't get to the table as often as you'd like because of the time investment than try this out it might scratch that itch for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If there is a game that is a true modern classic then it is Acquire. For its time it was a breakthrough design. Compared with today's games it is abstract and a bit bland, especially when played on one of the original 3M editions. Remarkably, the abstract mechanisms fit the theme of mergers & acquisitions perfectly. It couldn't be more contemporary in the way that the shareholders of the overtaken company often are the real winners. It's great to see such a basic design esteemed highly today and I personally enjoy it more than many overchromed modern economic games. The game end calculations could be less tedious though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Only have played the 3M version so far. My Avalon Hill edition from 1999 is still in shrink.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A most important thing in this game is to tackle the mid-game money shortage. Because of that, first you are forced to make some short term investments. On the other hand, there is nothing better than to see how investing in two-tile corporation earns you big money at the end. Almost everything in this game is right: limited shares, a little bit of luck in the drawn tiles, forbidding players to sell their shares any time, they want, etc.

Svarbiausias tikslas šiame žaidime - išvengti žaidimo vidurio pinigų trūkumo problemos. Dėl to žaidėjai yra priversti bent kažkiek investuoti trumpajam laikotarpiui. Iš kitos pusės, nėra nieko smagiau, kaip matyti kaip investicija į dviejų langelių korporaciją žaidimo gale uždirba daug pinigų. Beveik viskas šiame žaidime padaryta teisingai: ribotas akcijų kiekis, truputis sėkmės langelių traukime, draudimas žaidėjams parduoti savo akcijas, kada tik jie nori ir t.t...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

Almost everything in this game is right: limited shares, a little bit of luck in the drawn tiles, forbidding players to sell their shares any time, they want, etc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Acquire fully deserves its classic status. It is a solid design in which you have to have a bit of a different mindset when comparing to all the other stock market games I've played. The stakes in the acquired company matter in the mergers during the game much more than the stakes in the acquiring company, but towards the end this dynamic turns upside down. Suffers a bit from the reality that if you don't get the right tiles early on to force the right mergers you may just run out of money and turn into a bystander.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 7
This game is the oldest that receives a high rating from me. My main concern is the memorization element surrounding stock holdings.

Update: after a few plays I realize that it is not particularly deep but still enjoyable for a 40 year old game. The memorization is not a big deal as you will probably focus on a few companies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have a love hate relationship with this game. Either you get a merger early and get ahead or you just hope the luck of the draw changes down the line and you can catch back up.

Still though, of all the strategy games that are like this, I enjoy this one more due to it's uncomplicated nature using the same 'win by draw' mechanic.

Some will debate that you can still out strategize people. Sure, if you play with a bunch of lesser lifeforms or play it a lot more than someone else sure... but then no one else has any fun either.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A game I played and enjoyed as a kid, but have grown to appreciate more as I've become a "gamer".  The one page rulebook and simple turn structure makes the game lightning-quick to learn, but the strategies and tactics required to play well are rather deep.  The restrictions inherent to the turn sequence force lots of agonizing decisions.  One of the best!

RATING: 9
A pure stock game, absolutely addictive. 

It doesn't show its age at all. Fast, and very highly recommended, although I wouldn't play it with more than four. MAYBE five if people were desperate, but it'd be a horrible game if everything depended on happening to draw the right tile in the opening and get the right bonus stock as might be the case. Best if you're a huge investor with enough capital to spread it around rather than some sucker with a pension so small as to not be worth diversifying.

RATING: 7.5
Good game.  Pretty straightforward and easy to learn.  Plenty of strategy (with a good mix of luck involved).  Much better alternative to Monopoly or any other financial game I have played.  This is an interesting game in that I never really suggest it and am not overly thrilled to play it when it is suggested by others, but ALWAYS enjoy playing.  Very tense moments...

EDIT:  The more I play this game, the more I think there is a serious flaw.  If you get shut out of the first merge and you don't get into a merge within your next turn or two, you are hosed for the rest of the game.

RATING: 7
Played 2 player, would like to play with more, though 2 works well with the game provided rule modifications.

Very tense throughout and tough decisions to make.  You have to be careful with your decisions, the more you make, the less you have.  If you over extend, you find yourself with nothing to do until a merger happens.  It's similar to using all your meeples in Carcasonne.

1st game took 2.5 hours to finish, but was very easy to learn.

Main detractor is its dryness as you find yourself examining a grid of numbers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
How did I miss this for most of my life???  This Sid Sackson classic was decades ahead of its time.  Play is very simple - just play a tile and buy some stock - but doing well takes some skill and a little bit of luck.  It rewards being able to anticipate which hotel chains will merge next, as well as getting the timing right in switching over from getting quick cash to investing in the long term.  More than anything, it's a family-friendly game that is lots of fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Very simple rules, and easy to teach. That it's a stock game buying game in which you win by having the most money means makes it understandable to anyone who has played Monopoly. But it can be  counter-intuitive (the company isn't really yours and also you want your company to to get swallowed for the cash bonus). There's a lot to consider, like: what company will be the largest the end of the game?  But you want that cash bonus -- how far do you push up a company's size before placing the tile that will have it taken over, because you don't want your company to get too big, not yet.

Never has a board so bland looking looked so interesting and caused so much tension.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Definitely interesting, but I never quite manage to get the hang of a strategy.

RATING: 7
Sid Sackson should have got a Nobel Prize for this game. It is an excellent game which has stood the test of time. People can be found playing it at conventions, on-line, house cons and family groups. The luck balances out and it is the skill of where to invest that produces winners. Of all the share dealing games that have been produced over the years this is still one of the best and would be one of my Desert Island Games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After playing it twice, I can recognize that this was an amazing game in its day. It must have been a treat for the gamers of those days to play a game so ahead of its time. Unfortunately, it faces some stiff competition in this day and age. The game seems to suffer from a runaway leader problem as the rich get richer. Without the right tiles to make mergers that show you as the main benefactor, you'll quickly find yourself sunk as you watch the guy who was  in the right place at the right time breeze on to victory. I recognize that there is some more strategy to the game than I'm letting on, but it didn't seem to click after two plays. Perhaps we need to play with hidden shares. [b]5[/b]

RATING: 5

Other players have nothing to do. Whee...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This Sid Sackson classic has taken many different forms over the years depending on the publisher. Each player strategically invests in businesses, trying to retain a majority of stock. As the businesses grow with tile placements, they also start merging, giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizable bonuses, which can then be used to reinvest into other chains. All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks for current value or trade them 2-for-1 for shares of the newer, larger business. The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
The archetypal stock taking game with a random scrabble like tile laying mechanic to grow the companies.  The randomness and gamy aspect is very typical of early American boardgames but there's a core of strategy here that's rare for that period.  It's been mostly replaced by smarter & heavier alternatives like Chicago Express, Imperial, Airlines and Samarkand.

RATING: 8
This is a real classic masterpiece by a truly great designer.  I think I really like this with a full complement of 6 players.  Better to warn newbies about why one should merger only if you're in first majority and in some cases 2nd.  This gem takes a good deal of getting used to so there is a learning curve to it.  Then, of course, there's the never ending debate of open holdings vs. closed holdings...  I prefer open b/c I don't believe this should be a memory game.  

The 1999 Avalon Hill/Hasbro premium edition is superb and best edition thus far.  [posted as of Dec2009]

I also tend to have a great time with Wolfgang Kramer's Tycoon, or the Rio Grande version of Shark (aka "Acquire's evil twin brother"), or Alan Moon's Union Pacific - for which they all have some similiarities with.

RATING: 3
Acquire is a game about hotel merger and acquisition.  Very abstract for this kind of game as to the takeover occurs when two tiles of different colors touches on the square game board, rather than a diligent financial anaylsis of profitability from merging together.  Strange to me as a financial guy.  The buying and selling of shares are also a bit off-the-board as to the rising and decline of share price is determined by more or less randomness.  Strategy?  Yes, a little.  Good for casual play but don't beleive the game could give you some insight to the actual financial market operations.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]This classic tile laying stock game of mergers and acquisitions remains engaging despite its lackluster components and simple game play.[/b]
[color=red][i]Arguably Sid's finest design which has stood the test of time.[/i][/color]

SYNOPSIS
Numbered and lettered tiles are placed from one's hand in turn onto a grid representing buildings being erected in a cityscape. Players vie for controlling interest in a business by buying stock in the companies. Eventually buildings will merge together due to board constraints. At that time when businesses fold into one another creating larger companies, stock investments are paid out for those holding shares of the companies. The winner is the one who accumulates the most wealth after the game's end when a final payout of existing buildings occurs for stockholders.

COMMENTS
Though I don't own this, I do enjoy playing Acquire whenever anyone brings it to a game night. It's easy to explain, and the puzzle aspect of where best to build businesses combined with when best to buy stock makes for thoughtful consideration of capital investment strategies in order to "one up" your opponents.

PROS+, CONS- & NOTES*
+ Teaching this game is simple.
+ There are opportunities to position oneself well through clever tile placement or timely investing.
- Though good strategy is rewarded, players can get caught feeling left behind or left out of the big payouts due to unexpected circumstances.
* Different versions are aesthetically more appealing than others, but this can usually be found inexpensively at thrift stores and garage sales since several editions have been published over the years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
game gets played alot
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The first time I played this was with a friend while we were in Germany. He pulled out this game and taught me how to play. The game is mostly a waiting game and not overly difficult but it is a game where a new player will usually get crushed the first play. It is hard to know which tile to lay down in the beginning and what to invest in when you aren't familiar with the game. However, after the first game this game is great. My rating is based on the fact that there is a lot of luck (drawing tiles) and when you run out of money it can be a little boring. Overall a good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This should be right up there with Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk, Stratego, and so forth as a Classic American Game. It's easy to learn, easy to play, and has tons of strategy. Also, don't be put off by the "horrible" production quality of the most recent edition. It plays just fine, as do the older versions. The gameplay is what shines here; you don't need big plastic toys to appreciate it.

RATING: 8.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a very cutthroat Euro that as I found out can be quite unforgiving if you have no money. There's a lot of clever stock speculation in this game, and knowing when you should acquire (to raise value), be acquired (to get cash or to trade for a different company to get majority in that company), start focusing on a new company or avoid other people. How other people value things can really mess with your plans. Overall while it appears really abstract it is very true to its capitalist theme. Very ahead of its time and I can see why it became so popular. Nowadays it is probably not for everyone: as I said the game can be quite punishing for bad plays and there might be a bit of a runaway leader in that if you can acquire value early, you can potentially cash out and continue acquiring more value. However, it still holds a unique, capitalism simulation, simple yet clever niche in the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

While mathy and visually drab, this is a delightful game that holds its own against more current titles
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In this game you build hotel chains by linking more tiles to the original chain. The bigger a chain grows the more the stocks in it are worth. Money is payed out to the majority and minority stockholder when a chain is bought out out. There are a few more rules, but the overall rules are very simple. The play is complex, however, and unparalleled. One last note, this game should not be played with less than 4 players. At less than four players it bogs down and the closer you can get to the full 6 player count, the better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
During my university days I've played exhaustively a borrowed copy of 1995 AH Acquire with my classmates. Now we're all very busy at work/ family and can hardly meet, maybe 1 or 2 times per year. I brought this game out at my regular gathering so as to familiar with the rules and try it with my regular game-mates.
Many of them commented this game as heavily luck dependent, which, in my opinion, is a wrong observation. This game has quite a bit of luck, and it is usually down to a single tile to determine who's the winner. But luck won't make a good player comes out at last or make a bad player becomes the winner. Is it not the aim of Eurogames, in which experience does matter, but the novice still see a chance to win the game?

RATING: 8

All in all, this is a solid economic game with easy rules and a lot of depth. I am excited to have purchased the pretty Hasbro version now, but the game is so solid that any edition works well. This is an Absolute Classic and Highly Recommended!

Chaque joueur est un investisseur qui construit des hôtels. Mais la concurrence oblige les propriétaires à former des groupes.

RATING: 5.5
Buen juego, de mucha calidad sus materiales. Tal vez el factor suerte podría ser un poco más bajo. De hecho, con 5 jugadores, es muy, demasiado importante estar en las dos primeras fusiones. Quien no lo está, ve como sus acciones en las otras empresas valen cada vez menos, porque quienes tenían en las empresas fusionadas, adquieren gran cantidad de dinero que les permite hacerse con la mayoría en las otras empresas.
Le he  bajado la puntuación ultimamente, porque es un poco caótico. Es difícil de predecir por donde se producirán las fusiones. En síntesis, ello redunda en la dificultad de planificar, porque factores externos influyen mucho, incluída la suerte.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What can I add, really?  

This is a timeless classic, and was the bridge game that got me past Monopoly, Risk and Scrabble.  It was in the middle of a 4-player game of Scrabble about 12 years ago that a friend of mine rushed wildly into the room, rather rudely pushed the Scrabble board aside and presented us instead with this ugly plastic grid and a bunch of plastic tiles, saying "Put that away and let's play a REAL game."  We laughed out loud and dismissed him as a raving lunatic at the time, but now I realize what a favor he was trying to do for me.  I gave in and played Acquire the next time I was over, and it was the first time I'd ever been confronted in a game by the delicious need to choose the *best few* of the many desirable (no, CRITICAL!) options available to me.  I was hooked immediately.  I have been sinking into an ever-deepening pool of Geekhood ever since. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
AH/Hasbro edition.  Got in another trade.  Slight damage to one box corner.  Otherwise in great shape.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Brilliant.  Would love to play far more often as I still don't entirely understand the strategy.  My parents owned a 3M copy, and without that I'd probably never have started playing boardgames. 

I've moved this game back to 10, but I admit its a game that I actually don't understand.  It's random, but seemingly not too random.  It's nasty, but seemingly has little player interaction.  It's economic, but you seldom make money.  It plays beautifully, and maybe that's what I enjoy.  It is surely the design that launched eurogames... it just took a couple decades to hear the echo.

RATING: 7
A solid 7, by the book -- usually willing to play it.

Pretty fine mix of skill and luck, though I guess, like any game with luck, it can get a bit out of hand in any given session.

What keeps it from going higher? Mostly niggles and nitpicks. Not that fun squinting at the silly little chart, though I'm sure there are downloadable versions that are easier on the eyes.

Not that good for 'non-gamers' either. 

Early blunders, miscalculations or terrible luck can be costly, leading to a long night, but otherwise fun, challenging and engaging.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wow what a great game. I'm mad i never got to play this game growing up. After i played Power Grid, i loved the variable market mechanic, and was searching for something else in the same vein..that's when i stumbled upon Acquire! My version from 1968 really gives off a nostalgic vibe, so i don't even mind the paper money, and has nice plastic pieces. i can't imagine playing with the newer reprint that has cardboard tiles. This game has a little bit of randomness factor, which irks me, but it's not terrible. If you liked the variable market from Power Grid, you'll enjoy Acquire, as playing that market is the entire game.

RATING: N/A
Tom Vasal 2008 GOTY List Game 82
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.47
Rating:

Game quality: A game this old and this solid feels like it should get at least an 8 by default. But, I hate the "dead" turns where your placing of a block essentially feels like it does nothing. Sure, you can still deal with stocks but that one random tile might turn into something for another player before it does for you and that aspect grates at me more than it should. It is kind of a bucket list game that gamer's should at least play. I think it still serves its purpose as a gateway networking game. 7.

Would I buy this again if I was starting over: *sigh* I doubt it and that's a shame. The dead turn issue sinks this just enough and knowing there are numerous stock/networking games that came later which eventually did the idea even better makes this hard to justify again. Airlines Europe is just one example, and I know this despite not even playing it yet. Some day I will likely send off Acquire to a proper home and add in Airlines Europe. I still want to get my fill of it though. 4.

Do I want to play this if asked: Very likely. 7.

Overall: 7.47.

Rating Potential: About as high as it will go at 7.47. It did a stellar job being as good as it is for as long as it did.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This was the game I cut my early gaming teeth on.  I loved it and played it to death.  Nostalgia keeps its rating high for me but I don't reach for it like I used to.   Once exposed to a larger smorgasbord of games, Acquire feels a bit dated. I'm not fond of the memory element of trying to remember who is buying which stock. That said however, I wouldn't turn it down if that's what a group wanted to play.
