=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There's a reason this game has been around as long as it has and that's because it's excellent!  Strategy is subtle but easy enough for beginners to pick up within one or two plays.  The escalating structure of stocks forces action after sizes get to a certain point.  Even players that are not in the running for winning can still improve upon their positions and stay a part of the game until the end through acquiring stock and trying for end of game bonuses.  The game is a masterpiece!  (It is possible for someone who has not been part of a merger to be left out of buying stock in future rounds.  Though this can be mitigated somewhat, it does happen and is about the only reason not to rate this a 10 alongside Diplomacy)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Probably my all time favorite game. I played this game hundreds of times back in college. A true classis as long as it is played without hidden holdings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Classic Sid sackson design. A very worthy game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Acquire is a truly classic game. An experienced player will always beat a newbie which to me is the sign of a good game. It means that skill is rewarded and there is some depth to the game. However, the learning curve is not too steep and a new player will be competitive very quickly. With players of equal skill luck is often a large factor. To me, the key decision in the game is when to switch from assuring cash flow (selling your shares after a merger) to going for the majority in the final companies (trading in your shares 2 for 1 after a merger). In the beginning you need that cash because you simply must buy shares every turn. In the mid to end game however, you don't want to get locked out of the final large companies because the end game payouts can be huge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I do have one gripe with this game, and that is that the person who gets cash from the first merger CLEARLY has an advantage. Regardless, I have enjoyed playing this game and I'm interested in getting some more plays under my belt.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played my first game with honey and mom. Sigh, it gave my honey massive AP and my mom's words were, "I don't just hate it, I despise it." However, my honey said he liked it and so did I. It has an old-school feel, but is actually a well balanced game. An interesting mix of spatial skills, area control, and economics. Much more strategic than it first seems. I will probably like it more once I have a play were people don't bitch and moan the whole way through (that's right mom, I'm looking at you :/). I have the Hasbro version and yes, it is pretty ugly. However the cardboard is thick, everything is easy to see, and it all fits together well. So despite the color scheme obviously being created by a color-blind misanthrope - The components aren't actually poor quality (except for the tile holders... Seriously Hasbro, you couldn't spring for some rejected Scrabble holders?). In fact, I'd rather be forced to look at this board for a month than play even one more game of the Rio Grande version of Medici.

RATING: 7.8
A masterpiece.  Wonderful, wonderful game and the new edition is awesome.  What I think I like most about this game is the way the board evolves.  It is almost organic, but at the behest of the players, so if you study the players' moves, you can tell which way it is growing.  The game rewards you for paying attention.  Also, there is blocking by holding the tiles needed to merge until the company you have can be safe.  It's a cool game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If simplicity is the mark of genius, then Acquire is the meaty foundation of Sackson’s overwhelming claim to the title.  The players just do 2 things, place tiles and buy stock, but those 2 actions are the vectors onto a massive field of positional dominance on the board, for shares, even with their ability to generate mid game money.  But the real brilliance is that in a game ultimately about the value of mobility and timing in a speculative market just those 2 actions and handful of tiles give aggressive players the ability to manipulate the game, either to hedge a bet or to trick players into bad investments.  It is simple, smart, and very mean, but what’s more it is and will always be one of the watermarks of good game design so lucky for us it is so gosh darn fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best version of one of my favorite games. Glad I got it when it was still in stores, as I wouldn't want to pay the kind of money it's going for now... though I would seriously think about it! :)

RATING: 8
Great classic game that I only recently (re)discovered.  Over the years, I always figured it was slow and boring compared to other AH games and SPI wargames.  It is a true classic.

You'll need 1/2-a-game to figure out the general flow and feel, but it gets into high gear thereafter.  Easy to teach.  The production values of the latest version are pretty abysmal, but you can cobble together your own game support aids from BGG.  By all means, try to find colored chips to replace the paper money.  Your game will increase speed by a magnitude.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Build corporations and watch them merge by laying tiles while investing your limited funds in seven possible companies along the way.

Played as: 3,4,5,6 player

Pros: One of those simple but deep games where it takes 10 minutes to understand the rules and flow the first time but kind-of blows your mind after that. Thematically nailed it as the game starts out with a bunch of little mom and pop businesses running their own niche of the board and ends with one 'Walmart' conglomerate absorbing the 'competition'. Overall, a fast satisfying investment game that doesn't over complicate things. 

Cons: Mathy. Having to consult the reference card that's filled with all sorts of numbers then multiply this by how many that... it really can take away from the focus of the game. Not any significant interaction of note, probably the easiest to play in silence. The restrictive nature of the board and tile placement doesn't allow any real freedom to mitigate luck of the draw which is usually the strength of tile laying games. 

Other: Has that, "I want to play it because its challenging but not necessarily because it's fun" feel. I expected to like this game a little more then I did because I'm such a huge fan of tile-laying games. Being that that element of this game is so restricted, it almost doesn't even deserve that classification. As an investment game it's aces though so newcomers should expect that, and only that, to be the lasting draw of the game.

Best Use: A bridging game from non-gamers into something a little more gamer-y.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
After ~40 plays.  Classic.  An abstract with simple rules that harbors some kind of ineffable (sp?) magic.  Works amazingly well, but it's hard to say why.  With experience, I've found increasingly that the effects of chance are not nearly as strong as it used to seem they should be.  Newbies have little chance against experienced players, which for me is essential in a strategy game (it's a sign that there is a lot to learn about the game).  The recent AH edition is great; As is true for many games, I prefer using poker chips instead of the paper currency that comes with the game.

RATING: 10
Great Game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was my first stock game.  I enjoyed it on my first play and I think I'll always enjoy it since it introduced me to this type of game.

In acquire you are building up hotels (at least most versions call them hotels), and you are buying stock in those hotels.  At the end of the game you get to sell your stock back and see who has the most money.  Each turn you will add one tile to the board.  If the tile makes a new group of tiles you choose a hotel that isn't in play yet and add it to those tiles.  For starting up the hotel chain you get a free stock in that hotel.  You then are able to buy up to 3 stock in any company or companies that are on the board.  The value of the stock depends on the size of the company which is based on the number of tiles that make up the company.  At the end of your turn you draw a tile to bring your hand back up to 6.  The interesting part comes in with mergers.  If a tile is placed that attaches to two or more companies everything gets merged into the company with the most tiles.  It is very key to be involved in mergers in the beginning and you need to have stock in the company that is being dissolved.  Because the company going away will pay the majority and minority stock holders a handsome bonus, as well as giving those stock holders the option to sell, keep or trade up their stock.  This is important because mergers are the only time you can get more money.  If you run out of money for too many turns it is hard, if not impossible, to catch back up.

I give this a high rating because it is fun having to manage who has what stocks while everything is hiding.  There is a lot of tense decisions trying to decide which company you need to stay up with to keep some majority and minority holdings.  I couldn't go up to a 9 or 10 because there is one major flaw.  If you aren't lucky enough to draw any merger tiles you are at the mercy of those that do.  Sometimes this means companies that you need to merge in order to keep pace with everybody won't get merged.  This isn't a huge deal breaker because it doesn't happen all too often, but it does happen enough to cause some frustrations.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::star::star::nostar: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 4-5

RATING: 8
Classic game design that still holds up very well in the current modern board game scene.  How many games published in the early 1960s (or earlier) can make the same claim?

More subtle and strategic than the game might appear at first glance.  I underestimated the game, despite owning it, but not playing it for years.  So my loss.

Eurogame like mechanics in a game published in the 1960s and an influential design.  Likely the precursor to modern tile laying and stock holding games including the 18XX games.

RATING: 10
50 years old in 2014 (apparently Acquire was actually published in '64 despite the year on the 3M box).

Genius.  With four players this game just has a nice combination of flow vs. depth vs. game time.  Of course, I just play casually.  And I'm a Sackson fan.  I've always played public stock/private money.  I really don't get to play this as often as I'd like, luckily there are some nice AI versions that I've played a lot - unfortunately for me this doesn't seem to be helping my face to face play.

If you're new to Acquire or have an older edition and you don't know already, be sure to use the newer rules for discarding unusable tiles.

RATING: 7
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* THE granddaddy of all stock market games
* Muliple editions throughout the decades show its staying power
* Pure stock market mechanic rewards the bold and decisive, and punishes the safe
* Has a "rich get richer" feel, but fitting, as the successful will have more resources
* Good as the go-to stock market game, fans of high risk/high reward decisions
* Initial rating: [b]7/10[/b]

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played twice.  Tactical game of tile placement and stock purchasing; the mechanics are very interesting - players have a set of 6 tiles in front of them, one of which they must play at the start of their turn.  Corporations are groups of adjoining tiles, which can aquire other corporations when their tiles are merged.  Players can buy stock in corporations; the larger (more tiles) a corporation is, the more its stock is worth.  A very tactical resource management game that requires planning ahead, but which has a possibly frustrating amount of randomness.  Must play this more.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Pretty good stock exchange-investing game, although a few times I've run into situations where, even though I've invested in a few different companies, by other players' decisions, my companies stay on the board and overtake smaller companies.  While this may be good for the end game, when it happens near the beginning and I've run out of cash, it leaves me paralyzed the rest of the game without any means to make any money and get back on my feet.  Which makes for a very painful gaming experience.

Maybe that could somehow be avoided, I don't know, and it has only happened a couple times, so it's not the end of the world.  But it has left a little bit of a sour taste in my mouth.  Overall, a decent game if you don't mind a bland financial theme.

RATING: 8
Sid Sackson
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow!  Acquire first came out in 1962 and as far as I am concerned it is still kickin' ass and taking names.  I mean seriously, its a completely playable, enjoyable, strategic experience which comes in at under an hour.  On top of all that I'm willing to argue that its design easily competes with some of the best "Euros" to have come out in the past decade.

As a whole are Euro-style games the progeny of Acquire?  Most definitely.  If you can score a copy do so...and play it!  It doesn't even need to be one of the fancy-pants, Hasbro's Avalon Hill plastic goody editions.  Any will do.  You can probably score one of the but ugly versions for a couple bones.

If you like this game I would recommend Union Pacific and the 18xx series of games.  Union Pacific is very much an Acquire variant.  If you love Acquire you'll probably like UP.  If you are seeking something more 18xx games are *much* longer, more depthful, heavier on the rules, and perhaps only tenuously related...but they might scratch some similar stock-game itches.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Quick, tight 45 minute game of economic manipulation and prediction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Picked up two copies in shrink at 75% off at B&N. One for trade, one to keep, I suppose, though don't know if I will play it.

Previously traded away an old 3M version I found in town at a used bookstore.

...And now that I've actually played the game, I regret it.

Well, to be fair, the 1970's 3M was a bit warped, and the money and stock was on super-thin paper, so maybe not that particular version.

BUT I do regret not having played this sooner.

It was chaotic in the best way - it reminded me of surfing actually - you try to ride waves of change as companies merge, reform, and merge again, and your ability to mitigate and control this is limited to your own tiles. The game also seems to have plenty of nasty undercutting as players fight over who will control majority and minority shares.

My only complaint was that if you fall behind or hit a patch of bad luck with tile placement (either your own or that of the other players) it's almost impossible to catch back up.

Can't wait to play it again.


--------

edit, 6/13/08: every play of this game gets better. It's fast paced, it requires difficult decisions, it's random enough to keep me guessing and add some dramatic tension of the unknown, and it's never the same. Plays equally well with casual gamers and family (like my old mom and pops) as it does with serious gamers. It gets suggested and requested frequently around here. I STILL prefer Chicago Express, simply because I know, when I win it, it's because of my own strategy and choices, but this is a closing second. Might as well rate it a nine.

I'm willing but not anxious to try it again.

RATING: 5
It's okay for what it is. There's a big luck of the draw factor that prevents it from ever being more than a family game. The entire game boils down to the timing of the big mergers near the end of the game, and which player has the right tile to make the merger go his way. Draw the right tile at the right time and you can cruise to a win.

RATING: N/A
Acquired - November 2nd, 2007 - TF
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Acquire is a good economic stock holding game. Very much an abstract tile drawing game crossed with an economic engine with a stock market theme. I like the game but as I have only played a few times recently (outside of a solo learning game), I am still not able to fully pass judgment on it. It's easy enough to learn and play and there are enough small variances and tweaks you can employ in the rule set that you can make the game balanced for all (1st through 4th place majority/minority payouts, special 2 player rules etc.) yet I still need to play the game more to be certain that the luck of the draw factor will not make this game more luck filled than I like. It's always a bit disconcerting and unsatisfying when those you play with somewhat complain about a game because they feel it has too much luck in it. I don't mind luck in my games but this might be slightly over the line for a game masquerading as a strategic economic style game. Right now I'm rating this as a tentative 6.5. That could go up .. maybe even by a full 2 points or so once we settle in and explore the nuances of this game to see if luck can truly be overcome and the strategy of this game can be fully fleshed out. Experienced players likely already know the answer to this but the process of discovery in finding this out for ourselves is what makes boardgaming great and I do look forward to more sessions of Acquire.Update.. played a bit more and have upped my rating a full point to 7.5 based on some great game play and further discovery of some of the strategic/tactical nuances of the game. The rating may still go up after more sessions as I'd still like to play the game with the full range of 2-6 players to see if there is a "sweet spot" with a certain number of players. So far 3 players is definitely a little better than 2. Since we are still in the early stages of "exploring" the strategies in this game... I'm still cautious to rate it higher than 7.5 but I do think it does have room to climb further.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Acquire is a race to get as much paper money as possible by the end. Lucks plays a factor in the tile draw, but playing right tiles at the right moment keeps it from being all luck, I would advise groups to decide on open or closed info for money/stocks before playing. Woe betide the player who thinks it is buy low sell high. There is no way to just sell at will. It is a game of creating favourable mergers with a variety of players at the table to stop them catching up with you individually. Game is very simple yet deep enough to take seriously.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I got this in a second hand shop for 20 bucks. Very nice edition of a solid classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

RATING: 6.85

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a delight to play this very first "euro game". All the characteristics are there in a very simple and streamlined form: choose which tiles to place where to maximize your score and minimize that of your opponents, compete by acquiring just about more than your opponents, and balance between money for now or victory points for later. The only objection I have is the run-away leader problem if you get low on cash from the start (which happened to me, but the game was still fun). Why didn't I know about this game back in my Monopoly days?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Acquire is a good game that I'm happy to have in my collection.  I find that it is a great gateway game, especially for people who are interested in business or finance.  It is a tactically interesting game, with some tough decision making.  However, it does seem that sometimes the luck of drawing the tiles can be overpowering.  A good player will usually win, but not as often as in other games.  My other complaint is that in some situations, a player can be completely eliminated from the game early if they spend all their money and don't get a merger soon aftewards, whereas another player may luck into an almost undefeatable position.  A good game, but not without its flaws.

RATING: 9
Love Acquire.  Luck of the tile draw is apparent, but I have played many games where the outcome was always different from initial planning and conclusion.  The more players the better in my opinion.  

Game never gets old in my family.  Acquire gets the most game time.

We even have records:

I have the longest winning streak of 5

My brother-in-law has the highest accumulated dollar amount of $56,200
^Update: I snagged the new highest score of $58,500.
^Update: Brother-in-law has it at $58,800 now.

My sister has the lowest accumulated dollar amount of $13,000.  Update 04/27/2013, I 'acquired' the new all time low of $11,000. Gah!

#Note:  I believe the game is compromised on Acquire.net or any online site where the stocks are visible to all opponents. I wont play the game with that knowledge of stock ownership.

Session 09/04/09- Most amazing game I ever played for myself to win.  All won on a merge of a 3-tile Luxor when I had minority (1 share) to obtain money ($1500).  So I could purchase and hold onto majority shares in my 41+ Continental to win the game by $600.  I was broke most of the end game until the mentioned scenario.

04/23/10-  First time ever to see a tie for a win in a 5 player game.  Me and my brother in-law both hit a score of $41,300

Note: My group always plays this with closed holdings.

RATING: 8.5
I have the old Avalon Hill Version, and prefer it for it's classic nostalgic look and feel.  I also like that game producers had to change the hotel names, as the Luxor, and others were built after the original release of the game.

I like this game as a step toward strategic gaming for those who haven't played a lot of games.  People seem to relate to the buying and selling of hotels, and the visual board keeps people interested.  We play that stock and money are public, which increases player interaction.

A great, classic game.

Prospecting is very similar, and I like both for different reasons.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Acquire is an abstract strategy financial game from the 60's that still holds up today. Unlike Risk or Monopoly, there is no dice-rolling or player elimination. Visually it is not much to look at, so it may take a bit of persuading to get people to play such an old game. Also, at first glance, Acquire looks like it will be math-heavy, but it doesn't involve anything more than simple addition for the end-game total, everything else is just read off a chart. 

I'm glad I got a vintage edition of Acquire. The blinged-out Avalon Hill version from 1999 is pretty cool, but Acquire is still an old-school game that maintains it's old-school feel regardless of how modern the components may be.

Does have one gameplay issue: Inability for players to sell stock except during mergers can potentially lock up players' finances forcing them to sit out the rest of the game. A rare occurrence, but when it happens it sucks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Acquire is a game about stocks, hotels, and mergers.  A money game to the core, but fun and different from any game I have played thus far.  I can see the end of the game being a bit of a downer to someone who was not able to keep a stockpile of cash on-hand.  In the end, because there are not any more spaces left on the board for hotels to grow, many mergers and stock changes happen at the end of the game that players need to be aware of.

I would play this again, however I found the theme dry which does not appeal to, or excite me.

RATING: 10
[size=9][b][c]OVERALL REVIEW:     :star::star::star::star::star:[/c][/b][/size]
[size=8]Quick and easy to teach. Minimal setup and perfect game length. The components may look simplistic but the mechanics still feel fresh for a game that is over fifty years old.
[color=green]My favorite economic game[/color].[/size]

[size=9][c]RULES SIMPLICITY:   :star::star::star::star::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]First merger requires rule review, but during play only valuations are referenced[/size]
[c]QUICK SETUP:        :star::star::star::star::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Minimal setup to distribute player pieces and currency[/size]
[c]SHORT GAME LENGTH:  :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Depending on players, sixty-ish minutes[/size]
[c]MAXIMUM STRATEGY:   :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Press your luck deciding to merge or estimate long term value of shares[/size]
[c]MINIMUM LUCK:       :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Random tile draws but you choose when to play them[/size]
[c]PLAYER INTERACTION: :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]Every move is a direct action for and/or against other players wealth[/size]
[c]COMPONENT QUALITY:  :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Depends on version. Favorites are 1962 3M Wooden and 1999 Hasbro editions[/size]
[c]THEME INTEGRATION:  :star::star::star::star::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]You feel like a Mergers & Acquisition Manager investing and growing companies[/size]
[c]REPLAYABILITY:      :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]Random tiles and shifting player strategies create new results every time[/size]

[b][c]BEST WITH:[/c][/b]
[size=8]4 or 5 players[/size]

[b][c]MY PLAYS:[/c][/b]
[size=8]in-person with 3,4,5,6 players[/size][/size]

1960s Wooden tile edition:

[ImageID=1730514 small inline]

1999 Hasbro edition:

[ImageID=2582655 small inline]

Acquire was published in 1963 by 3M as part of its Bookshelf Games series. It has been popular among gamers and republished every since. Because of its age, simple components, and financial theme, many people pass over Acquire to play other games with more impressive playing pieces or colorful themes. As far as game design can be a science and an art, Acquire is a masterpiece. 

Each player starts with an amount of currency, and a random set of numbered tiles that only they can see. A player must place one of their numbered tiles on the corresponding empty space on the board grid comprised of lettered rows and numbered columns. If the player creates a contiguous set of three or more tiles on the board, a new company may be founded. If the player connects existing companies, a merger occurs, and the larger company acquires and dissolves the smaller company, with shares and cash payouts. One exception is that large companies above a specified number of tiles, cannot merge. As a final action, the player may purchase stock in any existing company on the board. 

[color=#3388cc][b]Why is Acquire such a good game?[/b][/color]

The brilliance of the game design is that early game play may favor tactical founding and merging small companies. The quantity and value of the different company stocks allows for wealth to spread amongst the players during this growth period.  But later game play requires the player to think strategically about investing in existing companies and being watchful of the growth of all companies and all players investments in the different companies and their values. Every single player's tile placement on each turn, can change company value and player investments. A player may choose to try to enrich themselves, but every other player can join and compete for majority. Players trying to maintain an even spread of shares will lose to the shrewder player who has the most shares of the most valuable companies.

A great article on the history of Acquire can be found here: https://opinionatedgamers.com/2014/05/29/how-acquire-became-acquire/

[color=#3388cc][b]Variations?[/b][/color]

We almost always play with the Special Powers variations, which arguably speeds the game up by about two turns when players activate single-use special powers to A) draw extra tiles or B) purchase more stock or C) play multiple tiles to the board, etc.

[color=#3388cc][b]Pimp it?[/b][/color]

You can get an opaque bag to hold tiles for selection, which allows you to avoid having to turn over all of the tiles on the table top. Originally, I had the 1963 plastic edition and have acquired a 1962 wooden edition, which I enjoy much better. I am considering the 1999 edition for the plastic hotels. There are many different hotel customizations people have made. Additionally, newer versions use corporations instead of hotels, and have corresponding customized stock certificates and/or currency.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Its impeccably crafted mechanism makes Acquire smooth as silk - good timing and control of the board areas are equally needed, the amount and price of the stock options are perfectly weighed for having a wide range of choices throughout the game, the strategy and tactics can change very much from one game to the next, and the draw of the tiles avoids predictability while not seriously influencing the outcome of the game. The topic might put off a bit (finance... what can you say), but a round of play is enough to be left craving for more.

After more than forty years it's still fresh as a daisy - current games might be more spectacular in concept and execution, but when it comes to elegance, depth and fluent gameplay there are only few matches for this. There's just nothing (rules or material) too much or out of place. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Brilliant game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Per essere un gioco degli anni sessanta, recentemente rieditato, è un ottimo prodotto. Graficamente si vedono tutti gli anni, ma le partite filano lisce regalando dinamiche interessanti e permettendo diverse strategie. Un buon gioco, senza dadi ne carte, dove non manca un pizzico di fortuna nella pesca delle tessere.

RATING: 7
This copy is the 1968 3M bookshelf version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I have to confess by being a little underwhelmed by this tactical classic. It's really only area-control in disguise, and the back-and-forth counting of share acquisition is nowhere near as engaging as - say - the placements in El Grande. The basic strategies are easily grasped, although it has to be said that the diplomacy and bluffing elements are immaculately preserved.

But fun? The jury's out.

RATING: 7
Other than chess, I've been playing this the longest. I have two copies of this game: a bookshelf edition and the big brassy Hasbro version.

This is a classic for all time. Everyone should play Acquire at least once to see where much of modern euro gaming originated. Even after all these year, it is a sturdy, engaging, and tense game. And it's cheap enough to obtain, that every game library needs a copy.

RATING: 8
This game is an excellent example of how a game might be considered "elegant."  There are very few rules, yet within the context of those rules a complex game arises.  This is the best "moneymaking" game I've ever played, and I seriously doubt I'll ever play Monopoly again thanks to this title.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Brilliant game. Elegance, strategy, tactics, table talk, brain burnage, and a short play time. This plays better with 4-5 than it does with other counts, but it's always fun.

This game is the shining example of how to make a game with big moments and an opportunity to fail. Too many modern games artificially keep things close. Acquire does just enough obscuring of the game state to make you usually not lose hope, while still allowing players to fail and fail spectacularly. Victory means so much more to me when a few big decisions I made would have cast be down far below where I finished.

I wish I could rate this an 11. We just started using the house rule that you must state what your company manufacturers when founding one. Hilarious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very good indeed. Simple yet engaging and exiting. With three that is, with more players chaos grow too much of a factor.

RATING: 10
[b]Acquire[/b] 

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10 -> 10)[/COLOR]

[i]I honestly don't have much more to say, every time I've played Acquire it has been a nail biter. It is a truly outstanding design, there is so much depth and nuance packed into such a simple/elegant design. No matter how many games you've played and how jaded you may be you should try Acquire if you get the chance. Acquire is one of the few games I've played that truly stands out and will indefinitely stand the test of time.

My only gripe is how awful the new FF reprint looks and they also changed the dimensions of the board, why?![/i] 

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

Excellent intro into stock market games. The perfect example of a game design that has a dead simple rule set, but a lot of strategic depth. There is also a lot of player interaction with the constant shifting of the board state. You need to pay attention to everyone at the table if you intend to do well. Can't wait to play this one more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
心得:
遊戲策略就是前期買小公司，能開公司就開公司
盡量在最有機會被併的小公司持股為最多或第二(分紅的金錢夠你繼續買股)
併購後股票看狀況轉股或繼續持有(沒缺錢不要賣)
遊戲中期如果有發現哪家公司有機會獨大
一定要快速想辦法成為該公司最大股東
靠買股或是小公司被併的轉股
股票張數有限，能夠成為第一就不用再買
規則:
*起始一人六千，每個人抽一個版塊放到版圖上，越靠近A1的就是起始，每個人在按抽六塊當初起始版塊
*股票跟金錢可以決定公開與否，但是剩下的股票一定是公開的
*放版塊 -> 買現有公司的股票(最多三張) -> 抽新版塊
*玩家可宣告遊戲結束一旦有一公司達到41塊規模，或是場上所有公司都11張以上，也可不宣告，最後每家公司會分紅利，且股票全變線，最多錢贏
*兩塊以上還未成立公司的版塊可成立一家公司，從還未成立的公司版塊挑，並擁有一張該公司股票(只要該公司還有股票)
*連結兩張公司的版塊，會讓公司合併(平手有放的人決定誰併誰，11塊以上的公司不能被合併，該版塊不能放)，被併購公司會拿到紅利(第一跟第二，兩個第一就把第一第二獎勵相加平分，兩個第二就把第二獎勵平分)紅利看被合併公司的規模，被併公司股票可此時選擇A保留B照併前價格賣出C兩張換一張併購的公司股票
*不能出的版塊可在回合結束時抽版前，棄掉一起重抽到六張
*兩人遊戲時，只要分紅利時就抽一塊版塊看上面的數字，當作第三位玩家的該公司持股數，然後再按擁有股票數分配紅利，最後記分也會

RATING: 6
This is the 1999 Avalon Hill edition with plastic tiles. I've not played this one much so everything is in very good condition and 100% complete.

The strategy seems to be mainly about chosing the best time to merge two companies, and picking investments that will give the best returns, using the information on your tile rack (the tiles that can create mergers or allow others to create mergers are the ones you want to be careful about).

Bought Spring 2005

RATING: 10
Excellent game.  This, not Monopoly, should be the world's best selling boardgame of all time.  Just another example of the sheer genius of Sid Sackson.  I play this more often than any other game, and the one I will introduce newbies to most often, as well.  Buy America...always.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Ahh, Acquire, why do I hate thee so. Because your destiny is entwined in being able to:
a) create companies and get the lead on other buyers in that stock (for majority bonuses) and 
b) being on the subsumed side of as many early mergers as possible to get cash to buy yet more shares.

Get less of these tiles than the other players and you sit there getting bored watching others reap while the sun shines. For a 90 minute game, I expect more than the opportunity to fall behind right from the start and watch the rich get richer.

Could seem boring to many folks, and you must keep track of the going rates of the corporations.  But so many awesome people have produced downloadable helps like scoresheets, and information cards to use with tokens for visual aids.  I dare you to try this game.

I actually want to own 2 copies of this:
- the 1995 version with the special powers variant
- a version with plastic or wood tiles. (I hope someday a version with skyscraper pieces).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Never the same game twice. You really need to keep track of what others are doing and whatever you do, don't run out of cash! You can play with open or closed hands, both work well. With open hands there is less memory and you can see exactly what the outcome of a merger will be, while with closed hands, you have to try and figure out or remember if you have majority, which you definitely want during a merger. If you get left out of early mergers it can be painful so there is some luck here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love this game. It would be vastly improved with some nice wood components. I've toyed with the idea of making my own set some night.

If you play with a smart crowd they will hold onto the tiles that give others a power play until the end of the the game. As such the endgame can become somewhat uneventful especially with higher player counts as it becomes obvious who is still in the running and who isn't.

Nonetheless, lots of tension and strategy, especially early and midgame.

3 players: Not ideal in my opinion. There are much better.
4-5 players: Awesome but probably best at 5 as there are better 4 player games.
6 players: Haven't done it much at this count but it seems a bit much for downtime and I feel like you don't have much control anymore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the first Euro-style games ever made, and still very good.  The careful balance you have to make between buying stock and intentionally ditching your stocks to get money again is difficult, and too-often leads to players with no actual options in the mid-game, so I've dinged it a few points for that... but it's still fantastic, and I enjoy every game of it that I play, even if I do terrible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really do need to play this more but it doesn't seem to appeal to many people. I can understand that it looks a bit dry (especially the edition I own) and I think because of it's age is pre-judged as inferior to modern games. The one time I played it I enjoyed it and can see it's potential.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Innovative and influential game by Sid Sackson. I was given this by my girlfriend, who used to play it with her brother and cousins in the 80s.  

It does suffer from two flaws: the game is unforgiving to poor strategy and/or poor luck of the draw.  I don't mind luck in games, but unfortunately this game has a true [b]run-away leader[/b] mechanic (positive feedback). It rewards the leaders with increased investment opportunities and punishes the laggards with few to no opportunities.  The feedback insures that if you are somewhat behind by mid game, you will almost certainly be MUCH farther behind at the end.

The other flaw is esthetic: [b]exponential inflation[/b] is built into the monetary system.  At the beginning you are counting out hundred dollar bills.  By the end you are counting out five thousand dollar bills.  It makes the game feel loose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Always fun and tense to the end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
avalon hill version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Widely regarded as one of the first board games with Eurogame sensibilities, Acquire is probably the father of all modern stock-holding games.  Players have a hand of tiles with coordinates describing where they can be placed on the grid board, and each turn they must place one.  Groups of adjacent tiles are considered to be hotel chains, and players can buy (but not sell) stock in those chains.  Tile placements can grow existing chains, create new chains, or merge chains--in this case, players owning the smaller chain can either trade in for stock of the bigger chain, or cash out.  Because cashing out is the one way to get money in the game, players generally want to be acquired so that they have a cash flow, though owning the monster chains can be very valuable at the end.  While I'm not the biggest fan of stock games, I certainly can appreciate this classic title.

(4 plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A really clever, simple stock manipulation game.  Way ahead of its time...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the games I have played the most (over 100 times if you include online play). Really good, although I've played it so much that a few problems are worth pointing out. One, it's difficult for new players not get destroyed without coaching. They will invariably make bad buys, fail to capture a majority or do so in isolated companies and run out of money and be forced to sit with a lost position with nothing to do. Two, it's pretty dry (despite the new snazzy looking pieces and designs). Three, requires heavy concentration (and card counting) if you wish to do well, yet doesn't always reward this as with more players the random element negates the benefits of planning to a degree. Four, can take up a good chunk of your evening to play, and you can be stuck for a lot of that time without a chance of winning. Five, ending can be anti-climatic (recommend you convert all your funds to $5k notes, and do a simultaneous countdown until the winner appears). These issues have come up over 25 years of playing. But we should all respect this strong Sackson title: it's been around in various forms for a LOOONNG time for a reason.

12/11/05: with some many other good Euros out there, I don't think this will come out too much in the future. Played it 20-30 times online recently, perhaps every couple of years I will get the bug, but there are other games I'd rather introduce and invest time in (PR, PoF, E
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Definitely one I need to play again. The board was impossible to read and the game was a bit dense initially strategy-wise. I bought too many shares of companies that didn't merge right away and I sat for almost half the game only placing a tile as I had barely any money or no money at all. Not the games fault, it was my dumb ass, but it made it less enjoyable than it could have been.

Still, the game was quite aesthetically pleasing even with the horrendously hard to read board.

RATING: 9
Simpler, faster and better strategy than Monopoly. Love the merger mechanic and trying to figure out which chains to buy stock in.

I like to use a variant where you just draw the next tile out of a bag and play it. It makes the game go faster. I feel the better part of the strategy is figuring out which stocks to buy and not which tile to place next anyway.

You still have to do the money changing and mental math as in Monopoly, and calculating the final tally at the end game is a bit tedious, but the thrill of the merger is way more fun than waiting for somebody to land on your property with a house.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fairly abstract but fun. Build one or more chains of hotels. The more they grow, the more the stock is worth. But to buy stock you have to have money, which you will get when your chain is merged into a larger one. So to win you will have to start new chains and hope to have them bought out.

Can get really tricky toward the end, when few tiles are left and you're hoping to draw that perfect tile while fearing that one of you opponents are holding on to it just to block you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Long considered a classic, yet I only read about it when I subscribed to Sumo in the late '90s. I bought the 1995 cardboard version with special power tiles, but it took some enthusiasm to finally play it (I thought the simple rules would make it a boring game). Myself and a few family members enjoyed the quick thinking person's "Monopoly".

Recently played again (with the plastic 2005 edition) and it shows its age compared with the Euros I've been fed for the past 5-6 years. It's interesting in trying to anticipate the mergers with some clues possibly coming from the other player's stock purchases. Unfortunately as a package it is an unforgiving design in regards to tiles drawn (I think I can say the last game with one quick corporation and merger help alot in my victory) and if cash strapped it can mean you are out, which is bad to sit through for 60 mins. Even the special powers don't seem to help. Also the cross refencing and working out the maths for share prices etc is abit of a hiccup in the proceedings and puts some players off. 

Sadly the grandfather of Euro's, it's time to retire. The merger system and share holdings has been superceded by Stephenson's Rocket (and Rheinlander).

RATING: 9
A great game with lots of choices. You must grow your properties, but too quickly you price your self out of the market. Mergers make you money but might help your opponents net worth more than you. However, mergers are necessary to get money to continue buying stock. If you get locked out your growth will stall, you may need to force a merger to keep buying stock. If you are too heavy in one company you will not get help growing it, so you would want to diversify, remember you don't always have to be first second can work as well. I find the number of options available fascinating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is one of the few games in which the mechanics themselves are evocative of the theme, which is surprising since the mechanics are so simple.

Despite the simplicity of the ruleset, there are things in the game that I consider as flaws:

* There are turns during which you have no meaningful decisions to make since you both might have useless tiles in your hand or there aren't any worthwhile shares to purchase (or can afford to purchase). I prefer games in which *every* turn you must make some meaningful choice.

* Significant money flow only comes from majority share holder bonuses. If you don't get any of these bonuses during the game, then you're pretty much screwed.

* Near the end of the game, players are counting the size of the larger hotel chains so they can calculate when the game's going to end. Counting about 30-40 individual tiles is annoying. This could be rectified by someone writing these values down, but no one bothers to do that, of course.

I own the all-plastic minimalistic and austere 3M version, which reflects the 1950s-1960s ethos better than the newest incarnation of the game (which I think has excellent artwork despite its flimsy components).

=====

Note that I don’t like area majority or influence games. I own two copies of this but I don’t particularly like this game; the pacing is just way too slow. I can’t stand having to look all over the board to see where my tiles could be played, nor do I like having to “wait” for a tile to appear in my rack. Perhaps this game just doesn’t work as well with three players (the most I ever played this game).

RATING: 7
acquire feels surprisingly fresh given how old the game is. my only real complaint is that this game seems to have the same problem that settlers of catan has, in that some players will be out of contention during the mid-game and will have to sit and play for 20-30 more minutes with no hope of winning. that's kinda sucky. despite this problem, acquire is way more engaging than settlers.

also, the monetary transactions are kind of fiddly. playing with chips instead of paper money would probably alieviate the tedium of buying and selling stocks during the game, and improve the pace of the payouts at the end. pretty neat and fun game though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game plays well enough and is still solid, especially given its age. The random drawing of tiles is typical for games from this time so it's understandable that it is here as well. It is often hard to plan for what to do as you do not know what tiles you will have to choose from. It is not uncommon for a player to get the perfect tile(s) and grow and merge as they seem fit while you need to buy and sell stocks to stay ahead of the market and not get caught selling low. A little too much luck involved in my opinion. The game is enjoyable, but there are others in this genre and that are similar that are more likely to make it to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have played this several times and I'm torn as to whether or not this is a good game.

This game offers a lot of opportunity for strategy.  Timing your moves is very important as is keeping track of what everybody else is doing.  It has that pure strategy trait where you have to predict what others are planning and plan your own moves accordingly.  It really becomes a match of wits.

Unfortunately, I find the tile-drawing mechanic destroys the strategy.  Just as a game of poker can be won by a lucky card in the river, so too can a game of Acquire be won or lost based on the turn of the tiles.  There is little you can do if you end up not getting critical tiles, while those who do get critical tiles can become very powerful as a result.

It's also easy to get yourself stuck early on and kill your entire game.  If you find yourself with no cash in hand and all of your investments become "safe" (or just aren't nearing being acquired), your turns will just be passes until something finally gets acquired.  In the mean time, you will be earning nothing while others pull far away from you.  It's easy to fall into this trap and it ruins the rest of the game for any player that finds themselves there. It's really boring to play when you can't play anything.

The play can also be quite slow.  Examining players' stocks and those still available, finding spaces on the board, counting the size of hotel chains and trying to calculate the worth of stocks all make for a time-consuming process.  Every decision is agonizing and can mean the difference between winning and losing.

And when it finally ends, the winner often isn't who you think it is.  It's difficult to judge who is winning just by looking at the piles of stocks and the sizes of hotel chains.  It makes it difficult to judge the state of the game and plan accordingly.  I've also found myself making Excel spreadsheets to help with tallying the final score because there are so many numbers involved.  It takes 5-10 minutes just to find out who won, at which point, people are already thinking about what game to play next.

With so many bad things to say about it, you would think I would rate it low, and yet it still offers a chin-stroking challenge and lots of opportunity for strategy.  Like a game of poker, you find yourself benefiting from these flaws just as often as you fall victim to them and I find myself driven to find a way to "beat" the game.

It's something different and it is certainly challenging.  Victory is sweet and it can feel great when everything goes your way.  As far as a fun, balanced, fulfilling game; I think there are better games to be had.  I don't recommend this game, but that doesn't stop me from playing it.  I only wish it could be tweaked to make it better. It suffers from many of the same problems as Monopoly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As they say, a classic.  Sid rules.

RATING: 8

RATING: 7
A reliable game.  Appeals to non-gamers as its simple sequence of play feels familiar.  However, first-timers invariably run out of money part-way through the game and miss out on a lot of the action.  This is really a strike against the game.  Even experienced players can, by chance, miss out on being in the first two mergers, and then end up side-lined for the rest of the game.  Don't play with 6.  I have the AH version with the bonus actions: they are actually quite good, and spice it up a bit without ruining it.  There are a few fiddly rules to prevent tiles locking up, but it is very simple and usually offers some thought and tension.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This Sid Sackson classic has taken many different forms over the years depending on the publisher. Each player strategically invests in businesses, trying to retain a majority of stock. As the businesses grow with tile placements, they also start merging, giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizeable bonuses, which can then be used to reinvest into other chains. All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks for current value or trade them 2-for-1 for shares of the newer, larger business. The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth.

I have the 1968 version which looks to play quite nicely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.18
A
Unknown Wins

RATING: 9

Played with open holdings for the first time and I'm now not sure which way I prefer - open or closed.

RATING: 8

The luck aspect, which receives too much criticism, mandates an evolving, flexible strategy throughout the course of the game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Another one of my recent top-100 tries that I would like to get a few more games of. Game play initially appears quite random, you draw tiles and place then on designated spots on a board. These start, expand, or merge hotel chains. At the same time you buy shares in the chains. Shares appreciate in value as chains get bigger but they also pay out bonuses if you have the majority holding in a company.

In fact it becomes clear that tile placement is a lot less random than it initially looks (you just can't see the patterns for your first couple of moves) though decisions on when to buy, trade, or exchange shares are a vital part of the game.

Definitely an interesting and challenging game, and potentially easy and fast enough to be playable with the family.

RATING: 5.5
(6/17/08) - Pozy.com strikes again. This is the 2008 reprint with the supposedly not-so-fabulous components. I had been looking to acquire a copy of Acquire (poor joke) for awhile now. A $20 price tag is fine by me as a way to get my foot in the door.

(3/22/09) - [8.5] - After playing a pair of 3-player sessions with Merph and Tim this weekend I find myself a huge fan of this game. I love the shameful manipulation of stocks a player must conduct in order to win. If you have the tile to merge a corporation, why not wait and buy a ton of the acquired corporation first in order to win a shareholder bonus? It's no wonder this game has stood the test of time.

(09/21/2014) - [5.5] - Unfortunately I find myself revising my Acquire rating by a three-point reduction. I think my group is much better at this game than I am. Getting wrecked every time has taken a lot of the fun away! With a group of fresh meat this is probably an 8.5 rating again.

SOLD (04/14/2017) - Acquire has been sold. I found it to be very enjoyable for a number of plays, but was ready to part with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Put Acquire on this side of the scale, Spades in the other.  The balance is about perfect!  The simplicity of rules, the uncomfortable tension of not knowing what your opponents will do, the card-counting and lapses of memorization,  the cursing/blessing of luck, the joy of realizing that you will reach your goal.  

So imagine Spades as a graphical novel, where the following story unfolds before your eyes: the Many Hands of Gods try to stir up a primordial soup, making bets with each other and maneuvering their favorite-tasting proto-organisms into the hungry mouths of other proto-organisms.  The organisms in the protoworld grow and evolve, and what starts out as a fairly egalitarian society later contains a few dinosaurs that can menace others, though considerable tension occurs when equally-matched dinosaurs come into contact.  In addition, the Gods go through a maturing process over the course of a game: the young, immature Gods worry over short-term gains, like hungry dogs; by midgame, they are more maturely wondering about the longer-term future, and their behaviour changes as such.  Can you imagine all of this in a game with a ruleset and mental requirement no greater than Spades?

I find the Chuckles Variant the best:  closed holdings, but any time during your turn, you may ask one of your opponents how much stock they own of a particular company.  Only one question can be asked per turn.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
Classic stock and mergers game. I generally prefer playing with stock revealed since I'm not a fan of memory mechanics in games. If you get some good draws early in the game, you can create a gap from the other players that is hard to make up. The tile placing is a little restrictive, even with a large hand of tiles. It's easy to sit on a tile someone else desperately needs, or continuously draw tiles that don't help you. 

To me, two things really make this game tense and interesting: the majority and minority shareholder bonus. Do you diversify trying to get a minority bonus in several companies, risking not getting a bonus at all, or focus on majorities in one or two companies? With the semi-random development of the board, you have to take gambles on which companies are going to grow, and which to take a pass on.

It is a little too easy for someone to run out of cash, and not able to get more for extended periods of the game. The luck of the draw can basically knock someone out of the game if the company they invested their money in doesn't merge, since that is the only way to get more money. I've seen people locked out of the game for several turns not able to do anything but play tiles to help others. While this can be prevented most of the time, sometimes it is just the luck element of the game biting you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Sheer luck can win this game. But it's rare. It rewards planning, watching your opponents moves and trying to figure out exactly why they made it. Are they trying to buy into something you own because they think it'll grow, or because they want to merge it into a larger hotel to help gain share. Watch you money, having none is a very bad thing when a prime opportunity comes along.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
----------

This isn't a stock market game.  Sure, you have stocks, but there isn't really any market simulation going on:  stock prices don't rise/fall with demand but are instead a bi-product of company size... which is too much of an abstraction on the stock market for the game to fit inside that category.  That being said, I don't care.  I love the competition surrounding the majorities/minorities in the hot prospects and then trying to get your majorities/minorities merged.  But the tension is high and the game offers plenty of decisions for its relatively quick play time.

I actually like the randomness of the tile draw; this allows the game to unfold somewhat differently each time.  Sure, sometimes luck will play a factor in the outcome, but it's not a game-breaker by any means (some of my friends would strongly disagree).  

I really enjoy this one.

----------
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This Game is quite fun for being so old. This game is more family oriented and  I can easily get my kids to play this one. RATING: 6
I picked the new edition of aquire up because it was cheap and recommended by my local FLGS as i was buying agricola.

This game is MUCH better than agricola.

The mechanics are absurdly simple.  Play a tile, buy some shares.  The rest of the game is procedural, save for some decisions on what to do with stock after an aquisition.

That said, the game can be tense and laid back at the same time.  Tense as you pay attention to what everyone is buying(knowing who has stock where is a key to victory) and laid back due to the groans and cheers of the inherent randomness.

Must have for any collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I first came into contact with Acquire many years ago when I bought the 1998 Avalon Hill edition used for a price that is well under what that version of the game sells for now.  I read the rules, determined that it must be the most boring game ever, and sold it right away without playing it.  What a mistake.

This year, as a far more mature gamer, I decided to give Acquire a second chance and bought a used 2008 edition for a few dollars.

I loved it from my first play.

Yes, there is randomness in the tile draws, and you can find yourself out of a game through getting cut out of some big mergers, but few games build tension like this classic.  Never going out of my collection.

RATING: 7.3
The second game I was interested in after Learning Catan
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I have only played the new Avalon Hill (HasBORG) Edition. This is a tile laying/area influence game. The tiles have a number and a letter that denote where it can be played. Each tile only has on playable space on the board. Sometimes this can be frustrating, as you wait and wait and wait for the tile you need to be played. Although, you should be buying stock and anticipating other mergers to be happening while you wait. When two or more tiles are adjacent, and don't already have a corporation for them, the player who made laid the second tile down can assign this grouping of tiles a corporation, and recieves a free stock in it. There is a limited number of corporations, so starting them early on is a plus. If able, saturating the board with corporations early on, thus recieving a free stock in all you start, opens up alot of options for everybody and really stretches players thin. On the flipside, if there are only 1 or 2 corporations on the board for to long, then all the players are vying for control of those, and its hard to get ahead and becomes repetitive. After a player places a tile, then he has the option of buying stock. Only [b]3[/b] shares of stock. Whether they be from the same, or from different corpoations, 3 is the limit. It is this limit that really taxes the brain. Do you spread thin and hope you can get a piece of action from at least a few of those, or try to be strong in one, and weak in another. There are only 25 shares in each corporation, with the first share going to the player that started it for free. This allows a observational player to gauge who has how much of what, and determine if it's worth it to invest in a corporation, considering how likely it is to be bought out soon, and whether or not he'll make any money out of it, taking into account how useful his tiles are to which corporation's chance to grow or die. It is a good idea to hold the majority in at least 1 corporation during the game, winner usually has majority or, at least, minority in one of the last surviving corporations at the end of the game. When a tile is placed so that it joins 2 or more corpoations, then they merge. The corporation that has more tiles before the merger with incorporate the other, adding its tiles to itself. Everyone who had stock in the bought-out corporation recieves a payout, with the amount depending on the size of the bought-out corporation. With the Max amount going to the majority holder, and half the max amount going to the minority holder. Then the individual shares can be sold for their going rate (which also depends on the size of the bought-out corporation), or traded at a 2-1 ratio for shares in the larger, still active corporation. Trading up is usually a better idea, because shares for that corporation would usually be alot more that the selling cost of the dead corporation, considering the size of the new active corporation. All in all, this is a game that is really easy to teach to newbies, and has a deep strategy to keep veteran players interested. Elegance, with a random keep-you-doubting-and-hoping mechanic at its simplist and best.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Players invest their money in stocks.  The value of the different holdings depends of the number of companies that they control in a grilled board.  If holdings touches each other the bigger one absorbs the other, so the value of stocks gets higher, and the price for being the first and second stock holder too.  This is a good game, with some nice decisions and strategies.  Being absorb is as good as absorbing, cause it gives you valuable money that allows you to get some other stocks.

RATING: 6

Although I think the game is overrated, I admit there was a time (early 1990s) that it was one of my very favorite games.  Now there are just too many other better games of its length and weight that get my playing time.

Sid Sackson's finest achievement only seems to get better with time.  Simple choices. Not TOO heavy on the strategy, but far from brainless.  Plotting your moves, trying to count cards and remember who has what stock positions, trying to perfectly time your mergers to extract every last penny from the majority bonuses, only to have you plans foiled by opponents playing their mergers ahead of your schedule.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Acquire mixes a need for both short-term and long-term strategies very well: The winner almost always has a good balance of both. There is a decent amount of luck involved so that new players can certainly be in the hunt if they get the right tiles while experienced players can't completely blame a loss on the tiles they get, though that would be a factor. Most importantly, the game is a lot of fun. It's a great feeling to see your long-term hotel(s) get larger and larger thus making their stock prices rise and maybe even a better feeling to cash in on the bonuses when your smaller short-term hotel(s) gets acquired. Wonderful game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game. It has stood the test of time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of those games where you sit there and stare at a board.  Not really my thing, but this game is quite elegant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A downright addictive game with a good deal of randomness, but not so much that long term strategies are impossible. Deducing the intentions of your opponents is advisable. Some tough decisions sometimes have to be made. The game gets more tactical in the second half, and the decisions get tougher. There is a bit of a press your luck aspect near the end re: keeping shares after a merger and hoping to re-start a company before someone else does and before the game ends.  Best to play it with shares & money hidden. Too much analysis paralysis otherwise. If you are good at keeping track of things in your head, then you deserve the slight advantage it gives you when playing this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So simple, yet so deep!! Very easy game to teach then everyone is amazed by its depth. The best gateway game along with SoC & TTR, yet it doesn't get old as easily.

RATING: 9
Wow.  I can't believe it took so long for me to play this.  It is nearly perfect in its simplicity.  You place a tile and buy shares, but by the end of the game, you are scrambling to be the majority shareholder and hoping your company gets bought by another company.  The ONLY thing that keeps this from being a 10 (even on one play) is the fact that it has an illogical bit about not being able to sell stocks unless the company gets merged.  Aside from that (VERY) minor quibble, this game is fantastic and immediately goes into my top 10.

RATING: 9
Have been playing this game since I was about 6.  What a game.  Only thing that keeps this from being higher is that now I really only play 2P, which is nice, but needs tweaking (we play 1 less piece in hand and 1 less chain on board - forces playing pieces you dont want to).  3P i think is where this game shines.  Enough for all, yet not too crazy.  5P results in too much chaos i think.

It's just not fun playing a game where I'm not really going to factor except as a spoiler / kingmaker.

RATING: 9
[COLOR=#663300][b][size=11]Acquire[/size][/b][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#663300][i]Note: My numeric ratings disregard BGG's associated verbal descriptions.[/i][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#006600]Version played: [/COLOR]1976 Avalon Hill
[COLOR=#006600]Play History: [/COLOR]
 [COLOR=#006600] • 3 players: [/COLOR] Several times
 [COLOR=#006600] • 4 players: [/COLOR] Many times
 [COLOR=#006600] • 5 players: [/COLOR] Many, many times
 [COLOR=#006600] • 6 players: [/COLOR] A few times

[COLOR=#006600]Instructions: [/COLOR]Must evaluate.
[COLOR=#006600]Learning Curve: [/COLOR]It has been so long since I learned the game that it's hard for me to evaluate the learning curve.  I think it's fair to say that it only takes a few turns to pick up the basic play, and the possible moves per turn are relatively easy to identify.  That said, it takes at least a full game to appreciate how the values of actions evolve over the course of the game.  And of course, learning the nuances takes several plays.
[COLOR=#006600]Depth: [/COLOR]Middling.
[COLOR=#006600]Luck: [/COLOR]I've heard complaints that the tile draws bring too much luck to the game, but I've played this game enough to know that good play outweighs luck.
[COLOR=#006600]Downtime: [/COLOR]Not an issue.
[COLOR=#006600]Fiddliness: [/COLOR]Low.
[COLOR=#006600]Components: [/COLOR]The pieces in the 3M and early Avalon Hill versions are quite sturdy.
[COLOR=#006600]Player Interaction: [/COLOR]High
[COLOR=#006600]Conflict: [/COLOR]Indirect at worst (e.g.: preventing a merger which would benefit an opponent).
[COLOR=#006600]Theme: [/COLOR]The tile placement is a rather abstracted representation of the growth of hotel chains, but the purchase and liquidation of stocks is straight-forward enough.

[COLOR=#006600]Travel related: [/COLOR][COLOR=#CC0000]Unsuitable.[/COLOR]
 [COLOR=#006600]• Size: [/COLOR]Medium.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Weight: [/COLOR]Medium to heavy.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Table Required: [/COLOR]Yes.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Footprint: [/COLOR]Large.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Component Trackability: [/COLOR]Poor.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Replaceability: [/COLOR]Difficult to replace this edition.

[COLOR=#006600][b]Comments: [/b][/COLOR]

I played Acquire every week, with few exceptions, from late 1990 through early 2005.  Our group was a total of five players and we typically played two games of Acquire every game night.  My point?  This game has replayability.

Our group found the 1960's versions of the game much more functional than the 1999 Avalon Hill (Hasbro) edition, hence the higher rating for this edition.

For his geeklist titled "[geeklist=34548]Short Interviews With Each Person Who Has The Most Recorded Plays of Each of the Games Ranked 51-100[/geeklist]" James Fehr ([user=fehrmeister]fehrmeister[/user]) asked me a few questions:

[i]What do you like the most about Acquire?[/i]

Hmm. All the features I can think of aren't really specific to Acquire. Random tile-draws provide replayability as well as the potential for both good and bad luck. (Yes, I think luck is a good thing. Responding to players' deliberate moves can foster only so much adaptability.) The shared gameboard means that players' actions impact subsequent gameplay for everyone. Tactics and strategy are rewarding, but not to the extent that newbies can't play successfully with experienced players.

[i]What do you currently rate this game (from 1 to 10)?[/i]

I have an odd dichotomy of thought on that one. I consider it one of the greats (perhaps as high as a 9), but I don't actually want to play it. Let me be clear: I did not burn out. I still enjoy the game and I'll happily play if that's what the group wants. The thing is, we own so many games (many of them unplayed) that it's hard to devote time to a game we've already played so frequently for so many years.

[i]Do you think you'll be playing much more of it in the future?[/i]

In the near future, not much. But I hope that our retirement years will be spent playing and playing and playing our favorites. Acquire is definitely on the list.

[i]Why do you think this game is so replayable? In other words, what keeps you from getting bored with it after so many plays?[/i]

Answering that is like answering why I like to play board games. I can point to various qualities of games, but it really comes back to some ineffable personal affinity. For all the years we played, I found Acquire somehow simultaneously engaging and comfortable. It's important to mention that our gaming group was committed to Acquire Night. It was rare for any of us to miss a session. This meant we didn't have to worry whether there would be enough people, and since this group didn't play any other games, we didn't agonize over which game we would play. Our Acquire Night was spent in companionable gameplay.

[COLOR=#006600][b]Why we own it: [/b][/COLOR] 

This game is not only a classic; it's a classic that we enjoy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
[COLOR=#663300][b][size=11]Acquire[/size][/b][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#663300][i]Note: My numeric ratings disregard BGG's associated verbal descriptions.[/i][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#006600]Version played: [/COLOR]1999 Avalon Hill
[COLOR=#006600]Play History: [/COLOR]
 [COLOR=#006600] • 3 players: [/COLOR] Several times
 [COLOR=#006600] • 4 players: [/COLOR] Many times
 [COLOR=#006600] • 5 players: [/COLOR] Many, many times
 [COLOR=#006600] • 6 players: [/COLOR] A few times

[COLOR=#006600]Instructions: [/COLOR]Must evaluate.
[COLOR=#006600]Learning Curve: [/COLOR]I think it's fair to say that it only takes a few turns to pick up the basic play, and the possible moves per turn are relatively easy to identify. [COLOR=#006600]Depth: [/COLOR]Middling.
[COLOR=#006600]Luck: [/COLOR]I've heard complaints that the tile draws bring too much luck to the game, but I've played this game enough to know that good play outweighs luck.
[COLOR=#006600]Downtime: [/COLOR]Not an issue.
[COLOR=#006600]Fiddliness: [/COLOR]Low.
[COLOR=#006600]Components: [/COLOR]The 1999 Avalon Hill (Hasbro) edition may be pretty, but our group found it less functional than the 1960's versions, hence the lower rating for this edition. Not only are the plastic pieces so thin that they can be accidentally broken, but the colored hotel chain markers are so tall they block the view of tiles beyond them.
[COLOR=#006600]Player Interaction: [/COLOR]High
[COLOR=#006600]Conflict: [/COLOR]Indirect at worst (e.g.: preventing a merger which would benefit an opponent).
[COLOR=#006600]Theme: [/COLOR]The tile placement is a rather abstracted representation of the growth of hotel chains, but the purchase and liquidation of stocks is straight-forward enough.

 [COLOR=#006600]• Footprint: [/COLOR]Large.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Component Trackability: [/COLOR]Poor.

[COLOR=#006600][b]Comments: [/b][/COLOR]

I played Acquire every week, with few exceptions, from late 1990 through early 2005.  Our group was a total of five players and we typically played two games of Acquire every game night.  My point?  This game has replayability.

Our group found the 1960's versions of the game much more functional than the 1999 Avalon Hill (Hasbro) edition, hence the higher rating for this edition.

For his geeklist titled "Short Interviews With Each Person Who Has The Most Recorded Plays of Each of the Games Ranked 51-100" (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/34548) James Fehr (fehrmeister) asked me a few questions:

[i]What do you like the most about Acquire?[/i]

Hmm. All the features I can think of aren't really specific to Acquire. Random tile-draws provide replayability as well as the potential for both good and bad luck. (Yes, I think luck is a good thing. Responding to players' deliberate moves can foster only so much adaptability.) The shared gameboard means that players' actions impact subsequent gameplay for everyone. Tactics and strategy are rewarding, but not to the extent that newbies can't play successfully with experienced players.

[i]What do you currently rate this game (from 1 to 10)?[/i]

I have an odd dichotomy of thought on that one. I consider it one of the greats (perhaps as high as a 9), but I don't actually want to play it. Let me be clear: I did not burn out. I still enjoy the game and I'll happily play if that's what the group wants. The thing is, we own so many games (many of them unplayed) that it's hard to devote time to a game we've already played so frequently for so many years.

[i]Do you think you'll be playing much more of it in the future?[/i]

In the near future, not much. But I hope that our retirement years will be spent playing and playing and playing our favorites. Acquire is definitely on the list.

[i]Why do you think this game is so replayable? In other words, what keeps you from getting bored with it after so many plays?[/i]

Answering that is like answering why I like to play board games. I can point to various qualities of games, but it really comes back to some ineffable personal affinity. For all the years we played, I found Acquire somehow simultaneously engaging and comfortable. It's important to mention that our gaming group was committed to Acquire Night. It was rare for any of us to miss a session. This meant we didn't have to worry whether there would be enough people, and since this group didn't play any other games, we didn't agonize over which game we would play. Our Acquire Night was spent in companionable gameplay.

[COLOR=#006600][b]Why we own it: [/b][/COLOR]

RATING: 8
one play

I have fondness for stock market games and this one pleasantly surprised me, being different, vintage even. Maybe closest one could get to enjoying the ride in stock market games as there's just enough randomness (I love chaos) and interesting speculations roaming above the heads of the players. Didn't feel like incentive partnership type affair, but closer to traditional capitalist feel of being in it for oneself and trying to sniff out what the future will bring and what those other bastards are up to. Merger mechanic is unique (for me) and deciding what to do with outdated stocks is still (an intriguing) mystery to me. 

My problem right now is that the version I've played (AH big ass plastic edition) is oop and ridicolously priced, whereas in print version seems the most inferior of them all. [i]Help! I need somebody. Help! Not just anybody...[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Do not take my rating wrong. This is a good game but I lean towards games with more theme. To be honest any sort of "Business/Economics" type game instantly loses 1 to 2 points in my ratings.
