=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Played twice with 4P, with a two-year span between games. The groups I have played Acquire with have found its concept rather difficult to grasp. Perhaps it is because we have a very remote understanding of the business world, but it makes little sense to expand a corporation in hopes that it will be acquired, or to be unable to sell stocks until the corporation is acquired.

However, Acquire performs quite well on its own economic terms. In essence, this is a game of balancing between getting stocks in corporations which will be eventually acquired, and stocks in predicted 'safe' corporations. (Or at least, that's what I think.) The one thing that irks me is the luck of the draw in the tiles. Getting money from early mergers seems to be rather valuable, but if your tiles give no indication which company may be acquired, then the expansion of corporations is at the mercy of your opponents. In many ways, Acquire plays like the inverse of [thing=90419][/thing] – the expansion of companies is semi-random, while the acquisition of stocks is fully decided by the player.

Nevertheless, Acquire is a rather fascinating classic title. It has met a less-than-lukewarm reception from the people I have played with, which is a pity because this is a game which requires a play or two for it to make sense.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2014: 8. This was the first "real" boardgame that I ever played, and while I haven't played it in ages, it still holds a special place in my heart.

2016: 8. Have played the game a few times lately, and it still holds up against modern stuff.

P:3-6
Best: 4-5?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[82 plays] Sid Sackson's classic work, a pioneering game that can play quickly and tensely with any good gaming group.

We were playing and enjoying the old 3M bookcase version of Acquire a decade or more before any of us had heard of "German" games. It was one of the first games that revealed to some of us that there were some really nifty games out there besides the wargames we knew.

I have played enough Acquire to realize that there is some amount of skill and tactics required to put yourself in position to win if fate smiles upon you, but that ultimately a good player has absolutely no control over the lucky twists of fate that will occur at key moments in the first 2/3rds of the game.

Most recent plays 6-12-05, 12-10-06, and then 2-8-09. Jerry, Ben, Mindy, Garrett, and Barb. Most recently 11-26-10 in KC with Steve, Barb, Jerry, Vallie, and Garrett.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Old AH Bookshelf edition off Ebay.com.au. Finally.

A classic for good reason. Players are putting chips onto a board to build hotel chains. Money is used to buy shares which are then sold for money and worth $$$ when small chains are bought over.

Not very heavy but it's a classic case of 'too much to do' 'too little money/actions' to do it. Sackson is genius.

RATING: 9

This game works even with new to board game people but has a simple depth that allows for seasoned gamers to enjoy the game again and again.  A true classic in the board game community.
------------------------------------------------------------Jan 2017 - it may be old but it is still the best pure economic game out there.  Simple Rules, Simple Setup, Simply Fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Splendid, elegant game that was way ahead of its time. Even after all these years, I can't think of a game in the same niche that compares to Acquire. The way that stocks become desirable just because other people are buying them is a pretty realistic simulation of actual investor behavior. It's disappointing that Hasbro wasn't willing to invest in plastic pieces in the latest version of this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
By far and away, quite simply my favorite game. Period.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
This game is less luck-driven than I had originally thought.  Having the right tile at the right time is of course very helpful, but there's more to it than just that.  Acquire is older than I am, and it still puts most newer games to shame.  It's also a great gateway game in my experience.

*****

I've played this quite a bit recently at www.gethostile.com.  Believe it or not, the best player does actually seem to win the majority of the time.  Really bad luck can ruin you every once in a while, but you have more control over your fate than you may think.  Focus early on getting at least minority control in corporations near each other and ignore lone corporations by the edge of the board.  And sometimes it's better to just hold on to your money early on if it seems like that first merger may not come any time soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

IMO best played with four.

RATING: 7
Reviewed on Mounted Cloud
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent game; I can see why this one has stayed in print for so long.  Great decisions to be made every round.
----
This game delights several of my sensibilities.  First, it's a game of stock and money management.  You buy the stock certificates, and by adding to the corporation, the value of the certificates increases.

Second it's a tactical game where a player has to make a determination by the tiles held as to whether to buy further into a chain if it can be merged, or to make that merger, or to continue to grow a small corporation so that it goes safe and cannot be merged (especially if opponents are holding quantities of stock in that corporation, and would benefit greatly from it merging out).

Third, I love the whole nature of the stock majorities -- a player has to keep a little bit of a mind about what the other players are holding, but only to the point that that player wants to be one ahead of all the other players in order to claim the majority shareholder bonus when that stock merges. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Definitely a fun game. Can go long if played with AP (analysis paralysis) people. Love the mergers mechanic. Also, this game is actually quite thematic to me, believe it or not. I know it really shouldn't be, as it is quite abstract to look at, but with all the money and the mergers and the cool buildings (if you have the Avalon Hill Hasbro '99) and the old school feel of the stocks, I really feel like a major mogul looking down from a thousand feet on the city that i'm trying to utterly dominate. 

There is surely a luck driven mechanic of picking tiles, and that does bug, but it's not too bad.

good stuff -   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game of speculation.  The board is a grid, from 1-A to 12-I.  Players have a "hand" of 6 tiles that can be placed where indicated on the grid.  On your turn, you simply play a tile and purchase up to three shares of stock in one of 7 hotel corporations.  If a tile is played that connects orthogonally to another single tile, a hotel corporation has been created (or resurrected).  If a tile is played that connects two corporations, a merger occurs.  The smaller company is absorbed and its stockholders cash in or trade their stock.  The goal is to maximize stock holdings in corporations that you control the fate of (using your hand tiles) or speculate in other corporations.  Most money wins.  
3p game is not worth it, as one player always eats it early.  6p is too chaotic.  5 is best, but 4 isn't bad.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I own the last edition printed by Avalon Hill

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
So many games have taken elements of Acquire. Yet in many ways, none have surpassed it. Unlike derivatives like Airlines Europe, this can be a brutal, cutthroat game, and it's incredibly tense. Often you know what you want to do but you can't quite do it on your turn. So you wait, watching anxiously as others change your plans--or not. Most of the game is like this. There's so much tension that the end of the game can be downright cathartic.

I got killed on my first play, completely cut out of contention early on, but that's not a dealbreaker for me. I'm glad I persisted with another play because I fared much better the second go around. Winning is satisfying. There might be a bit too much randomness in the tile draw, but there's a lot of subtlety to the strategy. It's an excellent design, all the more astounding given its age.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I can certainly see why Acquire considered by many to be one of the best-ever American board game designs. A true classic that seldom disappoints.

Gateway rating: 7

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've discovered that I'm really "new school" when it comes to my board games.  Except for Boggle (and a couple Chess boards and a novelty version of Yahtzee), this is the oldest game I own by more than 30 years.

It's very watered down for my usual tastes.  Gameplay consists of playing tiles on a board to start, expand, or merge hotel chains.  Then you buy stocks, trying to predict which ones will grow so you can buy as low as possible and sell them for huge profits by the end of the game.  The player with the most money at the end wins.

I think this game is certainly better with more people.  It can accommodate up to 6 and that may be too many (I've never played with that number) but with 3 or fewer it is too easy to run away with the game.  More players offers more competition and gaps between your turns and dilutes the available stock.  With three you can see what tiles you have available and buy up huge amounts of stock early before other players have time to react and attempt to thwart your plan or prevent you from a big pay-out.

I've enjoyed Power Grid and have intended on playing a deeper economic game for some time but this certainly isn't it.  This is much more shallow an experience although it does play reasonably quickly and may fill a shorter time slot if players are looking for a quick buy and sell stock game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
Love this game.  I would play this any time, any place.  My kids are also very good at this.  I love the simplicity of the rules and the depth of the game.

RATING: 8
A true classic, which I'm glad to have in my collection. It may be a bit dated compared with recent offshoots like Union Pacific and Stephenson's Rocket, but still holds its own. The luck of the draw doesn't really bother me, as there are many ways to circumvent bad draws with clever play. By the way, I'm firmly on the open holdings side. Closed holdings only introduces unnecessary AP, as players struggle to remember who has what.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[3M 1971 Bookshelf Edition] {Hotel business; stock holding, tile-laying; optimal 4-6p} Acquire is a vintage stock speculation game.  To me, it is the masterpiece of Sid Jackson. Acquire is quite unforgiving and takes some time to master. It's great in the old time but it's still good in current gaming world.  It is quite abstract and opaque, which may not be fun for some players.  Nevertheless, it's a first-rate game which provides different strategies and lots of player interaction.

It needs a good strategy to develop a stock. The decision each turn is clear if a player has a definite plan to make money. Besides, maintaining a good cash flow is very important in this game; therefore players should be ready for quick merges, in addition to develop stocks. There is some luck in tile draws but it can usually be countered by wise moves (There are 6 tiles in a player's hand. Unless he has really bad luck, it's not usual that he has all useless and unfavorable tiles).

[Variant] If your game group extremely hates luck, you may use a variant to reduce the luck: when drawing a tile, a player draws 2 tiles, keeps 1 for himself and return the other to the supply. I don't think this variant is necessary, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
After reading the rules I wasn't sure what all the fuss was about. It seemed rather mechanical and dull. After playing the game, now I see. The way the different elements combine is where the true game lies. I wanted to immediately play again.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
 2 points for the "game emeritus" status.  I guess the two things I took away from this game are:

1.  It's an outstanding design in the context of its time.  Given the level of game designs that were its contemporaries, this is a really interesting game.

2.  Having said that, it's now a dated game.  I played this right after playing a game called Arkadia, and all I could think while playing Acquire is just how many decisions were being taken out of my hands by the tiles that were drawn.  The good Eurogames avoid throwing these huge curveballs at you based on randomness and allow the system to evolve its own complexity with almost everything out in the open.  If I get a smattering of tiles that are around the edge of the mapboard at the beginning, or otherwise away from the first 3-4 companies that get formed, I'm in trouble through no fault of my own.  And these days there are games that have all the fun of Acquire in terms of calculating payoffs, reading other's behaviour, etc. and don't randomly screw you that way.  So why would I play this one?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A great light strategy game that works well with non-gamers.  Interesting decisions to be made trying to balance long-term objectives (projecting which company will be the biggest by game end and investing there, but getting no immediate payoff) and short-term pressures of needing money (investing where takeovers are likely to occur in the short-term so that you can get a boost of funds).  One glaring weakness though (in desperate need of a house rule to fix) is the situation where someone runs out of money (due to bad luck) and can do nothing while another player gets lucky (through a random tile draw) and has one of his companies acquired, giving him the money to continue purchasing stock.  That player then vaults ahead quickly and end game result becomes fairly predictable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Finally got this to the table, was pretty hard seeing all the component rich competition.

However, the game was really fun. We had one chain in the end completely dominating the table but all of us could already see the different ways of strategy to win this game.

As for play it is a mix between spatial tile laying and a stock game. However, the last is absolutely prevalent. Try to 'buy in' to the right chains and try to have others do your work. And know when to keep and when to sell stock. You don't want to run low on money!!

Great game, in the end we finished with just $100 difference with scores of the top players ranging in the 50K.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'd feel mildly positive about playing this again, hence a 6. On the good side, there is a good expansion mechanic and even better stock ownership system that allows you to purchase more. The rules are clean, the mechanics are not over wrought, so it's quiet professional.

The biggest shortcoming is the timeframe. It is too long (2 hrs for 5 of us, mostly newbies) for what it very tedious at times. And there's not enuf excitement packed into that. If you made this many decisions in 45 min. it would be excellent. This is a good example of a game that would likely benefit from a jump start, if you could set up this game, so it was at the midway pt. where the strategies and choices come alive it would be far better. So game is sort of weak for me in the areas of: play time, and drama/excitement. 

There are variants to speed this up, so this may help. It also feels rather dry. I dont recall making any real deals with players (going from memory) so maybe that hurts the flavor.

RATING: 7.1

It doesn't really compare to many modern games, but wouldn't look massively out of place in a collection.

Update: the game is better than I originally gave it credit for. Cashflow really is king and getting cut out of the first few deals can be devastating. It also has possibly the same problem with T&E in that an unfair number of turns can be significant. You certainly want to be the one to end the game.

Rating up from 5.5 to 7.1

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the first economic games I played, and, especially after Monopoly, was an entirely new experience. After many plays, and many other economic games, this one still holds up. Some people dislike the random tile draws. I find that strategic play still carries the day, especially if you get the player count right. For my tastes, the game is best with four. Six is simply too chaotic. Four seems to strike a perfect balance between control and luck of the draw.

That said, the game does show its age. I've never been impressed with the components. And this is coming from a guy who used to own the fabled 1999 Avalon Hill edition with pretty plastic pieces. I sold that edition in exchange for the more portable (and therefore more likely to be played) cardboard edition. After some upgrades to the racks and the addition of a draw bag, it's not so bad! But I'd love to see something that blended the best of both worlds.

Finally, it's a game that demands repeat plays. Especially because mitigating the luck of the draw takes experience, you have to know a bit about what you're trying to do in order to avoid getting stymied mid-game with little cash and even fewer options.

With stock games like Chicago Express available, Acquire doesn't hit the table as often at it used to, but it's still one of my favorites for its simplicity and its subtle opportunities for skillful play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An oldie but a goodie.  Amazingly I didn't play my first game of this until 2009.  If you have someone in the family who loves Monopoly, definitely try to get them to play this.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a great game. I can't believe that if this has been around so long that it isn't in teh public domain (at least in the UK). Nice and easy to play with a whole load of subtlety to it. And I don't see that it's obviously been copied - there are some borrowings of elements of the mechanics - tile-laying in Carc has a nod towards this, and the multiple owning of states in Imperial is kind of derived from this I think, but otherwise it stands very much as it's own game. Relatively quick, no-one really sure who's winning, refined play, and simple rules. This game takes some beating.
This is one of my happiest gaming personal discoveries. Thank you Geek!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Universally acclaimed as a classic, and given its longevity and legions of fans, that's a tough point to argue. It's certainly well designed. For me, though, the game feels devoid of any semblance of warmth, charm, theme or flavor. Strategy is possible, but only if the right tiles fall your way at the right time. It's cold, analytical, abstract and not a whole heck of a lot of fun. Guess if I'm looking for a Sid Sackson classic, I'll stick with Can't Stop which, while equally abstract, nevertheless has all the charisma and accessibility Acquire lacks.

RATING: 9
OK - I'm biased. I played this game back in the 60's with my dad, again and again. I loved it then and I still love it now.  My son and two nephews played it over Thanksgiving, the three of them for the first time, and everyone had a great time.  As my son said, "It really grows on you."  Easy to get into, becomes deeper and more competitive as the game progresses, and when we finished, all three of them were ready for another game.

We played the 1965 version; if you can grab one - do it.

RATING: 7.5
This was the first real (german-style) board game I ever played. I loved it immediately and as a result it hols a special place in my heart. Unfortunately, I've played it a number of times recently and seen that it has some serious flaws in keeping some players in the game until the end. I played a game (4 players) where one player nearly got shut out of the game entirely until counting the money at the end. 

The game plays best as a 3 player game, though I have yet to try it as a 5+ player game. But I feel like as the number of players increases and the time between turns grows, the problems with the game will become more apparent.

:star: Innovative mechanics
:star: Feels unique
:star: Low downtime between turns

:nostar: Multiple paths to victory
:star: Re-playability

RATING: 9
The trick with stock market games is making the side game compelling enough that you care about the stock itself.  Acquire strikes the perfect chord between elegance, luck, and analysis.  The components are a bit grim in presentation but the game is immersive.  And thankfully, the market is bidirectional:  you can buy AND sell stock for a very fluid game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
Economic tile-laying game. Each player invests in hotels, trying to retain a majority of stock. As their empire grows with tile placements, they also start merging, giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizable bonuses, which can then be used to reinvest into other chains. All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks. The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth.
Sid Sackson
3-6 players

Video Review
eekamouse: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/video/6796
UvulaBob: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/video/1196
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An excellent game. Not overly complex but clever design leads to an interactive and tactical classic. You can get a bit buggered by bad early choices for the whole game but hey! that's life.

Highly recommended.

1/7/13
I finally played this about a month back, and have played it two more times since. I love it. It's simplicity meeting complexity throughout. On a player's turn, he does very little mechanically, but what every play does to the game state is complex and deep. This is a must-have game for gamers, and especially for economic gamers.

Everybody should replace their copy of Monopoly with this game.
[COLOR=#FFFFFF]TAGS: euro, economic, classic, tile-laying game, [/COLOR]

RATING: 5

I guess it's okay game mechanics, but the way to compete with the others is quite dull. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the all time classics.  A superior game in every way.  I have the old AH bookcase version as well as the 95 version (the one with the Special Powers Variant) in the big box...with the new version coming out soon I figured I'd revisit this in my thoughts and well going ahead and pumping it up to the coveted 10 spot. This game does deserve it from me. 

UPDATE: I Love the 1965 AH Bookcase edition which I feel is the most functional of all versions. It's small and the plastic pieces seat nicely onto the board keeping things from sliding around like crazy. Thrift store find for $1.49 in complete and what I would rank as EXCELLENT condition.

Additionally I own the 1995 AH version with the "Power Tiles" which I feel completely unbalances the game. Obviously AH thought so too as this is the only edition with the stupid tiles. This edition had a nice look to it though with the lovely board printed wonderfully. Thrift store find for $0.49. Condition was new...the game had never been played all stock cards had HARD/SHARP corners and were still stuck together. However it was w/o shrink wrap and the box suffered water damage and split corners. 

I just got my copy of the 2008 edition as I love the look of it. Smaller size is nice, and lower price is GREAT in my opinion. People here on the geek want to complain about the "quality of the bits" but hey a lower price point very well may go a long way to exposing NEW PEOPLE to this game and gaming in general! Bravo AH on this excellent edition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
SOLD (5/10/08) -- While I don't think this is a bad game, I have two major problems with it:

1) If you're not involved in the first or second merger, you're out without much chance of winning.  You need your company to go defunct quickly to get a majority or minority bonus right away.

2) More often than not, all 6 of the tiles you're holding don't do anything at all, and you can't help but place one of them completely randomly because none of them add to an existing corporation, join corporations, or present the possibility of forming a corporation; they're just off in the middle of nowhere. This is particularly true in the first half of any game.

I have never understood what people see in this game. It's alright, but I feel like I must be missing something, perhaps nostalgia?

Received as gift: Date unknown

RATING: 7
Just brilliant. Why? Unique, elegant and strategic; couched in luck but ruled by long term planning; a fantastic arc as players position and tensions raise in the endgame. I'm close to elevating this to an 8, just need a couple more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This Sid Sackson classic has taken many different forms over the years depending on the publisher. Each player strategically invests in businesses, trying to retain a majority of stock. As the businesses grow with tile placements, they also start merging, giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizable bonuses, which can then be used to reinvest into other chains. All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks for current value or trade them 2-for-1 for shares of the newer, larger business. The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This Sid Sackson classic has taken many different forms over the years depending on the publisher. Each player strategically invests in businesses, trying to retain a majority of stock. As the businesses grow with tile placements, they also start merging, giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizable bonuses, which can then be used to reinvest into other chains. All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks for current value or trade them 2-for-1 for shares of the newer, larger business. The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth.

Some versions of the 3M bookshelf edition included rules for a 2-player variant.

RATING: 6
Very simple, very smart.  A boiled down stock market experience.  Any economic fan needs to own this as filler.  The spacial element is secondary to the abstract element of valuing shares.  Thematically this simulates what markets actually are, barely related to the real world.  

But the random tile draw is annoying and sometimes you can't engineer any ideas.  You need to play this quickly or you'll get annoyed at not having any control.

RATING: 6
04/2009: 7.5
A classic Sackson game. This however, is a really darn good game. A very basic economics game but a really really solid design. I can't help but feel that this game really does reflect the ebb and flow of buying stocks and the tense nature of corporate mergers.. I can really see why this game has withstood the test of time and still remain in the top 100. 

02/2018: 6
Almost a decade later, the game is still solid. However, having played many more games in the interim, there are a few flaws in the game. If you don't have good cash flow and participate in initial mergers to get some cash, you will have a tough time catching up especially if the two larger companies start to form and you don't have any shares in it. There is a rich-get-richer flow to the game where players that can cash in early on the mergers will get more money to compete for shares in other companies. There is no apparent catch up mechanism in the game other than trying to buy early in younger companies. Given how old this game is, it is remarkably streamlined and fits the economic theme to the T. This is certainly Sackson at his best and you really can't fault this design. However, this is not a game for newbies and requires a few plays to see emergent properties of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not bad for such an old game! Economic game with some interesting and clever mechanics. My biggest complaint is importance and need to track the number of stocks of different players, which can be tedious.

RATING: 8
Sackson's masterpiece still compares favorably to games released today, 45 years later, which you really can't say for more than a few games from that era. Acquire is fantastic, agonizing fun. My only complaints about the game are that sometimes, you can get hosed by the tile draws, and sometimes, the game can pretty much be decided by the first and second mergers. Open holdings is preferable with 5 or 6, though I think you could go either way with 3 or 4 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've probably played more games of Acquire over the course of my life than any other game - and I'm still happy to get it out and play it yet again.

I own the 1998/99 Avalon Hill/Hasbro edition with incredibly beautiful components.  The component quality in the currently-in-print AH edition isn't as high, but still pretty nice.  If you are looking to pick up Acquire, put in a bit of legwork and see if you can get the older one first.

Many define Acquire as an economic game, but in truth it's more of an abstract with an economic theme pasted on.  It could be almost exactly the same game with biological entities, farms, or anything else.  Power Grid is an economic game - Acquire is not.

This is a universal recommend - give it a try, no matter your tastes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
1st impression: Fun M&A game. I'd like to play again to see how deep the strategy goes - I suspect not very far. I suspect that once everyone knows what they are doing then the game boils down to tracking majorities and luck.

On the plus side, though, I do like how each player knows some perfect information (their tiles, and their shares), but how valuable that info is depends on how the other players play the game. Through careful observation you can therefore gain clues about their set of information, and add this to your set accordingly. This, of course, is exactly what every good economic game strives for.

RATING: 7
I like the mechanic and how quickly the game plays. I have played with teams of two with six players and it adds a fun new strategic level to the game. Each person plays as individually but can talk and strategize with their teammate. The turn order goes A1,B1,C1,A2,B2,C2 where teams are (A1,A2),(B1,B2) and (C1,C2). At the end of the game the total amount of money for each team is scored.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The first time I played Acquire I thought it would be a definite 10 for me. I usually try not to comment on games until a 2nd or 3rd play, unless I feel like I have a really good grasp of the game. Nevertheless, usually my rating will move by 1, but rarely more after a 2nd play. So I was surprised last night after my 2nd play that my rating dropped about three points to a 7. In a 5 player game, after about the 4th or 5th round of tile playing I found myself entirely out of cash. This would have been alright had something I had an interest in been acquired. As it was not, and as I had no way to trigger the event myself, I spent the rest of the game (1 hr. plus) on the sidelines, watching with no meaningful engagement in the game. Indeed, the rules give the dire warning to mind your cash lest you wind up in my unfortunate situation. Generally, I like unforgiving games, I even seek them out: bring on the punishment of tight money I say! But in the case of Acquire, it seemed like the tight cash situation-- unlike Imperial for example-- can come about through a sort of capricious, uncontrolable (random) path. In other words, tight, unforgiving games that you leave you stranded from poor play: mmmm, gooooood; tight, unforgiving games that leave you stranded from a series of random events: not as tasty. So I will definitely play this again, and perhaps (hopefully!) I'll discover that this truly is mmmmmm, good, kind of unforgiving and that I just played poorly. But until then, I'll "usually be willing to play" vs. "Always want to play and never expect that to change."

All my friends that have played it liked it and it is one of my most popular games. Hasbro edition’s pieces are very good quality and it is good to play in such a colorful setting. I have played more than 30 times until now and every game of Acquire happens to be very different from the earlier ones.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This Sid Sackson classic has taken many different forms over the years depending on the publisher. Each player strategically invests in businesses, trying to retain a majority of stock. As the businesses grow with tile placements, they also start merging, giving the majority stockholders of the acquired business sizable bonuses, which can then be used to reinvest into other chains. All of the investors in the acquired company can then cash in their stocks for current value or trade them 2-for-1 for shares of the newer, larger business. The game is a race to acquire the greatest wealth. I have a recent AH version. 1999 - Avalon Hill large box version. Plastic tile "caps" for gridded board. Chain markers are buildings of three different heights. Theme has been changed from hotels to technology corporations. Went out of print around 2004-05.



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Awesome little game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Classic tile laying stock market game.  Fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The most amazing thing about this game is its pedigree, considering it was released back in the 1960s.  The game isn't without its issues (it seems like every time I play this game now, it's with a different set of house rules to balance out some strong elements), but it's still a finely balanced game between its actions and the reward associated with each one.  I think I still prefer Shark over Acquire (at the very least, it improves the randomness issue), but I wouldn't turn down a play of this every once in a while, either.

1 play: 4 players
1 play: 6 players

RATING: 8
The first time I played this at a friend's house, I felt like I was just being swept along. I couldn't really comprehend the possible consequences of my various actions. I made a late surge in the final disposition of stocks and finished 3rd out of 6. 

My one knock on Acquire is that sometimes you can't draw the tiles you need and run out of money as other players initiate mergers that help them but not you. I've since come to prefer Union Pacific when I want to play a stock game. 

This is still an excellent game, though.

I will admit that the game can be a bit unforgiving to new players, as it is easy to run out of money if you don't have a merger early in the game.

Aquire fue el primer juego "grande" que compré.  Como tal, este juego, junto con "A Través del Desierto", tiene un lugar especial en mi colección.  Por supuesto, el hecho de que este juego me encanta no estorba.  Tengo que admitir que el juego puede ser un poco difícil para jugadores nuevos, ya que es fácil quedarse sin dinero si no hay una adquisición temprana.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A shelf-worn 1966 Bookshelf Edition of Acquire is one of the few heirlooms that survived my biological father, who drowned when I was a 3-month old.  I've moved it from place to place, opened it a few times, and thought "what is this— Scrabble with money?" 

25 years later, when I finally broke it out for a game, I noticed how extremely well-loved (but complete!) the  components were, the cards with creases and rounded corners, the faded board, chipped in a few places... and an hour or so into a game with my wife and two good friends, I found out why.  

Even without the obviously colossal amounts of sentiment surrounding my copy of this game, I'd still give it a 9+.  The only bummer is that it has taken me this long to find out that my dad and I would've had such similar tastes in gaming!

RATING: 8
Excellent game. First time play left me wanting to "have at it immediately again." I royally screwed up the game for everyone else since I discoved I was "color-blind" this game. Tweaks' 3M version of the game only has colored chains with no other identifying traits, such as a letter. Dorko I was, I kept nabbing up the wrong shade of greens/blues. Crikey, I handed the game to Tweaks who was seated to my left. Sorry guys!

Even all my bad plays doesn't detract from the game. I can't wait to play it again - no wonder it's been in print for over 40 years.

It was one of my top ranked games for a long time, but I've recently dropped it a bit. I still love the game, it's just not as nearly perfect as I once thought it was.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Acquire is a solidly "good" game.  At its core is a sort of puzzle-like game about chosing the best times and places to lay your tiles and managing your investment in the various companies.  Knowing which companies to invest stock in, anticipating mergers so that they play favorably for you and how to stay ahead of the other players in holding majority shares, all play important roles.

It is a very family-friendly game and probably ought to replace Monopoly in the casual American household as it features more meaningful strategy, no player-elimination and a much shorter length of play (90 minutes or so).

As an economic/stock market game, it can be a little math-y at times when players must decide how to optimally trade/sell shares but no moreso than most any other game of its genre.

Nothing about Acquire screams with excitement but its gameplay is simple, quick and timeless.  There is a reason it has existed in one edition or another for half a century.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Finally got one! Very happy about this one!

RATING: 6.5
I bought the latest reprint of this game but I'd downloaded the rules from the AH/WotC site a number of years ago when they still had it in print to see if I wanted to buy it. I did but was just barely too late. So, I compared the new and old rules set due to a comment the rules had changed. I see no difference although the rules are rewritten except the old comment players should decide beforehand whether the show or conceal assets is no longer included. Since nothing is said about this one way or the other in the new edition of the rules, it's still a good idea.

It's a good game and an economic strategy game but this doesn't have the "thrill of conquest" that gets the blood pumping.

RATING: 8
While holding a merge tile can make this more dramatic and interesting, it's still a fine game deserving of its revered status.

I routinely expect so-called "classics" to be either marginal or completely awful (Empire Builder, Talisman, etc.), but that just isn't the case here.  Consider the fact that, since Acquire's creation,  no other merger game has even come close to its level of ingenuity or replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
In Acquire, players basically all perform the same strategy: create two-square chains and obtain 4 shares upon initiation while either fighting for minority shareholder in another company or buying stock for cheap in a company destined to exist until the end of the game. Who wins? The people that are fortunate to start with tiles near the middle of the board where their company is more likely to get gobbled up sooner? Or even draw the tiles necessary to form a hotel chain at a reasonable time in the first place? (Gotta love those opening turns where first player has no chain so he dumps a random tile which arbitrarily helps another player create one.) Or how about the folks who are fortunate nobody adds to their chain, making it too big to get bought out and thus less profitable because there's no acquisition bonus? It's a monotonous process that becomes chaotic quickly - too many uncontrollables for serious play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.25
Acquire has a simple game mechanic that manages to capture the essence of the financial world quite well. Its simplicity makes it easy to teach. However, it is very engaging and involves a lot of strategising to play well. Scalability is on the poor side and it works better with more players; 6 players is the best player count.

The only part My Significant Other and I do not quite like is the gaming components of the 2008 edition. They are unattractive and indeed, feels a little cheap. We have since gone on to purchase the 1999 edition and that really adds to the game experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The plastic pieces and the board that holds them, really makes the game so much better. It is the tactile addition that improves the game. The game play is terrific and solidy deserving of the "classic" status that the game has.

Abstract Strategy game where players are building and buying shares in hotels. Money to buy the shares is generated through larger companies merging with smaller companies - and the share holders of the smaller companies get a payout for their shares. The trick is to be the major shareholder in small companies while still holding stock in the larger companies. Most money (cash in hand and value of your share holdings) wins.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I can appreciate its place as a landmark game and the blueprint/inspiration for tile laying games to come, but that's about it. When I see Acquire's rating, I'm baffled. I see a game held up by staunch supporters who love what the game represents to them (either nostalgia or a game ahead of its time -- at the time) and not what the game currently is. 

The allure of Acquire eludes me completely. I think it is an imbalanced, luck-riddled, rich-get-richer, plodding dinosaur. But for some, Acquire is their first kiss -- one of the first "real" games they played that they'll always remember fondly, regardless of the actual details. No matter how much better the kisser might be, and how many better kissers they've made out with, that first kiss still tantalizes the senses and triggers fond memories.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
a classic. paved the way for lots of similar games

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A frustrating game about buying and selling  stocks that never really quite work out the way you planned by the time you finally get to take your turn.  It is often nice to be in "control" of mergers when you draw the right tiles, but trying to manipulate stock holding so you'll end up as the majority is another beast altogether.  Lessons I learned from my first play includes, but does not limit to, having the most liquidity doesn't mean the game is won; running out of money is bad, you should always take the opportunity to buy, even if the choices aren't obvious; trading in stocks for another is almost always mandatory towards the end of the game, it could mean the difference between earning 12000 or half of that.  I'm looking forward to try this again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simple and captivating. It's almost quiet when we play Acquire. Good balance of short- and long-term considerations (hard decisions can come up), and of skill and luck (although sometimes luck is too decisive).

RATING: 7

Nearly everyone who has had enough volition to get over its uninspiring concept (unless you're a broker at heart) has discovered the thrill of this superb game.  Though I have seen a player downtrodden from the start, I have only seen such misfortune once.  Play this game.  The biggest downside of it is that you can run yourself out of cash, and have no way to trigger income, but that's mostly in how much risk you choose to toy with in playing the game.

RATING: 8.25
After your playgroup plays this game about say...50 times in a couple months it starts to get old, haha. Really fun game, easy to learn, there is def. a bit of strategy (you have to remember who buys stock in different hotels/companies), but the game is also somewhat dependent on what tiles you draw. Recommended!

RATING: 9
The only thing that prevents this from being a 10 is the fact that one can fall completely out of contention very early on.  Otherwise, a great game of strategic investments and stock management with a mix of luck-based tile distribution.

Really good stocks game and a great tool for teaching math. The abstract nature of the tiles and grid though seem to be a turn off for many people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I've got a 1966 3M bookshelf edition and a 1999 Avalon Hill (Hasbro) edition.  The 1966 has been played once and has some spotting and shelfwear but is otherwise in fine shape. The 1999's box shows shelf wear but all of the components (the tiles and building tops) are still in their heat sealed bags.  

I bought the 1999 edition at a show; it's got a high trade value, though, so I'm willing to trade it away if the offer is right.

RATING: 8
Classic and elegant economic game. Works well with any number of players. Lot of people find it too abstract tough.
